elements.content: Metal–organic framework (MOF) nanoparticles, also called porous coordination polymers, are a major part of nanomaterials science, and their role in catalysis is becoming central. The extraordinary variability and richness of their structures afford engineering synergies between the metal nodes, functional linkers, encapsulated substrates, or nanoparticles for multiple and selective heterogeneous interactions and activations in these MOF-based nanocatalysts. Pyrolysis of MOF-nanoparticle composites forms highly porous N- or P-doped graphitized MOF-derived nanomaterials that are increasingly used as efficient catalysts especially in electro- and photocatalysis. This review first briefly summarizes this background of MOF nanoparticle catalysis and then comprehensively reviews the fast-growing literature reported during the last years. The major parts are catalysis of organic and molecular reactions, electrocatalysis, photocatalysis, and views of prospects. Major challenges of our society are addressed using these well-defined heterogeneous catalysts in the fields of synthesis, energy, and environment. In spite of the many achievements, enormous progress is still necessary to improve our understanding of the processes involved beyond the proof-of-concept, particularly for selective methane oxidation, hydrogen production, water splitting, CO2 reduction to methanol, nitrogen fixation, and water depollution.

Metal–organic framework (MOF)
nanoparticles, also called
porous coordination polymers, are a major part of nanomaterials science,
and their role in catalysis is becoming central. The extraordinary
variability and richness of their structures afford engineering synergies
between the metal nodes, functional linkers, encapsulated substrates,
or nanoparticles for multiple and selective heterogeneous interactions
and activations in these MOF-based nanocatalysts. Pyrolysis of MOF-nanoparticle
composites forms highly porous N- or P-doped graphitized MOF-derived
nanomaterials that are increasingly used as efficient catalysts especially
in electro- and photocatalysis. This review first briefly summarizes
this background of MOF nanoparticle catalysis and then comprehensively
reviews the fast-growing literature reported during the last years.
The major parts are catalysis of organic and molecular reactions,
electrocatalysis, photocatalysis, and views of prospects. Major challenges
of our society are addressed using these well-defined heterogeneous
catalysts in the fields of synthesis, energy, and environment. In
spite of the many achievements, enormous progress is still necessary
to improve our understanding of the processes involved beyond the
proof-of-concept, particularly for selective methane oxidation, hydrogen
production, water splitting, CO2 reduction to methanol,
nitrogen fixation, and water depollution.

elements.content: The metal–organic frameworks (MOFs), also called porous coordination polymers (PCPs), are two- or three-dimensional porous crystalline materials with infinite lattices synthesized from secondary building units (SBU), metal cations salts or clusters, and polydentate organic ligands with coordination-type connections. Their structure is flexible and can be tuned by variation of the nature of the metal cation and linkers and by postsynthesis modification (PSM). MOFs bridge micro- and mesoporous materials and possess ultrahigh surface areas measured by Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) up to 10000 m2 g–1, which is much higher than zeolites and active carbons. MOF constructions and applications have been pioneered and emphasized in the 1990s by the groups of Robson, Moore, Yaghi, Kitagawa, and Férey. More than 20 000 MOF structures have so far been reported, and some MOFs have been produced in ton scales by BASF and are available at Sigma-Aldrich, Strem Chemical, and MOF technologies. The most currently utilized MOFs are MIL-53, HKUST-1, Fe-BTC, and ZIF-8. Their properties include inter alia gas storage, energy conversion, chemical sensing, drug delivery, proton conductivity, and catalysis, and their applications are in oleo-chemical and textile industries, transportation, all-electric automobile prototypes, food packaging, and respiratory systems.

Introduction, Scope, and
Background
Introduction and Scope
The metal–organic
frameworks (MOFs), also called porous coordination polymers (PCPs),
are two- or three-dimensional porous crystalline materials with infinite
lattices synthesized from secondary building units (SBU), metal cations
salts or clusters, and polydentate organic ligands with coordination-type
connections. Their structure is flexible and can be tuned by variation of the
nature of the metal cation and linkers and by postsynthesis modification
(PSM). MOFs bridge micro- and mesoporous
materials and possess ultrahigh surface areas measured by Brunauer–Emmett–Teller
(BET) up to 10000 m2 g–1, which is much
higher than zeolites and active carbons. MOF constructions and applications have been pioneered and emphasized
in the 1990s by the groups of Robson, Moore, Yaghi, Kitagawa, and Férey. More than 20 000 MOF structures have so far been reported, and some
MOFs have been produced in ton scales by BASF and are available at
Sigma-Aldrich, Strem Chemical, and MOF technologies. The most currently
utilized MOFs are MIL-53, HKUST-1, Fe-BTC, and ZIF-8. Their properties
include inter alia gas storage, energy conversion, chemical sensing,
drug delivery, proton conductivity, and catalysis, and their applications
are in oleo-chemical and textile industries, transportation, all-electric
automobile prototypes, food packaging, and respiratory systems.

elements.content: In the present review, we will first delineate the essential features and basic concepts involving catalysis by MOF nanoparticles (NPs) including synergistic interactions between the NPs and various catalytic components using seminal and major examples. Then we will comprehensively review research works published since the beginning of 2017 and until the first term of 2019, classified by reaction types. Indeed given the exponential growth of the field, the numbers of publications before 2017 and since then are of the same order. These reactions will be divided into three categories: “chemical”, electrocatalytic, and photocatalytic. Finally, we will suggest future prospects with remaining challenges.

then are of the same order. These reactions will be divided into three
categories: “chemical”, electrocatalytic, and photocatalytic.
Finally, we will suggest future prospects with remaining challenges.

elements.content: Seminal catalytic use of a MOF clathrate was reported in 1994 by Fujita et al. These authors constructed a two-dimensional 2D network of Cd­(4,4′-bpy)2(NO3)2 by reaction between Cd­(NO3)2 and (4,4′-bpy), and they used this MOF clathrate as a heterogeneous catalyst for the cyanosilylation of aldehydes. Excellent general reviews on MOFs in catalysis covering up to 2016 are available.
elements.clean_text:
Seminal catalytic use of a MOF clathrate was reported in 1994 by
Fujita et al. These authors constructed
a two-dimensional 2D network of Cd­(4,4′-bpy)2(NO3)2 by reaction between Cd­(NO3)2 and (4,4′-bpy), and they used this MOF clathrate as a heterogeneous
catalyst for the cyanosilylation of aldehydes. Excellent general reviews
on MOFs in catalysis covering up to 2016 are available.

elements.content: The MOFs are superb catalyst templates due to their metal centers, highly ordered porous structure, uniform pore sizes and environments, very high surface areas, and functional organic linkers. The metal located at the nodes of the MOF structure such as Cr, Mn, or Cu possesses free coordination sites following thermal removal of water ligands without great structural change. These coordinatively unsaturated metal sites act as excellent Lewis acid catalysts by themselves or in synergy with encapsulated NPs. Another very efficient method of introduction of catalytically active metal sites in MOF consists in the metalation of ligands located on the MOF linkers either during the MOF synthesis or by postsynthesis modification (PSM, ).
elements.clean_text:
Background
MOF for Catalysis and
NP@MOF
The
MOFs are superb catalyst templates due to their metal centers, highly
ordered porous structure, uniform pore sizes and environments, very
high surface areas, and functional organic linkers. The metal located
at the nodes of the MOF structure such as Cr, Mn, or Cu possesses free coordination sites following thermal removal of water
ligands without great structural change. These coordinatively unsaturated
metal sites act as excellent Lewis acid catalysts by themselves or
in synergy with encapsulated NPs. Another very efficient method of
introduction of catalytically active metal sites in MOF consists in
the metalation of ligands located on the MOF linkers either during
the MOF synthesis or by postsynthesis modification (PSM, ).

elements.content:
Reproduced with permission from ref . Copyright 2009 The Royal Society of Chemistry.

With their very large variety of topologies, MOFs are highly adaptable to catalytic design and can contain various guests including metal- and semiconductor oxide NPs. The leaching of small cluster atoms may eventually be prevented by MOF functional groups. The pore confinement limits the growth of metal and metal oxide NPs and favors the construction of ultrafine nano-objects. The insoluble character of MOFs insures heterogeneous catalysis for easy recycling, and their open channels favor the transport and diffusion of substrates and products with minimized mass-transfer limit. The MOF pore shapes and sizes are uniform and tunable upon design, affording size-selective catalysis. The MOFs can be combined with other nanostructures such as graphene and nanotubes in order to improve conductivity, and they can be calcinated to provide hybrid catalytically efficient metal–carbon and -heteroatom nanocomposites ().

elements.content:
Reproduced with permission from ref . Copyright 2018 Elsevier.

The metal centers and organic linkers are parts of the MOFs that act in synergy with a guest nanocatalyst located inside the MOF cavity. In MOF structures, the metal can be replaced by a variety of Earth-abundant transition metals, and heterometallic MOFs are also accessible. All these multiple advantages of MOFs have already been highlighted. The thermal stability and stability in water are essential factors for uses of MOFs in catalysis. In the early stages of MOF catalysis research, MOF structures such as MOF-5 and MOF-177 that have impressive surface areas and gas storage performances were also used in catalysis but suffered from limited thermal resistance or sensitivity to moisture. More robust MOFs have recently been selected, however. The very thermally robust, water-resistant, and therefore most extensively studied MOF structures in catalysis during the past decade are MOF-74, ZIF-8, CPO-27, UiO-66, Cu-BDC (HKUST-1), MIL-53, and MIL-101. These MOFs withstand prolonged heating in boiling water, as verified by the identity of their X-ray data before and after such water treatments. Postsynthetic metal-cation exchange and ligand functionalization are factors that can improve water resistance whenever needed. The introduction of NPs in MOFs is most often conducted in MOFs by impregnation, but in order to ensure complete NP encapsulation, more sophisticated methods are also used and briefly discussed in the following sections.

elements.content: MOFs are characterized by transmission electron microscopy (TEM), scanning transmission electron microscopy (STEM), powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD, including a check of the thermal stability after the reaction), and BET surface area. After introduction of the metal NPs by the deposition-precipitation method consisting in mixing the metal salt(s) with an aqueous MOF suspension followed by reduction with NaBH4 or another adequate reducing agent, the MOF-NP catalyst is characterized by TEM and high-angle annular dark-field imaging (HAADF), a STEM technique (HADDF-STEM) producing an annular dark-field image formed by very high angle, incoherently scattered electrons. Series of 2D data at various tilting angles using this technique allow a tomographic 3D reconstruction of the metal NP/MOF composite, which shows whether the NPs are located only inside the MOF framework. Measurement of the NP size by TEM only poses a problem because of the small NP size and lack of contrast with the MOF framework, and the charges that accumulate under the electron beam cause distortion of the images. Therefore, the MOF framework may be digested and the metal NPs stabilized using a polymer. For instance ZIF-8 is digested using ethylenediamine tetracetic acid (EDTA) in the presence of poly­(vinylpyrolidone) (PVP, M w = 10 000). Otherwise, nitrogen sorption of the MOF-NP catalyst also shows much size decrease compared to the free MOF. New characterization techniques such as spherical aberration-corrected high-resolution electron microscopy and cryo-electron microscopy may also be applied. The amount of metal contained in the MOFs is inferior to the one of the precursor because some metal components remain in solution or in suspension outside the MOF frameworks. The metal content in MOFs can be determined by inductively-coupled plasma mass spectrometry (ICP-MS). These data together with the NP metal surface determined by TEM allow one to calculate TOF values per NP surface atom. Spatial location of the metal NP in the MOFs, a question rarely addressed that involves the MOF-NP interactions, may be investigated using X-ray synchrotron radiation experiments. The crystallinity of the nanomaterial may be tested by the observation of lattice fringes by HRTEM. Energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDS), eventually called energy dispersive X-ray analysis (EDXA) or also energy dispersive X-ray microanalysis (EDXMA), is used for elemental analysis; this technique is based on the interaction of an X-ray source with the sample and allows one to determine if bimetallic NPs have an alloy or core–shell structure. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) allows one to determine the oxidation states of the metal(s) in the NPs. These techniques may be complemented by Fourier-transformed infrared (FTIR), NMR, and electron paramagnetic resonance (EPR) spectroscopies whenever their use is appropriate.

Characterization of MOF-Nanoparticle Catalysts
MOFs
are characterized by transmission electron microscopy (TEM),
scanning transmission electron microscopy (STEM), powder X-ray diffraction
(PXRD, including a check of the thermal stability after the reaction),
and BET surface area. After introduction
of the metal NPs by the deposition-precipitation method consisting
in mixing the metal salt(s) with an aqueous MOF suspension followed
by reduction with NaBH4 or another adequate reducing agent,
the MOF-NP catalyst is characterized by TEM and high-angle annular
dark-field imaging (HAADF), a STEM technique (HADDF-STEM) producing
an annular dark-field image formed by very high angle, incoherently
scattered electrons. Series of 2D data at various tilting angles using
this technique allow a tomographic 3D reconstruction of the metal
NP/MOF composite, which shows whether the NPs are located only inside
the MOF framework. Measurement of the NP size by TEM only poses a
problem because of the small NP size and lack of contrast with the
MOF framework, and the charges that accumulate under the electron
beam cause distortion of the images. Therefore, the MOF framework
may be digested and the metal NPs stabilized using a polymer. For
instance ZIF-8 is digested using ethylenediamine tetracetic acid (EDTA)
in the presence of poly­(vinylpyrolidone) (PVP, M
w = 10 000). Otherwise, nitrogen
sorption of the MOF-NP catalyst also shows much size decrease compared
to the free MOF. New characterization techniques such as spherical
aberration-corrected high-resolution electron microscopy and cryo-electron
microscopy may also be applied. The amount
of metal contained in the MOFs is inferior to the one of the precursor
because some metal components remain in solution or in suspension
outside the MOF frameworks. The metal content in MOFs can be determined
by inductively-coupled plasma mass spectrometry (ICP-MS). These data together with the NP metal surface
determined by TEM allow one to calculate TOF values per NP surface
atom. Spatial location of the metal NP in the MOFs, a question rarely
addressed that involves the MOF-NP interactions, may be investigated
using X-ray synchrotron radiation experiments. The crystallinity of the nanomaterial may be tested by
the observation of lattice fringes by HRTEM. Energy-dispersive X-ray
spectroscopy (EDS), eventually called energy dispersive X-ray analysis
(EDXA) or also energy dispersive X-ray microanalysis (EDXMA), is used
for elemental analysis; this technique is based on the interaction
of an X-ray source with the sample and allows one to determine if
bimetallic NPs have an alloy or core–shell structure. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) allows
one to determine the oxidation states of the metal(s) in the NPs.
These techniques may be complemented by Fourier-transformed infrared
(FTIR), NMR, and electron paramagnetic resonance (EPR) spectroscopies
whenever their use is appropriate.

elements.content: The NPs are most often synthesized by solution impregnation, whereby the MOF is impregnated by contact with the solution of the metal salts followed by reduction by NaBH4 or other reducing agents. During these syntheses, in many cases there is also formation of NPs on the external MOF surface in addition to incorporation into the MOF. The bimetallic NP@MOF synthesized in this way have been essentially used for hydrogen production from ammonia borane, hydrazine, or formic acid. Another efficient method is the “bottle around the ship” synthesis whereby the MOF is assembled around the NP seed with subsequent growth of the NP@MOF assembly. These nanomaterials obtainable only with a few MOFs (essentially ZIF-8 and UiO) were used for ethylene photodegradation to CO2 and H2O, secondary alcohol oxidation, nitrobenzene hydrogenation, generation of H2 from formic acid, and tandem reductive imination of nitroarenes with carbonyl compounds. A few NP@MOF (MIL-101) catalysts were also synthesized by MOCVD for the reduction of phenols and ketones by Ni–Pd and by the sol–gel method for the hydrogenation of benzene to cyclohexane by Ru–Pt. With MOFs possessing hydrophilic environment and large cavities such as MIL-101, a double-solvent approach (DSA) is sometimes utilized in order to avoid or minimize metal NP formation outside the MOF cavity, an inconvenience encountered with the impregnation method. The quantitative volume of aqueous solution of the metal precursor is selectively introduced into the MOF pores following dispersion in a large volume of organic solvent with a low boiling point. This astute process pioneered by Xu’s group is driven by hydrophilic interactions and capillary forces and is effective for both mono- and bimetallic NPs. It was applied by Jiang’s group to the synthesis of encapsulated core–shell NPs. Pd­(NO3)2·2H2O and CoCl2·6H2O were introduced into MIL-101 using DSA followed by sequential reduction using NH3BH3 of Pd­(II) (E° Pd2+/Pd = 0.915 eV vs SHE), then Co­(II) (E° Co2+/Co = 0.28 eV vs SHE, SHE = standard hydrogen electrode) according to the order of these standard redox potentials. The mild reductant NH3BH3 is selective, whereas the strong reductant NaBH4 is not, leading to the formation of alloyed PdCo NP in MIL-101. Core–shell bimetallic NP catalysts are of interest because the electronic structure and activation property of the shell is modified by the presence of the core. Their synthesis has mostly concerned noble metals and has been influenced by galvanic effects. In various MOFs they have been utilized to catalyze formation of H2 from ammonia borane, 4-nitrophenol reduction, CO oxidation to CO2, and phenylacetylene hydrogenation to styrene. Grinding solid NP precursors with MOFs, applicable only with volatile precursors, avoids the use of solvents but ensures complete precursor encapsulation in the MOF. This technique has been pioneered by Haruta with various MOFs including Al-MIL-53, MOF-5, CPL-1, HKUST-1 and ZIF-8 for the synthesis of encapsulated Au NPs of small size using the volatile gold complex [AuMe2(acac)].

elements.content: Metal NPs have also been generated in MOFs from their precursors simply thermally without the addition of any reducing agent. In many cases, such a method leads to MOF destruction or partial decomposition, depending on the MOF stability and the heating mode. This technique is used in various ways to form new catalysts with different degrees of nanomaterial decomposition, and specific examples will be further discussed. Variation of NP/MOF composites with NPs inside or outside the MOF are known involving stepwise or one-step synthesis of the NPs and MOF depending on the MOF type and procedure. All these methods are attempting to obtain clean, well-defined NPs inside MOFs, but engineering and readily verifying such syntheses remain a difficult challenge.
elements.clean_text:
Metal NPs have also been generated in MOFs from their precursors
simply thermally without the addition of any reducing agent. In many
cases, such a method leads to MOF destruction or partial decomposition,
depending on the MOF stability and the heating mode. This technique
is used in various ways to form new catalysts with different degrees
of nanomaterial decomposition, and specific examples will be further
discussed. Variation of NP/MOF composites
with NPs inside or outside the MOF are known involving stepwise or
one-step synthesis of the NPs and MOF depending on the MOF type and
procedure. All these methods are attempting
to obtain clean, well-defined NPs inside MOFs, but engineering and
readily verifying such syntheses remain a difficult challenge.

elements.content: A specific feature of NP@MOFs is their ability to activate substrates with synergy of interactions with both some part of the MOF framework (Lewis acidic metal, etc.) and the encapsulated nanoparticles, allowing tandem reactions. For instance, it was shown in early examples that phenol coordination to Cr­(III) allowed PdNP@MIL-101-catalyzed hydrogenation of phenol to cyclohexanone at atmospheric pressure and room temperature (rt), coordination inhibiting further hydrogenation to cyclohexanol. MIL-101, a well-known mesoporous material with large pores of 2.9 and 3.4 nm and a high BET surface area of ca. 4000 m2 g–1, has a high density of Cr Lewis acid centers. MOF pores also provide size selectivity. In a seminal example, n-hexene was selectively hydrogenated in the presence of cis-cyclooctene by PtNP@ZIF-8 based on size selectivity of the MOF cavity. PdNP@MIL-101 catalyzed the cyclization of citronellol diastereoselectively forming rac-isopulegol that was further hydrogenated over the PdNPs to (−) menthol. MNP@MIL-101 (M = Pd, Pt) also catalyzed the tandem nitroarene reduction to aromatic amine followed by reaction with an aldehyde or ketone yielding the imine and imine hydrogenation to the secondary arylamine. The presence of an amino group in amino-functionalized MOFs is useful for organic catalysis and tandem reactions. For instance PdNP@NH 2 -MIL-125 efficiently catalyzed formic acid dehydrogenation producing H2. AuNP@NH 2 -MIL-53 catalyzed benzyl alcohol oxidation and Knoevenagel condensation. Yaghi et al. attached sulfonic acid and ammonium groups to UiO-66-type MOFs called UiO-66-S and UiO-66-N, respectively. In methylcyclopentane transformation, the former catalyst selectively promoted the formation of cyclic C6 products, whereas the latter one promoted that of acyclic C6 products. The same MOFs to which NH2 or OMe groups were attached also yielded group-dependent selectivities in benzaldehyde areobic reactions in the presence of ethylene glycol.

elements.content: Finally asymmetric catalysis has also been conducted on MNP@MOF. For instance the presence of cinchonidine, a chiral alcaloïde, in PdNP@MIL-101 resulted in enantioselectivity in the asymmetric hydrogenation of prochiral olefins such as ethyl pyruvate and ethyl-2-oxo-4-phenylbutyrate.
elements.clean_text:
Finally asymmetric catalysis has also been conducted
on MNP@MOF. For instance the presence of cinchonidine, a chiral alcaloïde,
in PdNP@MIL-101 resulted in enantioselectivity in the asymmetric hydrogenation of prochiral
olefins such as ethyl pyruvate and ethyl-2-oxo-4-phenylbutyrate.

elements.content: The use of bimetallic NPs encapsulated in the MOF structure in catalysis allows not only synergistic activation between the NP and the MOF but also synergy between the two metals enhancing catalytic activity compared to those of both individual metal NPs. The bimetallic NPs can be alloys or core–shell NPs.
elements.clean_text:
Bimetallic NP@MOF Catalysis
The
use of bimetallic NPs encapsulated in the MOF structure in catalysis
allows not only synergistic activation between the NP and the MOF
but also synergy between the two metals enhancing catalytic activity
compared to those of both individual metal NPs. The bimetallic NPs
can be alloys or core–shell NPs.

elements.content: In the PdNP@MIL-101-catalyzed cyclization of citronellol diastereoselectively forming rac-isopulegol that was further hydrogenated over the PdNPs to (−) menthol cited above in 1.2.4, the presence of Ag in the PdAg alloy slowed down the reaction, rendering it more selective (). AuPd@MIL-101 selectively catalyzed oxidation of toluene to benzyl benzoate in air. With another MOF, Pd@UiO-66-NH 2 benzyl alcohol reacted to selectively yield 2-phenyl-1,3-dioxolane via formation of benzaldehyde and further acetalization using ethylene glycol. The bifunctional MOF PdPt@MM-MIL-53 containing both acidic and basic sites catalyzed oxidant-free secondary alcohol dehydrogenation to ketones and H2.

There are also NPs that are combined with other species, and in most cases, a metal NP was combined with a metal oxide in the MOF structure. For instance AuMO x @MOF-5 (M = Zn, Ti, x = 1, 2) in which both metal oxides strongly interacted with the AuNPs catalyzed benzyl alcohol oxidation in the liquid phase with higher selectivities and activities than Au@MOF-5. Metal oxide NPs and their molecular cousins, the polyoxometallates (POMs), play important roles in MOF nanomaterial catalysis, because their hydrophilic oxygen atom activates the hydrogen atoms of water and OH-containing molecules. Metal NPs can also act in synergy with a variety of other nanoparticles and other molecular ensembles and such applications have been reviewed.

elements.content: MOFs act in synergy in catalytic reactions in various ways using their SBUs, linkers, or PSM with functional groups such as amines. Yaghi and Somorjai’s group showed that variation of the acidic properties of linking ligands in UiO-66 led to different product selectivities and activities of embedded PtNPs in the gas-phase conversion of methylcyclopentane to acyclic isomer, olefins, cyclohexane, and benzene. MOFs not only provide size selectivity but also were shown to boost the concentrations and reactivities of gases such as H2 or CO in MOF cavities as shown for instance in PdNP-catalyzed hydrogenation of CC bonds with H2 and aminocarboxylation or aminocarbonylation of aryl iodides with CO, respectively.

elements.content: A good proportion of examples of tandem reactions with NPs@MOF catalysts involved the Knoevenagel reaction (see for recent reports on this reaction), and typical early tandem examples briefly follow. For instance, Tang reported the Knoevenagel reaction of 4-nitrobenzaldehyde with malononitrile to 2-(4-nitrobenzylidene)­malononitrile catalyzed by Pd@IRMOF-3 in which the MOF was amino-functionalized, and this reaction was followed by hydrogenation of the nitro group to the amino group. In another example, Raja’s group reported the one-pot and heterogeneous selective oxidation of primary alcohols in tandem with the Knoevenagel condensation reaction catalyzed by AuNP@UiO-66-NH2.
elements.clean_text:
Tandem Reactions
A good proportion
of examples of tandem reactions with NPs@MOF catalysts involved the
Knoevenagel reaction (see  for recent reports on this reaction),
and typical early tandem examples briefly follow. For instance, Tang
reported the Knoevenagel reaction of 4-nitrobenzaldehyde with malononitrile
to 2-(4-nitrobenzylidene)­malononitrile catalyzed by Pd@IRMOF-3 in
which the MOF was amino-functionalized, and this reaction was followed
by hydrogenation of the nitro group to the amino group. In another example, Raja’s group reported
the one-pot and heterogeneous selective oxidation of primary alcohols
in tandem with the Knoevenagel condensation reaction catalyzed by
AuNP@UiO-66-NH2.

elements.content: Whereas MOF-based catalysts described above involve metal-MOF as catalysts or parts of catalysts in which the MOF itself is present in its integrity during the whole reaction time, MOFs have also been pyrolized at various temperatures (most often between 700 and 1000 °C) for a usage as self-sacrificing templates toward the fabrication of highly porous carbon-based materials (). These MOF-derived nanomaterials benefit from precise morphologies, hierarchical porosities, and doping with heteroatoms, metal NPs, and metal oxide NPs. With high BET surfaces, they present a large density of active sites and therefore serve as excellent and durable heterogeneous catalysts, cocatalysts, or catalyst supports for a variety of reactions. This area has been developed relatively recently, and a large number of rationally designed examples are found herein, in particular, in the electrocatalysis and photocatalysis sections. Initiation of this area during the period before 2017 has been systematically reviewed by the groups of Song and Zhang and Li.
elements.clean_text:
MOF-Derived Catalysts
Whereas MOF-based
catalysts described above involve metal-MOF as catalysts or parts
of catalysts in which the MOF itself is present in its integrity during
the whole reaction time, MOFs have also been pyrolized at various
temperatures (most often between 700 and 1000 °C) for a usage
as self-sacrificing templates toward the fabrication of highly porous
carbon-based materials (). These MOF-derived nanomaterials benefit from precise morphologies,
hierarchical porosities, and doping with heteroatoms, metal NPs, and
metal oxide NPs. With high BET surfaces, they present a large density
of active sites and therefore serve as excellent and durable heterogeneous
catalysts, cocatalysts, or catalyst supports for a variety of reactions.
This area has been developed relatively recently, and a large number
of rationally designed examples are found herein, in particular, in
the electrocatalysis and photocatalysis sections. Initiation of this
area during the period before 2017 has been systematically reviewed
by the groups of Song and Zhang and Li.

elements.content: Hydrogen generation from suitable hydrogen storage inorganic solid materials, in particular sodium borohydride (NaBH4), ammonia-borane (NH3·BH3, AB), hydrous hydrazine (H2NNH2·H2O), and formic acid (HCOOH, FA) is an important component of advances in hydrogen technology. Rossin et al. reviewed catalyzed H2 evolution from borohydrides, AB, sodium alanate and hydrazine in MOFs either thermally or upon hydrolysis. Most studies are now focusing on hydrolysis reactions yielding a higher H2 content than thermolysis that also gives various polymers from boron hydrides.
elements.clean_text:
Catalysis of Organic Reactions
Hydrogen Evolution from Inorganic Hydrides
Hydrogen
generation from suitable hydrogen storage inorganic solid
materials, in particular sodium borohydride (NaBH4), ammonia-borane
(NH3·BH3, AB), hydrous hydrazine (H2NNH2·H2O), and formic acid (HCOOH,
FA) is an important component of advances in hydrogen technology. Rossin et al. reviewed catalyzed H2 evolution from borohydrides, AB, sodium alanate and hydrazine in
MOFs either thermally or upon hydrolysis. Most studies are now focusing on hydrolysis reactions yielding a
higher H2 content than thermolysis that also gives various
polymers from boron hydrides.

elements.content: Sodium borohydride has been a very popular potential hydrogen storage material that has still been extensively investigated over the past decade. NaBH4 is a well-known reducing agent, and its gravimetric hydrogen storage capacity is as high as 10.8 wt %. In 1953, Schlesinger et al. reported the reaction of NaBH4 with water generating 4 mol of hydrogen per mol NaBH4 and sodium metaborate (NaBO2) under ambient conditions. NaB H 4 + 2 H 2 O → NaB O 2 + 4 H 2

elements.content: This self-hydrolysis is slow, but the reaction between NaBH4 and water becomes fast when the temperature rises 100 °C, and acids and certain catalysts help to speed up the reaction, even at rt. Therefore, appropriate catalysts are required in order to accelerate the hydrolysis of NaBH4 at rt. Among various catalysts toward this reaction, cobalt NPs are recognized as one of the most efficient first-raw transition metal NP catalysts for H2 production from NaBH4 hydrolysis, and they are also widely used owing to their low cost. Luo et al. synthesized a series of Earth-abundant first-raw transition metal NPs embedded in ZIF-8 and showed that the best activity for NaBH4 hydrolysis was that of CoNPs@ZIF-8 with a rate of 14 000 mLH2 min–1 gCo –1 and 19 400 mLH2 min–1 gCo –1 at 30 °C ().

elements.content: There is now increasing interest for the controlled pyrolysis of MNP@MOF structures to fabricate efficient nanocomposite catalysts for H2 evolution from NaBH4. A porous magnetic cobalt/carbon composite (MCCC) was prepared using the cobalt-based ZIF-67 as a precursor (carbonized at 600 °C) by Lin et al. A cobalt content of 33 wt % made MCCC an efficient catalyst to hydrolyze NaBH4 with an E a value of 64.3 kJ mol–1. In the presence of 1 M NaOH, MCCC showed superior catalytic capability with an activation energy value E a decreasing to 25.8 kJ mol–1. A Co–Co3O4@carbon composite possessing a core–shell Co–Co 3 O 4 @C structure was synthesized from a Co-MOFs@glucose polymer by Du and Li et al. by controlled thermolysis followed by partial oxidation. Synergistic interactions between Co and Co3O4 NPs was found in Co–Co 3 O 4 @C and afforded a H2 generation rate of 5360 mL min–1 gCo –1 for NaBH4 hydrolysis. Co@C composites were prepared by carbonization of Co@MOF precursors at various temperatures, and Co@C-700 in which Co NPs were highly dispersed in nanoporous C was found to be the best of these catalysts for NaBH4 hydrolysis; upon recycling five times, 93% of the activity was retained.

elements.content: Lithium borohydride has been studied much more rarely than NaBH4 as hydrogen storage material, in spite of its high hydrogen volumetric and gravimetric contents. Recently, studies of hydrogen production from both LiBH4 and NH3BH3 have been reviewed.

elements.content: Ammonia-borane has received much attention because of its high hydrogen content (19.6% wt), low molecular weight (30.87 g mol–1), high solubility in common solvents, and high stability under ambient conditions. These properties make AB a convenient source of H2 upon hydrolytic dehydrogenation that can be achieved under ambient conditions only in the presence of suitable catalysts. Various late transition metal NP catalysts were generated in MOFs for hydrolysis of AB. Some reports also involve H2 release from methylamine borane (CH3NH2BH3) hydrolysis (for instance catalyzed by CuNP@MIL-101). These catalysts provoke the evolution of 3 mol H2 upon AB hydrolysis, the reaction being zero-order in AB and first-order in catalyst. The stoichiometry of AB hydrolysis catalyzed by NPs was shown by Duan and Chen, as follows: H 3 N · B H 3 + 4 H 2 O → N H 4 + B ( OH ) 4 − + 3 H 2

elements.content: Noble metal nanoparticles (NPs) have catalyzed the reaction with high hydrogen evolution rates. The practical use of noble-metal NPs is limited, however, owing to their high cost and global reserve scarcities. Thus, the improvement of non-noble metal catalysts possessing similar catalytic performance is important. Recently, Co-SiO2-N-doped porous C was prepared by heating at 800 °C under N2 Co@ZIF-67@SiO 2 microtubes, and this nanocomposite catalyzed H2 production from AB at a rate of 8.4 mol min–1 mol­(Co)−1 with an activation energy of 36.1 kJ mol–1 and at least 10-time reusability. The maximum turnover frequency (TOF) of 90.1 min–1 was achieved with CoNCs@PCC-2a by Zhou, which was an excellent result for non-noble metal catalysts. Co–Zn@ZIF-67 was heated at 800 °C yielding a Co–N-doped microporous C that catalyzed ammonia borane hydrolysis with a turnover frequency of 7.6 mol H2 mol Co min–1 and E a = 44.9 kJ mol–1.

elements.content: Several bimetallic catalysts on MOFs have been synthesized to minimize and optimize the use of noble metals. Enhanced catalytic activities compared to those of monometallic counterparts were found in these bimetallic catalysts, mainly thanks to the strong bimetallic synergistic effects between the two metals and with the MOF host. Ni 0.66 Co 0.19 P 0.15 /OPC-300 synthesized by Xu’s group by calcination of ZIF-67 at 300 °C exhibited good catalytic activity for AB hydrolysis. This catalyst benefited from the synergy between two metals, P and oxygen-doped porous carbon. In the presence of 0.4 M NaOH, the TOF value increased to 95.24 molH2 molcat –1 min–1 at 298 K. Ni 2 Pt@ZiF-8 was shown to achieve a TOF of 600 mol H2·molcatal –1 min–1 under ambient conditions, which was around 87 times higher than the TOF of the noble metal-only catalyst Pt@ZIF-8, and gave much better results than other transition metal bimetallic catalysts. ZIF-8 in this catalyst appears extremely selective for AB hydrolysis compared to other supports ().

elements.content: Hydrous hydrazine (H2NNH2·H2O), with an hydrogen content of 8.0 wt %, has been shown to be a promising hydrogen carrier. Care must be exercised, however, because explosion is a dangerous hazard of hydrazine, in particular in the presence of a metal catalyst. Hydrazine selectively decomposes to hydrogen and nitrogen at rt in the presence of catalysts in two ways according to complete decomposition () or incomplete decomposition (): H 2 NN H 2 → 2 H 2 ( g ) + N 2 ( g ) ⁣ ΔH = − 95.4 kJ mo l − 1 3 H 2 NN H 2 → 4 N H 3 ( g ) + N 2 ( g ) ⁣ Δ H = − 157 kJ mol − 1

elements.content: These two decomposition reactions depend on the nature of the catalysts and reaction conditions. It is very important to explore highly efficient catalysts over the complete decomposition of hydrous hydrazine in order to obtain a high efficiency of hydrogen generation. Recently, various bimetallic NPs immobilized by functionalized MOFs have been synthesized for selective decomposition of H2NNH2·H2O to generate H2. Ni 0.8 Pt 0.2 /MIL-101-NH 2 synthesized by Su and Gu et al. exhibited 100% of H2 selectivity for the dehydrogenation of hydrous hydrazine. A high TOF value of 137 h–1 at 298 K was achieved, which was assigned to the electronic state of active NiPt NPs, the interaction strength between hydrous hydrazine molecule and the electron-donating NH2 group in the MOF supports. The switch to Earth-abundant catalysts is more and more desired. Hydrazine borane, N2H4BH3, also is a new sophisticated precursor of choice for catalytic deshydrogenation. The bimetallic Ni and Pt NPs in Ni 0.9 Pt 0.1 /MIL-101_A synthesized by Lu et al. exhibited outstanding activity for complete H2 evolution from dehydrogenation of both N2H4·H2O (TOF value of 140 molH2·mol(Ni+Pt) –1 h–1 at 303 K) and N2H4BH3 (TOF value of 400 molH2·mol(Ni+Pt) –1 h–1 at 303 K), and the catalyst displayed excellent reusability for 20 cycles of reactions. The catalytic activity of Ni 0.9 Pt 0.1 /MIL-101_A for H2 evolution from N2H4BH3 is a little higher than from N2H4·H2O, probably due to the quick hydrolysis of the BH3 group of N2H4BH3. Soon afterward, the same group synthesized another bimetallic catalyst, Rh 0.8 Ni 0.2 /MIL-101, that showed excellent catalytic performance for the dehydrogenation of N2H4BH3 and N2H4·H2O with 100% conversion and hydrogen selectivity and high total turnover frequencies (TOF) up to 1200 and 428.6 molH2·mol(Rh+Ni) –1 h–1, respectively, higher than other Rh-based catalysts. The noble-metal-free catalyst Ni 0.5 Fe 0.5 –CeO x /MIL-101, prepared by liquid impregnation of MIL-101, showed full selective conversion with excellent hydrogen generation activity (351.3 h–1).

elements.content: Formic acid (FA, HCOOH, pK a = 3.75) is a safe colorless liquid with a high hydrogen content (4.4 wt %) that is industrially obtained by methyl formate hydrolysis. It has been regarded as a potential carrier for the production and storage of hydrogen for already half a century. Hydrogen can be liberated from FA through a dehydrogenation reaction (): HCOOH → C O 2 + H 2 However, FA can be decomposed in another way, which produces CO (). HCOOH → CO + H 2 O

elements.content: In order to selectively obtain H2, avoid the unwelcoming side reaction, metal NPs supported on various MOFs (such as NH2-MIL-125, MIL-100­(Fe), ZIF-8, and UiO-66) for the dehydrogenation of FA have been widely investigated. AuPd@MIL-101-NH 2 synthesized by Gu and Su et al., catalyzed dehydrogenation of FA with 100% of H2 selectivity and high activity, and an initial TOF value of 526 h–1 was obtained at 298 K. The electron-donating NH2 groups in MIL-101 frameworks enhanced the catalytic activity. Another bimetallic catalyst, PdAg@ZrO 2 /C/rGO (), from the calcination of UiO-66-GO, was reported by Xu et al. and exhibited excellent activity for the dehydrogenation of FA with a TOF value of 4500 h–1 at 333 K. In such a strategy, homogeneous coverage of the GO surface with MOFs ensures uniform dispersion of the metal oxide/porous carbon on reduced GO, and the NP electronic structure is favorably modified by the metal oxide toward catalysis. The released gas mixture was only a mixture of CO2 and H2. The introduction of ZrO2 benefited the formation of the electron-rich PdAg surface via electron transfer and thereby improved the catalytic performance for FA dehydrogenation. The catalyst Cr 0.4 Pd 0.6 /MIL-101-NH 2 reported by Wang and Zhao and synthesized by impregnation followed by reduction of the metal cationic precursor showed an excellent ZrO2@C activity with an initial TOF value of 2009 molH2 molPd –1 h–1 at 323 K.

elements.content: There is an increasing number of reports concerning catalysis of hydrogen generation catalyzed by nanomaterials resulting from thermolysis of NP@MOF nanomaterials. For instance, Xue and Wang’s group reported the formation of ZrO2@C upon pyrolysis of a UiO-66 precursor. Decomposition of FA using this heterogeneous catalyst Pd/ZrO 2 @C was achieved at 60 °C at a TOF of 8588 h–1, with 100% selectivity in H2. In another example, a nanosuper tetragonal ZrO2-embedded carbon synthesized by calcinating a Zr-MOF served as an excellent support for PdAg NPs in the catalyst PdAg@ZrO 2 /C; the latter exhibited an excellent activity (TOF: 9206 h–1) for the decomposition of FA at 50 °C.

elements.content: Numerous catalysts based on MOFs have been employed for reduction reactions, such as the hydrogenation of compounds with unsaturated carbon bonds and the hydrogenation of nitro compounds, aldehydes, CO2, CO, and Cr­(VI).

Reduction
Numerous
catalysts based
on MOFs have been employed for reduction reactions, such as the hydrogenation
of compounds with unsaturated carbon bonds and the hydrogenation of
nitro compounds, aldehydes, CO2, CO, and Cr­(VI).

elements.content: The hydrogenation of alkenes and alkynes is one of the main reactions in chemical industry and organic synthesis. Pd catalysts are largely used and are among the most effective catalysts for hydrogenation of multiple carbon–carbon bonds. Heterogeneous catalysts involving MOFs are either of the type MNP@MOF in which the MNP is embedded inside the MOF structure or inorganic composite materials resulting from the calcination of the MNP@MOF compounds taken as precatalysts.
elements.clean_text:
Hydrogenation of Unsaturated Hydrocarbons
The hydrogenation of alkenes and alkynes is one of the main reactions
in chemical industry and organic synthesis. Pd catalysts are largely used and are among the most effective catalysts
for hydrogenation of multiple carbon–carbon bonds. Heterogeneous catalysts involving MOFs are
either of the type MNP@MOF in which the MNP is embedded inside the
MOF structure or inorganic composite materials resulting from the
calcination of the MNP@MOF compounds taken as precatalysts.

elements.content: Pd/F-ZnO@ZIF-8 was synthesized by Zhang et al. using flowerlike ZnO as both support of PdNPs and Zn2+ source of ZIF-8. Using this catalyst a conversion of 99.80% for hydrogenation of 1-hexene to 1-hexane was obtained after 10 h. A sub-2 nm bimetallic Pd-containing catalyst, PdZn@ZIF-8C, synthesized by Chen and Zhou et al., displayed 80% selectivity in the selective hydrogenation of acetylene to ethylene. The conversion of acetylene was nearly total, but some nanoparticle aggregation appeared, and the catalytic performance of PdZn@ZIF-8C then decreased. Cai et al. designed bimetallic Pd–Ni@MIL-100­(Fe) that catalyzed reversible dehydrogenation and hydrogenation of quinolone derivatives. Excellent cyclic performance was demonstrated, and there was no significant decrease in catalytic performance after reusing 6 times (). The authors believed that the Lewis acid sites on the MIL-100­(Fe) were favorable due to weak electron-donating Pd particles enhancing the catalytic properties of Pd–Ni@MIL-100­(Fe).

elements.content: Catalysts resulting from the calcination of MNP@MOF benefit from the synergies between the metal(s), C, and N in microporous C materials. For instance, Pd@CN prepared upon calcination of ZIF-67 by Chen et al., possesses good catalytic performance (conversion: 95.6%, selectivity: 94.9% after 95 min) and excellent stability (no significant decrease after fourth cycle) for the hydrogenation of phenol to cyclohexanone. Soon afterward, the same group further synthesized Pd@CN D from the calcination of ZIF-67 and DICY. Pd@CN D exhibited a better conversion (96.1%) and selectivity (94.1%) toward the hydrogenation of phenol to cyclohexanone. Indeed it benefited from the introduction of DICY as an additional source of nitrogen. Luo’s group has applied the so-called MOF+ technique for the synthesis of the catalyst Zn-MOF-74@(Pd@Fe 2 O 3 ) and its use in efficient alkene hydrogenation and selective phenylacetylene semihydrogenation. This MOF+ technique consists in the reaction of a Fe­(II) or Fe­(III) salt with a phenol-containing MOF at high temperature, which leads to the formation of Fe2O3 on the MOF surface. Besides Pd, catalysts with some other metal NPs in MOFs also work well. Lin et al. reported that the Ti8(μ2-O)8(μ2-OH)4 node of the catalyst support Ti-BDC MIL-125 offers a single-site model of TiO2. CoII-hydride supported by TiIII in Ti-BDC MIL-125 appeared as the catalytically active species for benzene hydrogenation with a TOF value of 7017 h–1 with 0.005 mol % Ti 8 -BDC-CoCl for the hydrogenation of benzene (). Ti 8 -BDC-CoCl also showed good catalytic performances for the hydrogenation of substituted benzenes and was promising for the size-selective hydrogenation of arenes because of the size exclusion effect of MOF catalysts.

elements.content: Yamashita et al. reported pyrolysis of Ni-MOF-74 at 300 °C and obtained a NiNP-carbon/Ni-MOF-74 core–shell nanomaterial. The resulting Ni-MOF-74–300 exhibited high catalytic performance for the hydrogenation of 1-octene (conversion: 97% after 0.5 h), due to the highly dispersed and small NiNP core. This catalyst also showed size selectivity that benefited from the carbonaceous shell. The catalysts RhCoNi@ZIF-67­(Co) and RhCoNi@MOF-74­(Ni) were synthesized by Kuang et al. using RhCoNi alloys as self-sacrificing templates and HnIM and DOT as etchant and coordination reagent, respectively (). These two RhCoNi@MOF catalysts displayed various size selectivities for the hydrogenation of alkene because of the difference of the aperture sizes in the two MOF shells. For example, the conversion of hexene was close to 100%, but the conversion of cyclohexene was only 10% with RhCoNi@ZIF-67­(Co) as hydrogenation catalyst, because the shortest size of 1-hexane (3.0 Å) is smaller, whereas the shortest size of cyclohexene (4.8 Å) is much larger than the aperture size of ZIF-67 (3.4 Å). However, lack of recycle performance was a major weakness of these two catalysts.

elements.content: Catalytic hydrogenation of nitroarenes to the corresponding aniline products is of great importance in particular for detoxification, organic synthesis, access to pharmaceuticals, and production of dyes with recent emphasis on the Earth-abundant first-raw transition-metal-containing nanocatalysts. Since the middle of the 19th century, the reduction of nitrobenzene to the aniline dye has been very popular, and in the 20th century, it has been extended to a large number of derivatives that are industrially produced by high-temperature heterogeneously catalyzed hydrogenation. Selectivity of the nitro reduction in halogeno-substituted nitroarene is especially crucial because of the easy hydrogenolysis of the iodo substituent in the iodo derivatives that are useful in further coupling reactions. This selectivity problem has been solved in the mid-2000s by Corma’s and Qiu’s groups using oxide-supported nanogold and nanosilver catalysts, respectively.
elements.clean_text:
Reduction of Nitroarenes
Catalytic
hydrogenation of nitroarenes to the corresponding aniline products
is of great importance in particular for detoxification, organic synthesis,
access to pharmaceuticals, and production of dyes with recent emphasis
on the Earth-abundant first-raw transition-metal-containing nanocatalysts. Since the middle of the 19th
century, the reduction of nitrobenzene to the aniline dye has been
very popular, and in the 20th century, it has been extended to a large
number of derivatives that are industrially produced by high-temperature
heterogeneously catalyzed hydrogenation. Selectivity of the nitro reduction in halogeno-substituted nitroarene
is especially crucial because of the easy hydrogenolysis of the iodo
substituent in the iodo derivatives that are useful in further coupling
reactions. This selectivity problem has been solved in the mid-2000s
by Corma’s and Qiu’s groups using oxide-supported nanogold
and nanosilver catalysts, respectively.

elements.content: The MOF-based catalysts have recently been shown to bring about competitive selectivity and efficiency, even with earth-abundant metal-based catalysts. Zhang’s group reported the MOF catalyst Cu-BTC@Fe3O4 (BTC = 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylate) for nitroarene reduction by NaBH4 to anilines in aqueous medium under mild conditions and catalyst separation with an external permanent magnet allowing six-time recycling. Gascon et al. synthesized Co@mesoNC with dispersed Co-Nx sites by carbonization of a bimetallic Zn/Co ZIF precursor. Co@mesoNC shows good catalytic performance for the hydrogenation of nitrobenzene and excellent chemoselectivity in hydrogenation of substituted nitroarenes; it selectively reduced the nitro group without affecting double bonds and other substituents such as halogen, −OCH3, and −COCH3. Upon recycling, the nitrobenzene hydrogenation catalyst Co@mesoNC, the conversion of nitrobenzene decreased to 51% after the fourth run, which was mainly ascribed to fouling by deposits in the catalyst pores. Another Co-based catalyst, Co 2 P/CNx nanocubes, synthesized from red-phosphorus and ZIF-67 by Queen et al., displayed excellent catalytic properties for the selective hydrogenation of nitroarenes. Loss of catalytic activity was observed after 3 runs in the recycling experiment, owing to cobalt leaching from Co 2 P/CNx. The same group also reported Co 3 S 4 /CN hollow nanoboxes prepared from ZIF-67 and possessing good activity and selectivity for the hydrogenation of nitroarenes.

elements.content: Noble metal-based catalysts are still used for the hydrogenation of nitrobenzene. Bimetallic Co:Ag­(1:1)@NC, reported by Ma et al., selectively catalyzed the hydrogenation of halogenated nitrobenzenes without dehalogenation, and good catalytic activity remained after five reaction cycles. Pd/NH 2 -UiO-66 synthesized by Ahn et al. was effective in nitrobenzene hydrogenation (conversion, 98%; selectivity, 99%), and the catalyst was used up to 4 cycles.

elements.content: The reduction of nitrophenols in aqueous solution, in particular 4-nitrophenol (4-NP), is a standard in nanoparticle catalysis that has encountered considerable success. This is due to the toxicities of nitrophenols and to the kinetics that are easily followed by the decrease of the 4-NP band at 400 nm. The NP-catalyzed reaction proceeds best with Au and Pd NPs, and its kinetics has been shown by Ballauff’s group to proceed according to a Langmuir–Hinshelwood model according to which the rearrangement of the substrate (nitrophenol and reductant) is the rate-determining step that proceeds more slowly than reversible migration of substrates to the nanoparticle surface. The reductant is most of the time NaBH4, but other reductants such as hydrogen, hydrazine hydrate, and formic acid have also been used. Cu 2 O@ZIF-8 synthesized by Ma and Cheng et al. exhibited excellent activity (rate constant: 0.28 min–1) and good recycle performance (rate constant: 0.22 min–1 for the fifth cycle) for the hydrogenation of 4-nitrophenol, indicating that the Cu2O core was well protected by the ZIF-8 shell. Karahan et al. reported the synthesis of Cu-3­(btc)2 and CuIm2 MOFs and their annealing yielding the nanoporous nanomaterials Cu/Cu2O@C and Cu@N–C that catalyzed the reduction of various aromatic nitro derivatives to aromatic amines. The reactions were followed by UV–vis spectroscopy, and the catalyst Cu/Cu2O@C performed better than Cu@N–C. Cu@C and Zn@C synthesized by Qiu and Zhang et al. derived from Cu-MOF and Zn-MOF upon pyrolysis displayed good catalytic activity for 4-NP reduction (rate constant: 19.5 × 10–3 s–1 for Cu@C, 9.86 × 10–3 s–1 for Zn@C), without significant activity decrease after 8 reaction cycles. MDNM­(75Zn25Ni), prepared from MOF-74 by Jhung et al., achieved a TOF value of 2239 min–1 for 4-NP reduction (based on Ni).

elements.content: Pt/NPC-900 and Ni/NPC-900 synthesized from HKUST-1 (Cu-MOF) by Li and Zhang et al. were reported to catalyze the hydrogenation of nitrophenols. Similar reaction rates for 2/3/4-NP hydrogenations were observed with Ni/NPC-900, whereas Pt/NPC-900 displayed different selectivities toward these reactions. The difference was suggested to originate from the different distributions of Ni and Pt species in the NPC support.

elements.content: Good performances were obtained with 2D MOFs. Upon using ZIF-67 as precursor, 2-D porous Ni 3 N-Co 3 N was prepared by Fu et al. upon pyrolysis, and the conversion of 4-NP with Ni 3 N-Co 3 N remained at 80% after 10 runs. Another 2D catalyst, Au-1@NMOF-Ni, synthesized by Wen and Lu et al., is an ultrasmall Au NP (∼1 nm) incorporated into a 2D NMOF-Ni nanosheet (), and a rate constant of 0.404 min–1 was determined. Au-1@NMOF-Ni was used more than 10 cycles without significant activity reduction because the confined cavities of MOF inhibited aggregation and migration of Au NPs.

N remained at 80% after 10 runs. Another 2D catalyst, Au-1@NMOF-Ni, synthesized
by Wen and Lu et al., is an ultrasmall Au NP (∼1 nm) incorporated
into a 2D NMOF-Ni nanosheet (), and a rate constant of 0.404 min–1 was determined.
Au-1@NMOF-Ni was used more than 10 cycles without significant activity reduction
because the confined cavities of MOF inhibited aggregation and migration
of Au NPs.

elements.content: The catalysts Au 25 (SG) 18 @ZIF-8 and Au 25 (SG) 18 /ZIF-8, reported by Shi et al., were synthesized by encapsulating Au25(SG)18 into ZIF-8 and upon impregnating Au25(SG)18 onto the surface of ZIF-8, respectively (). The reduction of 4-NP was achieved within 12 min with the catalyst Au 25 (SG) 18 /ZIF-8, while it needed more than 15 h with the catalyst Au 25 (SG) 18 @ZIF-8. This remarkable contrast demonstrated the different distribution of Au clusters in ZIF-8 and showed that the Au clusters on the surface of ZIF-8 are more accessible for 4-NP than the encapsulated Au clusters, which made Au 25 (SG) 18 /ZIF-8 more favorable than Au 25 (SG) 18 @ZIF-8 to complete the substrate reduction.

elements.content: In sum, a significant pace has recently been accomplished by the crucial selective reduction of nitro derivatives using NaBH4 as a convenient reductant to amines, in particular with Earth-abundant MNP-MOF- or MNP-MOF-derived catalysts. It would be useful to develop the use of other simpler and cheaper reductants that could be extended to industrial production such as H2 itself, other hydrogen sources such as formic acid, hydrazine hydrate, and transfer hydrogenation systems, but all of them also present some specific drawbacks.
elements.clean_text:
In sum, a significant
pace has recently been accomplished by the
crucial selective reduction of nitro derivatives using NaBH4 as a convenient reductant to amines, in particular with Earth-abundant
MNP-MOF- or MNP-MOF-derived catalysts. It would be useful to develop
the use of other simpler and cheaper reductants that could be extended
to industrial production such as H2 itself, other hydrogen
sources such as formic acid, hydrazine hydrate, and transfer hydrogenation
systems, but all of them also present some specific drawbacks.

elements.content: Due to a huge market of pharmaceutics, flavoring, and perfumes, there is a large demand of unsaturated alcohols that is not fulfilled by natural resource. Therefore, selectivity is a key issue in the hydrogenation of aldehydes. Various metal NP catalysts have been reported for hydrogenation of aldehydes, and among them, selective hydrogenation of α, β-unsaturated aldehydes to unsaturated alcohols has attracted much attention. This process is challenging because the hydrogenation of the CC group to form saturated aldehydes is thermodynamically favorable. With oxide-supported NP catalysts, the NP edges in contact with the oxide surface provide such a selectivity but not the NP surfaces themselves. With their layer and channel specificities, MOF templates are ideally suited to enable the desired selectivity.
elements.clean_text:
Hydrogenation of Aldehydes
Due
to a huge market of pharmaceutics, flavoring, and perfumes, there
is a large demand of unsaturated alcohols that is not fulfilled by
natural resource. Therefore, selectivity
is a key issue in the hydrogenation of aldehydes. Various metal NP
catalysts have been reported for hydrogenation of aldehydes, and among
them, selective hydrogenation of α, β-unsaturated aldehydes
to unsaturated alcohols has attracted much attention. This process is challenging because the hydrogenation of the CC
group to form saturated aldehydes is thermodynamically favorable.
With oxide-supported NP catalysts, the NP edges in contact with the
oxide surface provide such a selectivity but not the NP surfaces themselves. With their layer and channel specificities,
MOF templates are ideally suited to enable the desired selectivity.

elements.content: Zhang and Hu et al. used a new approach in assembling MIL-101, Pt NPs, and FeP-CMPs (conjugated micro- and mesoporous polymers with iron­(III) porphyrin) to form MIL-101@Pt@FeP-CMP () and used this catalyst for the hydrogenation of cinnamaldehyde. With an outstanding TOF value of 1516.1 h–1, conversion of 97.6% and 97.3% selectivity of cinnamyl alcohol were obtained. The excellent catalytic performance benefits from the Fe sites that activate the CO bonds then improve the selectivity to cinnamyl alcohol during the hydrogenation reaction.

elements.content: Kuang et al. synthesized two Pt-based catalysts, Pt@ZIF-8 with a flexible structure and Pt@ZIF-71 with a rigid structure, for the hydrogenation of cinnamaldehyde. Compared to Pt@ZIF-8, Pt@ZIF-71 shows a higher selectivity for cinnamyl alcohol but a lower conversion for cinnamaldehyde. The results show that both the confinement effect and the flexible structure of MOFs have impact on the catalyst. PtNi 2.20 NWs@Ni/Fe 4 -MOF designed by Huang et al., through combination of porous nanowires (NWs) and MOFs, was used to the catalyze hydrogenation of cinnamaldehyde. 99.5% of Cinnamaldehyde conversion, 83.3% of cinnamyl alcohol selectivity, 77.6 h–1 of TOF value, and good recycle performance (no significant change after 5 runs) were achieved.

elements.content: Besides cinnamaldehyde, there are other important hydrogenation reactions of aldehydes. For example, 2-methoxy-4-methyl phenol, the hydrodeoxygenation product of vanillin, is a valuable phenol compound in pharmaceutical industries. El-Shall’s group reported Pd/PRGO/Ce-MOF that catalyzed the complete hydrogenation of vanillin (conversion: 100%) to 2-methoxy-4-methylphenol (selectivity: 100%). The reaction benefitted from the well-dispersed Pd NPs and the acidic active sites in PRGO (partially reduced graphene oxide). However, after 4 cycles of reuse, the selectivity of 2-methoxy-4-methylphenol decreased to 50% because residual reactants accumulated on the catalyst surface.

elements.content: Pd@NH 2 -UiO-66, synthesized by Zhang and Chen et al., displayed a high activity, selectivity, and stability (reused for 8 times) for hydrogenation of 2,3,5-trimethylbenzoquinone to 2,3,5-trimethylhydroquinone (an important vitamin E intermediate). Theoretical calculations suggested that the good catalytic properties of Pd@NH 2 -UiO-66 were due to the amine groups in MOFs facilitating the adsorption of 2,3,5-trimethylbenzoquinone and cooperating with the Pd NPs.

elements.content: The increased amount of CO2 in the atmosphere that mainly came from the combustion of fossil fuel is well-known to have a significant impact on climate changes. Consequently chemical processes involving catalyzed CO2 conversion to commodity products are essential in green chemistry. MOFs are able to encapsulate and store large amounts of CO2, but catalyzed CO2 transformation has long been a difficult challenge. Numerous results have recently been obtained to undermine the negative influence of CO2 through fixation and conversion of CO2. These reactions should be made more selective using MOF-based and MOF-derived catalysts, and ongoing efforts are encouraging. This section focuses on recent progress in the chemical reduction of CO2 using MOF nanocatalysts. Other approaches to CO2 conversion will be discussed later in this review.
elements.clean_text:
Hydrogenation
of CO2

The increased amount of CO2 in
the atmosphere that mainly
came from the combustion of fossil fuel is well-known to have a significant
impact on climate changes. Consequently chemical processes involving
catalyzed CO2 conversion to commodity products are essential
in green chemistry. MOFs are able to
encapsulate and store large amounts of CO2, but catalyzed
CO2 transformation has long been a difficult challenge.
Numerous results have recently been obtained to undermine the negative
influence of CO2 through fixation and conversion of CO2. These reactions should be made more selective using MOF-based and
MOF-derived catalysts, and ongoing efforts are encouraging. This section
focuses on recent progress in the chemical reduction of CO2 using MOF nanocatalysts. Other approaches to CO2 conversion
will be discussed later in this review.

elements.content: Hydrogenation of CO2 to CO, known as the reverse water–gas shift (RWGS) reaction, is a key chemical process reducing CO2 to generate CO for further conversions. Ni/ZIF-8-C, synthesized by the group of Li and Wang, shows high activity for selective hydrogenation of CO2 to CO (conversion: 43.81%, selectivity: 97.37%) in RWGS. Density functional theory (DFT) results indicated that the CO product resulted from the direct cleavage of a C–O bond of CO2 and the high selectivity was due to the weak adsorption of CO on the Ni/ZIF-8-C surface. A bimetallic catalyst for RWGS, Cu/Zn@C-submm, synthesized by Wang et al. using the catalyst Cu-BTC MOF (HKUST-1) led to a CO2 conversion of 5.0% and CO selectivity of 100%. Synergistic effects between Cu and Zn were shown by comparison with the monometallic Cu catalyst.

shown by comparison with the monometallic Cu catalyst.

elements.content: Xu et al. assembled the noble-metal-based nanomaterial Pt/Au@Pd@UIO-66 and used this catalyst for the hydrogenation of CO2 through RWGS. In this nanocomposite, bimetallic Au@Pd core–shell in the center was encapsulated by UiO-66, and Pt NPs was loaded onto the surface (). As the temperature increased, Pt/Au@Pd@UIO-66 was more effective for CO2 hydrogenation (conversion: 35.3% at 400 °C); however, the CO selectivity decreased with increasing temperature due to the increased amount of CH4.

elements.content: For selective hydrogenation of CO2 to methane, Xu et al. developed the catalyst Ni@UiO-66 that provided both excellent activity (conversion: 57.6%) and methane selectivity (100%) at a low reaction temperature (300 °C). Moreover, Ni@UiO-66 also displayed outstanding stability during 100 h. Another Ni-based catalyst, 20Ni@MIL-101­(DSM), synthesized by Lu et al., exhibited high activity (TOF: 1.6 × 10–3 s–1) at 300 °C for CO2 methanation. The good catalytic performance was due to the exposed Ni(111) facet of MIL-101 whose potential energy barrier is lower than that of Ni(200) facet for CO2 dissociation, which was confirmed by DFT.

elements.content: CO2 hydrogenation to methanol provides another valuable approach for CO2 fixation. In this reaction, the optimization of the Pd–ZnO interface appears crucial. MOFs, and in particular ZIF-8 based catalysts, were successful to increase selectivity as indicated by several reports. PZ8–400, a bimetallic alloyed Pd–Zn catalyst derived from Pd@ZIF-8 for selective CO2 hydrogenation to methanol, was synthesized by Hong et al. Active sites from PdZn alloy NPs formed after H2 reduction along with abundant oxygen defects on ZnO formed after the ZIF-8 decomposition contributed to the high methanol production of 0.65 g cat–1 h–1 (TOF: 972 h–1) at 270 °C. Hong’s group also reported highly selective hydrogenation of CO2 to methanol using the catalyst ZnO@ZIF-8-core–shell-Pd/ZnO. In this catalyst, the pores allowed optimized contact between Pd and ZnO and a selectivity superior to 67% was obtained at 290 °C.

elements.content: Lin and Wang’s group reported selective methanol synthesis upon CO2 hydrogenation using a MOF-derived catalyst of UiO-bpy type. The catalyst was synthesized via a solvothermal reaction between ZrCl4 and 2,2′-bipyridine-5,5′-dicarboxylate (BPYDC) in the presence of HCO2H forming BPYDC-briged Zr6(μ3-O)4(μ3-OH)4 SBUs. The interfaces between Cu/ZnO and Cu/ZrO2 formed at 250 °C played a decisive role.

elements.content: FeZnK-NC derived from ZIF-8 was synthesized by the group of Guo and Song for CO2 hydrogenation to hydrocarbons. Good activity (CO2 conversion: 34.6%), selectivity (54.1 C-mol %) for value-added hydrocarbons (C2–C4 2–, C5+), and remarkable stability (126 h) were achieved.

elements.content: The conversion of syngas (CO + H2) into hydrocarbons, known as Fischer–Tropsch synthesis (FTS), has received much attention toward the generation of synthetic fuel. This gas-phase reaction proceeds at high temperatures, and MOF-derived heterogeneous catalysts synthesized by pyrolysis of MOFs offer an expected selectivity. The core–shell catalyst Co@C-500, derived from Co-MOF by Zhang et al., demonstrated a high catalytic activity in FTS and achieved a CO conversion of 13.7% and C5+ selectivity of 75% (a benefit from the porous carbon shell structure) at 260 °C. Gascon et al. synthesized Co@SiO 2 that catalyzed FTS by hydrolysis of ZIF-67, furthering pyrolysis and calcination (). High activity (CO conversion: 15.8%) and C5+ selectivity (90.5%) were achieved because of the high loading, optimal size, and high reducibility of Co in Co@SiO 2 .

The CO concentration was reduced to 1 ppm, and the CH4 concentration was around 1% (selectivity: ∼100%) at 240 °C for 120 h, showing the good catalytic performance and stability of Ni/ZrO 2 .

elements.content: Transfer hydrogenation is an important procedure allowing the replacement of H2 by a hydrogen-rich compound for hydrogenation. Yamashita et al. developed a sulfonic acid-functionalized UiO-66 catalyst (), UiO-66-S 60 , for catalytic transfer hydrogenation (CTH) of levulinic acid and its esters to γ-valerolactone (GVL). Outstanding activity was observed (conversion: 98%, GVL yield: 80%) after 9 h at 140 °C, and the catalyst was successfully recycled 4 times, thanks to the Lewis-basic Zr clusters that catalyzed the CTH and the Brönsted-acidic −SO3H group that promoted the dealcoholization step.

This catalyst MIL-101­(Cr)-SO 3 H maintained its activity after five-time recycling with little loss.

elements.content: For reductive amination of aldehydes and ketones, Jagadeesh and Beller’s group synthesized Co-DABCO-TPA@C-800 () by reaction in DMF at 150 °C between cobalt nitrate and the linkers 1,4-diazabicyclo[2.2.2]­octane (DABCO) and terephthalic acid (TPA) followed by immobilization on commercial Vulcan XC 72R carbon powder and pyrolysis at 800 °C. This nanomaterial catalyzed the synthesis of more than 140 amines by reductive amination of aldehydes and ketones, N-alkylation to obtain secondary and tertiary amines, and synthesis of N-methylamines. The catalyst was reused 6 times without significant activity reduction.

elements.content: A catalyst based on MIL-101, Pd@MIL-101, was synthesized by the group of Shi and Cui and further modified by ethanol and 1-dodecanethiol (C12T) to form Pd-EtOH@MIL-101 and Pd-C12T@MIL-101. Concerning catalytic nitrite reduction, Pd-EtOH@MIL-101 showed much lower selectivity (0.31%) for the undesired ammonia byproduct than Pd-C12T@MIL-101 (10.18%). The difference was assigned to the interfacial electronic effects. The electron density of Pd increased upon EtOH modification that favored the reduction of nitrite activation energy, whereas the electron density of Pd decreased upon C12T modification.

Reduction of Other Inorganic
and Organic
Compounds
A catalyst based on MIL-101, Pd@MIL-101, was synthesized
by the group of Shi and Cui and further modified by ethanol and 1-dodecanethiol
(C12T) to form Pd-EtOH@MIL-101 and Pd-C12T@MIL-101. Concerning catalytic nitrite reduction, Pd-EtOH@MIL-101 showed much lower selectivity (0.31%) for
the undesired ammonia byproduct than Pd-C12T@MIL-101 (10.18%).
The difference was assigned to the interfacial electronic effects.
The electron density of Pd increased upon EtOH modification that favored
the reduction of nitrite activation energy, whereas the electron density
of Pd decreased upon C12T modification.

elements.content: Ru/Zn-MOF with subnanometer Ru NPs (0.8 nm) was prepared by Han et al. and applied to the selective hydrogenation of diphenyl sulfoxide. Ru/Zn-MOF achieved a conversion higher than 99%, 98% yield for diphenyl sulfide with a TOF value of 207.6 h–1 at 95 °C. This catalyst was more effective than other Ru-based catalysts with larger Ru NPs. The reusability was checked, and no change in activity was observed after 5 runs.

elements.content: Cu@C-550, derived from HKUST-1 (Co-MOF), was synthesized by Song et al. and used for the reduction of Cr­(VI) and pendimethalin. The reaction was complete within 15 and 4 min, respectively. In a previous work by the group of Liu and Yu, Pd@ZIF-67 showed a superior performance in the catalytic reduction of Cr­(VI) to Cr­(III) that was complete within 5 min, and Pd@ZIF-67 was recycled 10 times ().

elements.content: Phan’s group synthesized Co-ZIF-67, and this heterogeneous catalyst was utilized for the cascade redox condensation of 2-nitroaniline with benzylamine producing 2-phenylbenzimidazole in 97% yield after 1 d in DMSO at 140 °C without added oxidant or reducing agent. Benzimidazoles are largely utilized bioactive derivatives in medicinal and agrochemical areas, and therefore this simple heterogeneous process that does not require additives is of great value.

elements.content: Very few reports have concerned the synthesis of MOF-derived single-metal-atom catalysts. Li’s group reported selective hydrogenation of the nitrogen-containing ring of quinoline using UiO-66-NH2-derived single Ru sites as chemoselective catalysts. This amino group of the terephthalic acid MOF linkers acted as the Lewis base stabilizing RuCl3, which allowed confining the single Ru atom into the MOF pores. The MOF precursor nanomaterial was pyrolyzed at 700 °C, and the UiO-66 skeleton transferred in situ into ZrO2- and Ru-decorated porous carbon (). Related strategies were used by Li’s group to synthesize at high temperatures, via nitrogen ligand–metal stabilization, other single-atom porous catalysts from nanoparticles or bulk metal for reduction reactions.
elements.clean_text:
MOF-Derived
Single-Atom Metal Catalysts
for Reduction Reactions
Very few reports have concerned the
synthesis of MOF-derived single-metal-atom catalysts. Li’s group reported selective hydrogenation of the nitrogen-containing
ring of quinoline using UiO-66-NH2-derived single Ru sites
as chemoselective catalysts. This amino
group of the terephthalic acid MOF linkers acted as the Lewis base
stabilizing RuCl3, which allowed confining the single Ru
atom into the MOF pores. The MOF precursor nanomaterial was pyrolyzed
at 700 °C, and the UiO-66 skeleton transferred in situ into ZrO2- and Ru-decorated porous carbon (). Related strategies were used by Li’s
group to synthesize at high temperatures, via nitrogen ligand–metal
stabilization, other single-atom porous catalysts from nanoparticles
or bulk metal for reduction reactions.

elements.content: Selective oxidation of organic compounds is critical in chemistry and industry, especially because mechanisms are most often difficult to elucidate and therefore processes difficult to optimize. The development of catalysts for oxidation reactions has been pursued for a long time, and given the selectivity offered by MOF supports, huge efforts are now dedicated to develop selective and efficient MOF-based catalysts for oxidation reactions. Recent work has mostly focused on low-cost, highly efficient and environmentally friendly catalysts toward selective oxidation of unsaturated hydrocarbons, alcohols, and CO. The oxidation of hydrocarbons and olefin is usually catalyzed in the liquid phase by MOF-based catalysts, although a few MOF-derived catalysts have started to appear. On the other hand, more and more efficient MOF-derived catalysts resulting from calcination have recently appeared for gas-phase CO oxidation.
elements.clean_text:
Oxidation
Selective oxidation of
organic compounds is critical in chemistry and industry, especially
because mechanisms are most often difficult to elucidate and therefore
processes difficult to optimize. The development of catalysts for
oxidation reactions has been pursued for a long time, and given the
selectivity offered by MOF supports, huge efforts are now dedicated
to develop selective and efficient MOF-based catalysts for oxidation
reactions. Recent work has mostly focused on low-cost, highly efficient
and environmentally friendly catalysts toward selective oxidation
of unsaturated hydrocarbons, alcohols, and CO. The oxidation of hydrocarbons and olefin is usually catalyzed in
the liquid phase by MOF-based catalysts, although a few MOF-derived
catalysts have started to appear. On the other hand, more and more
efficient MOF-derived catalysts resulting from calcination have recently
appeared for gas-phase CO oxidation.

elements.content: Oxidation of olefins plays a key role to introduce and modify functional groups in organic synthesis, and therefore reports on olefin oxidation using MOF-based catalysts have involved various reaction types using t-butyl hydroperoxide (TBHP), H2O2, and O2 as oxidants. Early studies around 2010 examined inter alia polyoxometallate@MIL-101 for aerobic allylic oxidation and hydrogen peroxide for epoxidation. Recently, more sophisticated MOF catalysts have been designed. Using TBHP as oxidant, Fan et al. fabricated a multicomponent MOF nanomaterial Zn 1 Co 1 -ZIF for the oxidation of styrene. Good conversion (99%) and high selectivity for styrene oxide (70%) were achieved with a Zn 1 Co 1 -ZIF catalyst. Han et al. synthesized Au/Zn-MOF possessing subnanometer (0.8 nm) Au NPs. In the presence of O2, Au/Zn-MOF showed a high activity (conversion: 82%) and selectivity of 2-cyclohexene-1-one (98%) toward the oxidation of cyclohexene at 100 °C after 8h. It was demonstrated that the very small NP size was crucial to improve the performance of similar catalysts with larger AuNPs. CuLuMOF was synthesized by Spodine’s group and tested as olefin oxidation catalyst. A conversion of 88% was obtained for styrene oxidation using TBHP, and the main product was phenylacetaldehyde (selectivity: 43%). The main oxidation product for cyclohexane oxidation was cyclohexanone, and a higher activity (conversion: 95%, selectivity: 60%) was achieved upon changing the oxidant to O2.

elements.content: Tsung and Nguyen’s group astutely designed a bifunctional catalyst Pd@UiO-66-(sal)­Mo, and Pd NPs were encapsulated therein. MoVI(sal) (sal = salicylaldimine) moieties were modified on the surface of UiO-66-NH2 MOF. In this way, the encapsulated Pd NPs were in contact with H2 and O2 to generate H2O2, while the large alkene substrates were prevented by the MOF to contact the encapsulated Pd NPs. The alkene was then oxidized by the (sal)Mo moieties using the freshly generated H2O2 (). In sum, Pd@UiO-66-(sal)­Mo has been successfully used to catalyze the tandem reaction for H2O2 generation and alkene selective oxidation by generated H2O2.

elements.content: Gao and Wang’s group synthesized Cu-CuFe 2 O 4 @HKUST-1 that provided high activity (conversion: 99%) and selectivity of fluorenone formation (99%) from fluorene oxidation under O2 at 60 °C. The good catalytic performance comes from the active sites on CuFe2O4 and the absorption of O2 by the MOF. Furthermore, the magnetic catalyst was easily separated and reused 10 times upon recycling.

elements.content: These examples show that suitable catalyst engineering provide excellent results in terms of selectivity and performance, in particular, when the multiple oxidation states of the metal catalyst of the MOF provides the possibility of oxo transfer from the substrate to the olefin product via readily generated metal-oxo intermediates. This area is thus promising.
