elements.content: The selective oxidation of alcohols to aldehyde, for example, oxidation of benzyl alcohol to benzaldehyde is a well-known organic reaction that is useful, in particular, for pharmaceutical industry. Numerous catalysts have been searched, and the trend consists in finding environmentally friendly ways, such as processing at rt in H2O, ideally using O2 from air as the oxidant.
elements.clean_text:
Oxidation of Alcohols
The selective
oxidation of alcohols to aldehyde, for example, oxidation of benzyl
alcohol to benzaldehyde is a well-known organic reaction that is useful,
in particular, for pharmaceutical industry. Numerous catalysts have been searched, and the trend consists in
finding environmentally friendly ways, such as processing at rt in
H2O, ideally using O2 from air as the oxidant.

elements.content: MDNM­(75Zn25Mn) synthesized from MOF-74 by Jhung et al. achieved a TOF value of 1570 min–1 (based on Mn) for oxidation of benzyl alcohol to benzaldehyde. A good recyclability was observed after 4 runs of reaction. Another Mn-catalyst, Mn 3 O 4 /MIL-101­(15), synthesized by Zhan and Lu et al., led to a conversion of 38.7% and a selectivity for benzaldehyde of 99% after 4 h in oxidation of benzyl alcohol with O2. The reaction was performed at 100 °C in toluene, without base. The catalyst was repeatedly recycled 10 times with an unchanged catalytic activity.

elements.content: CuPd-HKUST-1 synthesized by Muhler et al. showed a conversion of 71% and selectivity of benzaldehyde of 92% for the oxidation of benzyl alcohol with O2 at 423 K after 7 h in toluene. Liu’s group synthesized PdNP@MIL-101 in which the Pd NPs were encapsulated in the MOF by capillary impregnation. The catalyst PdNP@MIL-101 showed a high catalytic activity for oxidation of alcohol by O2 and aldimine condensation in one-pot reactions at 353 K in toluene with K2CO3. High yield of benzaldehyde (99.9%) and good stability (reuse over five cycles) was achieved after 4 h at 353 K upon using toluene as solvent and K2CO3 as base for the oxidation of benzyl alcohol. Then in the same pot after the oxidation of 4-methoxybenzylaldehyde, the condensation reaction between 4-methoxybenzyl alcohol and aniline further proceeded to give N-(4-methoxybenzylidene)­aniline with 99.0% conversion and 99.9% selectivity. Pt@NH 2 -MONFs synthesized by Huang et al., showed an excellent activity (conversion: near 100%) for oxidation of benzyl alcohol with K2CO3 after 1.5 h. This was one of the best results of Pt catalysts in the green oxidation of alcohol (solvent: H2O, oxidant: air, at rt), and the catalyst was reused over 10 times without significant catalytic activity loss. The good catalytic performance was related to the hierarchically porous structure and the interactions between the −NH2 groups and PtNPs.

elements.content: The Tai group showed that the activities of core–shell ZIF-8-encapsulated Au0–Ag0 NP and AuAg cluster catalysts toward benzylic alcohol oxidation (TOFs, 130 °C, 1 h, THF, 8 bar O2) were in the order of Ag@Au/ZIF-8 (28 h–1) > AuAg cluster/ZIF-8 (25 h–1) > Au@Ag/ZIF-8 (20 h–1) with aldehyde selectivities higher for both core–shell structures (53%) than for the cluster structure (35%).

elements.content: Zhan et al. used sacrificial Cu2O nanocrystals as a copper source for the fabrication of HKUST-1, Cu2O@HKUST-1, and Cu 2 O@HKUST-1@Au. Galvanic reaction between encapsulated CuI from Cu2O@HKUST-1 and AuIII from HAuCl4 located outside the MOF to form Cu 2 O@HKUST-1@Au resulted from the diffusion of Cu2O through the MOF micropores to the MOF surface. The nanomaterial Cu 2 O@HKUST-1@Au successfully catalyzed the fully selective oxidation of aromatic and aliphatic alcohols to aldehydes.

elements.content: Although most of the above-mentioned catalysts are until now based on functional MOFs, a few MOF-derived catalysts obtained after calcination have appeared. Pd/ZDC@mesoSiO 2 , derived from ZIF-8 developed by Wang et al. exhibited high catalytic activity (conversion: 99%, selectivity: 99%) for the oxidation of benzyl alcohol to benzaldehyde. The reaction was conducted at 100 °C for 6 h under base-free conditions (oxidant, air; solvent, toluene). An excellent recyclability was also obtained (reused 8 times), benefiting from the SiO2 shell that prevented Pd leaching. Another green catalyst, based on non-noble metal, yolk–shell Co@C–N, was assembled by Shen and Li’s group for the oxidation of alcohols. CoNPs were localized in the core of Co@C–N, covered by ZIF-67-derived nanosheets, and then enfolded by a ZIF-8-derived C–N shell (). Synergistic effects between the CoNPs and the covering nanosheets were demonstrated. The outer layer C–N shell prevents CoNP leaching and provides a space for alcohol oxidation. These properties endow Co@C–N an excellent catalytic activity and stability in oxidation of alcohols. More than 99% conversion was achieved in mild and environmentally friendly conditions (no base, water, or air as oxidant).

elements.content: An elegant strategy was recently reported by Li’s group for selective functional alcohol oxidation to aldehyde using a nanomaterial catalysts resulting from the pyrolysis of ZIF-8-encapsulated [Ru3(CO)12] cluster. The carbonyl-free Ru3 cluster was preserved and stabilized by the CN atoms resulting from pyrolysis, and full conversion and selectivity were obtained for 2-aminobenzaldehyde from 2-aminobenzyl alcohol. The catalyst TOF (4320 h–1) was 23 times higher than that of small Ru NPs (2.5 nm; TOF = 184 h–1).

by the CN atoms resulting from pyrolysis, and full conversion and

elements.content: For the oxidation of other alcohols, Liu et al. synthesized NENU-9HP-1/120 through a gel-like/freeze-drying strategy and used it for the oxidation of alcohols using THBP as oxidant. High activity (conversion: 97%) and good stability (after reuse 5 times, conversion: 90%) were achieved for the oxidation of 1-phenylethanol to acetophenone after 7 h in toluene at 100 °C, due to the accessible catalytic sites and the accelerated mass transfer favored by this hierarchically porous material. Zhu et al. synthesized Pd–Ce/Fe–MIL-101-NCH through a neocuproine functional Fe-MIL-101-NH2. With the use of O2 as oxidant, a yield of 55% was obtained in the oxidation of glycerol to 1,3-dihydroxyacetone (DHA) after 6 h in acetonitrile/water at 60 °C.

elements.content: Carbon monoxide (CO) is a well-known gas product of vehicle exhaust that is extremely toxic for human and animals and thus causes a serious environmental problem. Its solubility in water is very low, so its oxidation is highly needed for elimination. Pt nanomaterials are used in exhaust pipes for CO elimination at high temperatures, which does not solve CO elimination upon starting engines near ambient temperature nor full CO elimination at higher temperatures. Therefore, Haruta’s discovery in 1987 of oxide-supported Au NP catalyzed CO oxidation at temperatures far below 0 °C has been very promising. Cerium oxide (ceria) supports have shown considerable efficiency inter alia in CO oxidation. Another catalyst using noble metal and Ce, UiO-66@Au/CeO 2 , was synthesized by Puntes et al., through dispersion of core–shell Au/CeO2 to UIO-66. Full CO oxidation was achieved at 100 °C, and during the recycling test no loss of activity was observed for 37 h (a slight decrease was observed afterward).

elements.content: Noble metals different from gold such as palladium and ruthenium have recently been used in MOF-derived catalysts for CO oxidation. El-Shall et al. synthesized a Pd/Ce-MOF catalyst from Ce-BTC-MOF. Pd/Ce-MOF stores oxygen both on Ce­(III)/Ce­(IV) centers and by Pd in the form of palladium oxide, and these oxygen atoms are released during the CO oxidation. Full conversion of CO was achieved by 5 wt % Pd/Ce-MOF at 92 °C, and this catalyst was stable during 8 h of reaction.

Ce­(III)/Ce­(IV) centers and by Pd in the form of palladium oxide, and
these oxygen atoms are released during the CO oxidation. Full conversion
of CO was achieved by 5 wt % Pd/Ce-MOF at 92 °C,
and this catalyst was stable during 8 h of reaction.

elements.content: Other MOFs used for CO oxidation follow. The catalysts ZIFs­(Co/Zn)@M (M = Pd, Pt, or Au) were synthesized by Liu and Li’s group for CO oxidation. Catalytic results show that the nanomaterials ZIF-67­(Co)@M are better catalysts than ZIF-8­(Zn)@M, and ZIFs@Pd is better than ZIFs@Pt/Au. The best catalyst, ZIF-67­(Co)@Pd, achieved full CO conversion at 120 °C because of the electron transfer from ZIF to Pd NPs. A 3D catalyst, Ru/GA-HK, developed by Chen and Lu’s group from HKUST-1 (), achieved a simultaneous adsorption and oxidation of CO with a conversion of 19.8%.

for CO oxidation. Catalytic results
show that the nanomaterials ZIF-67­(Co)@M are better catalysts than
ZIF-8­(Zn)@M, and ZIFs@Pd is better than ZIFs@Pt/Au. The best catalyst, ZIF-67­(Co)@Pd, achieved full CO conversion at 120 °C
because of the electron transfer from ZIF to Pd NPs. A 3D catalyst, Ru/GA-HK, developed by Chen and Lu’s group from HKUST-1
(), achieved
a simultaneous adsorption and oxidation of CO with a conversion of
19.8%.

elements.content: Beside active oxide-supported noble-metal CO oxidation catalysts, ceria-supported Earth-abundant metals of the first raw of the transition metals have recently been successfully utilized as components of efficient MOF-derived CO oxidation catalysts. In particular Cu-containing MOF-derived catalysts have attracted much attention. Zhang first applied this type of material to MOFs upon introducing CeIII into the channels of Cu3(BCT)2 followed by pyrolysis. Li’s group recently used CuII@Ce-UiO-66 to synthesize a CuO/CeO2 catalyst that was very efficient and selective (>95% selectivity) for CO oxidation of CO in a H2-rich stream.

elements.content: Several catalysts combining a metal and Ce-MOF were developed by Jia and Zhang et al., who synthesized a series of Cu x Ce1–x O2 catalysts through Cu x Ce1–x -BTC MOFs for catalytic oxidation of CO. The highest activity (conversion, 85%; selectivity, 94% at 80 °C) was achieved by Cu 0.3 Ce 0.7 O 2 -650 with a calcination temperature of 650 °C. This demonstrated that a suitable calcination temperature led to the production of additional CuO clusters and oxygen vacancies, due to enhancement of the interaction between CuO and CeO2.

elements.content: Other Earth-abundant metal-based MOF-derived catalysts are also efficient, especially with manganese and cobalt. For instance, Wang et al. synthesized, under Ar by pyrolysis of ZIF-67 at 600 °C, a CO oxidation catalyst Co/C-600 that was active even at −30 °C, and the conversion of CO did not decrease after 1 day on stream under ambient conditions. Zhang et al. reported a Mn2O3 catalyst produced through calcination of Mn-MIL-100 for CO oxidation. The calcination temperature had an important effect on the catalyst activity, and the best activity was obtained for Mn 2 O 3 -700 (calcined at 700 °C) with a T98 (temperature for 98% conversion of CO) at 240 °C. Later, the same group synthesized a-Mn-250 by calcination of Mn-MIL-100 at 250 °C. a-Mn-250 showed a high catalytic activity toward CO oxidation (T98 at 300 °C). Interestingly, a-Mn-250 was transformed into Mn3O4 during the recycling test at low temperature, and the catalytic performance improved (T98 at 200 °C after 4 runs). When it was treated with CO at high temperature, the catalyst a-Mn-250 was transformed into Mn2O3, and the catalytic performance still improved (T 98 at 120 °C).

elements.content: H2S is another highly toxic gas that is produced in industry by natural gas processing and use, coal chemistry, and crude oil desulfurization. The Claus process is used in industry to remove H2S from natural gas, but 3 to 5% H2S is left thereafter. Therefore, removal of sulfur from fossil fuels by developing efficient catalysts for selective, irreversible oxidation of H2S to S [H2S + 1/2O2 → (1/n)­S n + H2O] has long become a priority. Over oxidation to SO2 must be avoided. NH 2 -MIL-53­(Fe) synthesized by Jiang et al. () displayed a high activity for selective oxidation of H2S to S (H2S conversion, selectivity, and yield of S were all around 100%) in the temperature range of 130∼160 °C. In the durability test, H2S conversion was kept as 100% for 17 h and then began to decrease.

elements.content: Oxidative desulfurization has long drawn attention from researchers in heterogeneous catalysis because it is of great industrial and environmental importance. MDC-C synthesized from ZIF-8@H2N-MIL-125 by Jhung et al. exhibited a high catalytic activity toward the oxidative desulfurization of dibenzothiophene with H2O2. A high conversion of 99.5%, reaction rate constant of 0.12 min–1, and a low activation energy of 19 KJ mol–1 were obtained after 2 h reaction at 80 °C. Furthermore, the catalyst was reused for 5 cycles.

elements.content: Zhang’s group synthesized Co-ZrO 2 /N–C from UiO-66-NH2, the metal precursor Co­(NO3)2, six H2O, and DABCO using the in situ impregnation method followed by pyrolysis at 800 °C for 3 h under an argon flow. Co-ZrO 2 /N–C catalyzed the oxidative functionalization with O2 of cyclic amines using 2-aminoarylmethanols to ring-fused quinazolinones. Typically a yield of 80% was obtained for the cross-coupling of 1,2,3,4-tetrahydroisoquinoline and 2-aminobenzyl alcohol at 120 °C.

elements.content: Zhao et al. synthesized the bimetallic catalysts Au–Pd/MOF from MOF-253­(Al) for the oxidative carbonylation of cyclohexanamine with CO. Under O2, high catalytic activity (TOF: 2573 h–1) and selectivity (over 98%) were achieved after 20 h at 90 °C in THF (with the optimized Au:Pd molar ratio = 26:74), thanks to the synergy between Au and Pd (). However, the stability of Au–Pd NPs became lower after five cycles of reaction.

elements.content: Jia et al. and Chen’s group reported the synthesis of Pt@M-Cr 2 O 3 by pyrolysis of MIL-101-Cr with impregnated Pt NPs for toluene combustion. The optimized catalyst was 0.82Pt@M-Cr2O3 exhibiting the T 10%, T 50%, and T 90% of toluene conversion at 120, 140, and 145 °C, respectively. On-stream test displayed that the catalytic activity did not remarkably decrease in the water vapor (concentrations: 10 and 20 vol %). Intermediates along the toluene oxidation pathway were suggested to be benzoate and maleic anhydride before decay to CO2 and H2O.

elements.content: MOF-based catalysts are becoming among the most used catalysts for bond formation reactions including C–C and C–N coupling, cyanosilylation, Diels–Alder reaction, etc. Bis-N-heterocyclic carbenes (NHC) being excellent chelating ligands in homogeneous catalysis, Pd-bis-NHC complexes have been introduced into MOFs for heterogeneous catalysis of various Mizoroki-Heck, Suzuki-Miyaura, and Sonogashira reactions, and this specific field has been reviewed by Han’s group. Carbon–hydrogen bond activation for the formation of carbon–carbon and carbon-heteroatom bonds has been a popular area in homogeneous catalysis, and extension to MOF-based heterogeneous catalyst has now been reviewed by the Garcia group. The reactions involved and analyzed are mostly the Mizoroki-Heck and Suzuki-Miyaura coupling reactions, C–H arylation of benzoxazole, indole, N-methylindole and naphthalene, coupling of coumarin with N,N-dimethylaniline, of N-benzoyl-8-amino-quinoline and morpholine, of quinoxalin-2­(1H)-one or ethyl phenyl ketone with morpholine, C–H amination of tetrahydrofuran or cyclohenene, borylation of arenes, and halogenation of cyclohexane and heterocycles. Improved performances of MOF-based catalysts logically result from their porosity, large surface area, site isolation, and immobilization.
elements.clean_text:
C–C Bond-Forming Reaction
MOF-based catalysts are becoming among the most used catalysts for
bond formation reactions including C–C and C–N coupling,
cyanosilylation, Diels–Alder reaction, etc. Bis-N-heterocyclic carbenes (NHC) being
excellent chelating ligands in homogeneous catalysis, Pd-bis-NHC complexes
have been introduced into MOFs for heterogeneous catalysis of various
Mizoroki-Heck, Suzuki-Miyaura, and Sonogashira reactions, and this
specific field has been reviewed by Han’s group. Carbon–hydrogen bond activation for
the formation of carbon–carbon and carbon-heteroatom bonds
has been a popular area in homogeneous catalysis, and extension to
MOF-based heterogeneous catalyst has now been reviewed by the Garcia
group. The reactions involved and analyzed
are mostly the Mizoroki-Heck and Suzuki-Miyaura coupling reactions,
C–H arylation of benzoxazole, indole, N-methylindole
and naphthalene, coupling of coumarin with N,N-dimethylaniline, of N-benzoyl-8-amino-quinoline
and morpholine, of quinoxalin-2­(1H)-one or ethyl phenyl ketone with
morpholine, C–H amination of tetrahydrofuran or cyclohenene,
borylation of arenes, and halogenation of cyclohexane and heterocycles.
Improved performances of MOF-based catalysts logically result from
their porosity, large surface area, site isolation, and immobilization.

elements.content: The Mizoroki-Heck reaction, developed by Mizoroki and Heck, couples a vinyl, aryl, or benzyl halide with an olefin over catalysis by Pd0 (). It is the best-known C–C coupling reaction because of its simplicity since it does not necessitate the preliminary synthesis of an intermediate organoelement compound. In addition it tolerates a large number of functional groups and is thus of considerable interest in organic synthesis. Molecular Pd catalysts in which the ligands are strongly coordinated such as Pd­(acac) with or without PPh3 are most used, but Pd NPs [formed from Pd­(acac)] are not very efficient due to aggregation unless they are strongly stabilized against agglomeration. Therefore, MOF-templated and MOF-derived catalysts are of great interest in the stabilization of Pd NPs or nanomaterials under reaction conditions requiring heating around 100 °C.
elements.clean_text:
Mizoroki-Heck Reaction
The Mizoroki-Heck
reaction, developed by Mizoroki and
Heck, couples a vinyl, aryl, or benzyl
halide with an olefin over catalysis by Pd0 (). It is the best-known C–C
coupling reaction because of its simplicity since it does not necessitate
the preliminary synthesis of an intermediate organoelement compound.
In addition it tolerates a large number of functional groups and is
thus of considerable interest in organic synthesis. Molecular Pd catalysts in which the ligands are strongly
coordinated such as Pd­(acac) with or without PPh3 are most
used, but Pd NPs [formed from Pd­(acac)] are not very efficient due
to aggregation unless they are strongly stabilized against agglomeration. Therefore, MOF-templated and MOF-derived catalysts are of great
interest in the stabilization of Pd NPs or nanomaterials under reaction
conditions requiring heating around 100 °C.

7

elements.content: The Shaikh group reported the conversion of hexagonal ZIF-8 microcrystals to rod- and flower-shaped PdNPs@ZIF-8 with the controlled addition of formic acid. This ZIF-8-supported PdNPs catalyzed Heck coupling of aryl halides with substituted styrenes in excellent yields with high selectivities. A Pd-based microporous organic nanotube framework-supported catalyst, Pd@NH 2 -MONFs, synthesized by Huang’s group, provided yields between 94% and 99% for the Heck reactions of various aryl iodides and methyl acrylate at 90 °C, and the catalyst was recycled over 6 times without significant catalytic activity decrease. Dou and Li’s group synthesized several Pd-based MOF-derived catalysts (Pd@Co 3 O 4 , Pd@Co 3 O 4 /C and Pd@Co/CNT) through pyrolysis of Pd@ZIF-67 to catalyze the Heck reaction (). These catalysts all achieved high yields (94 to 99%) for the Heck reaction between styrene and iodobenzene at 120 °C for 6 h benefiting from the many active Pd sites in hierarchical pores after pyrolysis. Pd@Co/CNT was reused 5 times without activity loss.

elements.content: Dong’s group reported a UiO-67-type MOF that contained a palladium N-heterocyclic bis-carbene dicarboxylate ligand under solvothermal conditions, and this catalyst was active for Heck coupling and intermolecular benzyne–benzyne-alkene coupling insertion reactions. Operando X-ray absorption spectroscopy (XAS), X-ray powder diffraction, TEM, and 1H NMR have been combined by the Zou and Martin-Matute group to search the mechanism of the Heck reaction with Pd@MOF catalysts. Interestingly, the results show that PdII complexes dominate at the reaction beginning and then progressively form Pd0 nanoclusters containing on average 13 to 20 Pd atoms in later turnovers. The anions Cl– that are produced during the reaction coordinate to the cluster surface causing poisoning. Such understanding allowed increasing the catalyst lifetime.

Dong’s group

palladium N-heterocyclic bis-carbene dicarboxylate

Interestingly, the results show that PdII complexes dominate

The anions Cl– that are produced during the reaction
coordinate to the cluster surface causing poisoning. Such understanding
allowed increasing the catalyst lifetime.

elements.content: The Suzuki-Miyaura reaction is the most popular cross C–C coupling reaction between a halide compound and an organo-element (here organoboron) derivative because it proceeds under very mild conditions. It couples a vinyl or aryl borane, via boronate, with a vinyl or aryl halide. As in most coupling reactions, a Pd catalyst and base are used, and Pd NP catalysts in quantities as small as ppm or subppm Pd have been shown to be sufficient for quantitative homogeneous reactions. A general pathway for the Suzuki reaction is shown below (): R 1  X + R 2  B Y 2 + N R 3 → catalyst R 1  R 2 + N R 3 H + X − ⁣ ( X = halogen )

elements.content: The interest of MOFs in these catalysts is that they afford well-defined recyclable heterogeneous catalysts, although they are required in considerably larger amounts than in homogeneous catalysis. In addition, the robustness of MOF-based or MOF-derived catalysts allows addressing the challenging use of Ni-based catalysts instead of Pd-based catalysts.
elements.clean_text:
The interest of MOFs
in these catalysts is that they afford well-defined recyclable heterogeneous
catalysts, although they are required in considerably larger amounts
than in homogeneous catalysis. In addition, the robustness of MOF-based
or MOF-derived catalysts allows addressing the challenging use of
Ni-based catalysts instead of Pd-based catalysts.

elements.content: Madrahimov developed Ni-immobilized catalysts by combining a modified MOF (UiO-66­(L3)), Ni­(COD)2, and PPh3 (). A yield of 96% and good cyclic performance (reusable over 7 times) were achieved by this Ni-immobilized MOF for a Suzuki-Miyaura reaction between bromobenzene and phenylboronic acid, by using K2CO3 as the base and CH3CN as the solvent at 65 °C for 12 h with 3 mol % Ni. This catalyst is in fact a classic [Ni0(bpy)­(L)­(PPh3)] that is heterogenized by linking the MOF to the bipy ligand thanks to a “click” reaction.

elements.content: For the same reaction between bromobenzene and phenylboronic acid, Bian et al. reported a core–shell structured magnetic catalyst Fe 3 O 4 @PDA-Pd@[Cu 3 (btc) 2 ]. The best yield of 97% was obtained at 75 °C after 30 min, by using K2CO3 as the base and EtOH/H2O (v/v = 1:1) as the solvent. The catalyst was reused over 8 times without decrease upon magnetic recovery. The excellent performance was attributed to the strong synergistic effect between Fe3O4@PDA-Pd and [Cu3(btc)2]. A magnetic Fe3O4–Pd catalyst, Fe 3 O 4 @La-MOF-Schiff base-Pd, synthesized by Sun and Dragutan et al., has been used to catalyze the Suzuki-Miyaura reactions of various aryl halides with arylboronic acids. Yields of above 99% have been attained for various aryl iodides and bromides at 80 °C after 30 min, by using K2CO3 as the base and ethanol as the solvent. The catalyst was recycled over 12 times without significant yield decrease. The high activity and stability of the catalyst were assigned to the synergistic effect between Pd and the La nodes, and the stability of the Pd moieties was enhanced by the La ions.

elements.content: The Stanley and Huang group synthesized a series of isoreticular mixed-linker MOFs to examine the stereoelectronic substituent effects on the Suzuki-Miyaura reaction. The effect of linker substitution of MOF templates on the catalytic activity of encapsulated Pd NPs has been shown to be crucial, and remarkably MOF-Pd NPs and MOF-PdII catalysts generated similar active centers.

elements.content:
A3 coupling is a three-component coupling reaction that involves an alkyne, an aldehyde, and an amine, and the reaction will produce propargylamine derivatives in the presence of a catalyst ().

Ag-NHC-MOF, developed by Verpoort et al., achieved a yield of 97% at rt after 1h for the A3-coupling reaction between paraformaldehyde, phenylacetylene and diisopropylamine in CH2Cl2. The catalyst was recycled 4 times and further applied in the A3-coupling with other substrates. Core–shell AgNP@IRMOF-3 with average Ag NP size of 5.2 nm and IRMOF-3 of 91.5 nm was synthesized in only 5 min and was shown to be highly active for A3-coupling of amine, aldehyde, and acetylene; the catalyst was recycled 8 times without decrease of activity.

aldehyde, and acetylene; the catalyst was recycled 8 times without
decrease of activity.

elements.content: Zhang et al. synthesized a series of Au/MOF-199 by microwave irradiation in 2 min, and high TOFs value over 700 h–1 were achieved for the A3-coupling of formaldehyde, phenylacetylene, and piperidine in 1,4-dioxane at 120 °C after 5 min. This catalyst was reused five times without significant loss of activity. Yang and Jiang reported the comparison between the catalytic performance of Auδ+ and Au0NP in A3-coupling stabilized by MIL-101-NH2 via postsynthetic modification, and they found that the activity of the Auδ+ catalyst was 11-fold higher than that of AuNP.

elements.content: Liu and Tai’s group reported a postsynthetic modification method in the synthesis of salicylaldehyde-functionalized MOF via nucleophilic addition of salicylaldehyde to the amino group of NH2-MIL-53­(Al). Encapsulation of AuIII into this MOF and then reduction of AuIII to encapsulated AuNP allowed catalysis of A3-coupling of various aromatic or aliphatic aldehydes, aromatic alkynes, and piperidine, and the catalyst was recycled four times. Au@MIL-101-ED-SA and Au@MIL-101 were synthesized by the same group for A3-coupling catalysis, and Au@MIL-101-ED-SA that contained Au3+/Au0 = 0.9 showed higher catalytic performance than Au@MIL-101 that was synthesized using the impregnation method.

elements.content: The Knoevenagel condensation, a powerful reaction in organic synthesis, is a nucleophilic addition of an active methylene compound (with electron withdrawing functional groups Z) with a carbonyl derivative in the presence of a base ().
elements.clean_text:
Knoevenagel Condensation
The Knoevenagel
condensation, a powerful reaction in organic synthesis, is a nucleophilic
addition of an active methylene compound (with electron withdrawing
functional groups Z) with a carbonyl derivative in the presence of
a base ().


10

elements.content: The use or alkali metal hydroxides and organic bases pose separation and waste problems, however. Therefore, heterogeneous catalysts would, as for other reactions, present ecological advantages to avoid these drawbacks. In particular, MOFs are ideal candidates thanks to their structural flexibility adaptable to specific problems of the reaction. For instance, ZIF MOFs are excellent catalysts because the framework Lewis acid Zn sites activate the carbonyl oxygen atom of the aldehyde or ketone while the active methylene group is deprotonated by the frame imidazole ligand, as shown by Verpoort’s group. Thus, the MOF alone can be the catalyst even in the absence of other NPs, but in many MOF catalysts magnetic iron oxide or Pd or other transition metal NPs are introduced in order to facilitate the reaction and/or to allow cascade reactions. Han’s group synthesized a bifunctional MOF, Yb-BDC-NH 2 , for tandem deacetalization of benzaldehyde dimethyl acetal to benzaldehyde and then Knoevenagel condensation of the generated benzaldehyde with malononitrile at 50 °C for 24 h. The yield of the final product, benzylidenemalononitrile, reached 97% thanks to the strong Lewis acidity of the Yb MOF site and small ionic radius. However, the activity of Yb-BDC-NH 2 decreased in the recycle experiment. Ho and Wang reported the synthesis of magnetic hierarchically porous MOF composites through an interfacial nanoassembly/emulsion polymerization method with ZIF-8, UiO-66, Cr-MIL-101, HKUST-1, and Fe3O4 NPs. Excellent mechanical stability and higher conversion rate for the Knoevenagel reaction were obtained compared to the MOF itself in the case of ZIF-8. In order to develop supports for flow-based applications, Maya’s group designed NP-directed MOF/porous organic polymer monolithic materials. In two steps, these authors prepared macroporous polymer monoliths in which the surface of the pores is protected by a ZIF-8 coating. This ZIF-8-coated polymer monolithic was implemented as a microreactor for the catalysis of the Knoevenagel reaction. Zhang and Zhao synthesized 3.1% RuNP/UiO-66 that catalyzed the Knoevenagen reaction. This was attributed to the ZnO2 Lewis acid–base pair of the MOF frame. RuNP/UiO-66 also catalyzed the reduction of nitroarene to amines. The Yao and Dong groups grafted poly­[2-(diethylamino)­ethyl methacrylate] (PDEAEMA) chains onto UiO-66 via a postsynthetic approach forming PDEAEMA-g-UiO-66 NMOF (termed as MOF-3, ). Pd NP-loaded Pd@MOF-3 fabricated via solution impregnation showed high activity in interfacial catalysis of a Knoevenagel condensation-hydrogenation cascade. Huang’s group reported that PdNPs supported on a N-doped porous carbon Cz-MOF-253 resulting from pyrolysis of bipyridyl MOF-253 showed catalyst activity for the Knoevenagel reaction that outperformed other N-containing derived carbons. Pd/Cz–MOF-253–800 was also an excellent catalyst of the Knoevenagel condensation-hydrogenation cascade.

elements.content: The cyanosilylation reaction is an addition reaction between an unsaturated compound and a compound that possesses cyano and silyl groups. Cyanosilylation of carbonyl derivatives allows a practical synthesis of cyanohydrins that are important intermediates in organic synthesis. The Mirkhani group treated MIL-101 with Fe3O4, and this composite magnetically recoverable catalyst was shown to be active via its CrIII nodes in both oxidation and cyanosilylation reactions.
elements.clean_text:
Cyanosilylation
The cyanosilylation
reaction is an addition reaction between an unsaturated compound and
a compound that possesses cyano and silyl groups. Cyanosilylation
of carbonyl derivatives allows a practical synthesis of cyanohydrins
that are important intermediates in organic synthesis. The Mirkhani group treated MIL-101 with Fe3O4, and this composite magnetically recoverable
catalyst was shown to be active via its CrIII nodes in
both oxidation and cyanosilylation reactions.

elements.content: Reactions of CO2 forming valuable chemicals are actively researched because C1 source is cheap and inexhaustible. Cyclisation of propargyl alcohol with CO2 has attracted attention, especially since the alkylidene carbonate heterocycles produced find important applications in pharmaceutical industry and polymers. Zhao’s group synthesized a small Cu nanocluster-based MOF {(NH2C2H6)0.75[Cu4I4·L3·In0.75]·DMF·H2O} with L = 5-aminonicotinic acid that catalyzed the cyclization of various propargyl alcohols with CO2 in the absence of solvent (TON = 14400). Synergistic effect between CuI and InIII were responsible for this catalytic CO2 conversion.
elements.clean_text:
Cycloaddition of CO2

Reactions
of CO2 forming valuable chemicals are actively researched
because C1 source is cheap and inexhaustible. Cyclisation of propargyl
alcohol with CO2 has attracted attention, especially since
the alkylidene carbonate heterocycles produced find important applications
in pharmaceutical industry and polymers. Zhao’s group synthesized a small Cu nanocluster-based MOF
{(NH2C2H6)0.75[Cu4I4·L3·In0.75]·DMF·H2O} with L = 5-aminonicotinic acid that catalyzed the cyclization
of various propargyl alcohols with CO2 in the absence of
solvent (TON = 14400). Synergistic effect between CuI and
InIII were responsible for this catalytic CO2 conversion.

elements.content: The cycloaddition of CO2 with epoxides yields cyclic carbonates that are useful for fine chemicals and plastics. Jiang’s group reported N-doped porous carbon-encapsulated ZnO NPs (), ZnO@NPC-Ox-700, that catalyzed CO2 cycloaddition with epoxides at 60 °C for 2 d, under 0.1 MPa CO2 in the presence of TBAB, with 100% selectivity and 98% conversion. This catalyst was recycled 10 times. In order to prepare this catalyst, the authors pyrolized ZIF-8 at 700 °C (optimized temperature for catalysis), and the resulting material was oxidized with sodium hypochlorite, which resulted in the formation of ZnO@NPC-Ox-700. This material contained phenol, carboxylic acid, and lactone groups on the porous carbon surface providing synergy for the catalytic activation. Comparatively, ZIF-8 and TBAB only led to 16% conversion. Since TBAB itself gave 14% conversion, this shows the lack of activity of ZIF-8, which is taken into account by the lack of active sites, the small ZIF-8 aperture (3.4 A), and low diffusion rates. ZnO in this catalyst is more active than conventional ZnO encapsulated in porous carbon due to the synergies with the functional groups. In comparison, reactions catalyzed by other materials including porous carbons, ZIFs, and MOFs need higher temperature and CO2 pressure than ZnO@NPC-Ox-700.

elements.content: Zhang’s group showed that SnS2 nanosheets were essential as UiO-66 support to inhibit the blockage of the active metal centers by organic linkers for cycloaddition of CO2 with propylene oxide under solvent-free conditions. Indeed this catalyst was 11 times more active than the pure UiO-66 catalyst.

elements.content: The group of Sheng and Zhu et al. synthesized the atomically precise nanocluster [Au12Ag32(SR)30]4–, [Zn2+]2, and then reaction of this nanocluster with the ZIF-8 precursor 2-methylimidazole (2-MeIM) in methanol yielded Au 12 Ag 32 (SR) 30 @ZIF-8 after 1 day at rt. This nanomaterial catalyzed the reaction of CO2 addition with phenylacetylene yielding phenylpropiolate. In the presence of a base (Cs2CO3 or K2CO3), a TON value of 18 000 was obtained after 1 d at 50 °C in DMSO, which exceeded the performance of most reported catalysts, and this catalyst was reused 5 times.

elements.content: Biomass is an important source of primary energy, and its most abundant form is lignocellulose. Lignin, a natural amorphous polymer and one of the main lignocellulosic constituents, is the only large renewable feedstock containing aromatics, but it has not yet been exploited toward fine chemicals. Its depolymerization was conducted through cleavage of the β-O-4 linkages that comprised nearly half of the lignin linkages. Such cleavages were best conducted by transfer hydrogenation from the numerous alcohol moieties in lignin.
elements.clean_text:
Biomass
and Biodiesel
Biomass is
an important source of primary energy, and its most abundant form
is lignocellulose. Lignin, a natural amorphous polymer and one of
the main lignocellulosic constituents, is the only large renewable
feedstock containing aromatics, but it has not yet been exploited
toward fine chemicals. Its depolymerization
was conducted through cleavage of the β-O-4 linkages that comprised
nearly half of the lignin linkages. Such cleavages were best conducted
by transfer hydrogenation from the numerous alcohol moieties in lignin.

elements.content: Biodiesel is a green fuel that involves long-chain fatty acid methyl esters from the transesterification with methanol of triglycerides, and its development is highly desirable in the context of the energy crisis. Xie and Wan synthesized a magnetic core–shell catalyst Fe 3 O 4 @HKUST-1-ABILs using the layer-by-layer assembly method followed by encapsulation of basic ionic liquids. This green catalyst was efficient for the transesterification of soybean oil in methanol to biodiesel. This conversion to biodiesel reached 92.3% within 3 h, and the catalyst that was easily separated using an external magnetic field was recycled 5 times.

in methanol to biodiesel. This conversion

separated using an external magnetic field was recycled 5 times.

elements.content: Given the drawback of standard catalysts including Pd/C and the excellent synergistic properties of bimetallic NPs and porous MOF, Cai’s group synthesized a bimetallic NP-MOF catalyst Pd 1 Ni 4 /MIL-100­(Fe), prepared by the impregnation-reduction method, for β-O-4 cleavage of lignin. Upon using H2O as a solvent, high conversion (100%) and good yield (95%) were obtained under argon after 6 h at 130 °C for the conversion of 2-phenoxy-1-phenethanol to acetophenone and phenol through intramolecular hydrogen transfer and C–O bond cleavage, and the catalyst was stable during 5-time recycling. The good catalytic performance was ascribed to the synergistic effect between the bimetallic NPs and the MOF with Lewis-acid activity.

elements.content: Recently MOFs have been extensively studied as components of electrode materials for electrocatalysis of the oxygen reduction reaction (ORR), oxygen evolution reaction (OER), hydrogen evolution reaction (HER), reduction of carbon dioxide (CO2), and for Li–air batteries. The field of MOF-based nanomaterials for electrocatalysis has been reviewed by Zou’s group in 2016 and Zhang’s group in 2018, and designed strategies for energy conversion have been reviewed by Qiao’s group in 2017. Traditionally Pt has proven to be the ideal electrocatalytic metal, but its high price and scarcity on Earth has promoted research of other nanomaterials. The challenges are to overcome kinetic problems related to multielectron transfer and mass transport. Earth-abundant catalysts are limited by high overpotentials, but new strategies involve the design of bi- or trimetallic core–shell or alloy nanostructures eventually incorporating B, N, or P atoms in these structures or in carbon frameworks. MOF-derived nanocomposites have limited electron transport capability because of poor graphitic degree upon pyrolysis, but metal-based NPs encapsulated in porous carbon are promising high-stability materials. The pyrolysis of MOFs containing atomically dispersed metal nanoclusters between organic linkers is thus a major method to produce nanostructured M–N–C catalysts of suitable size with uniformly distributed active sites and excellent porosity. During the pyrolysis, the high annealing temperature provides enough Gibb’s free energy for diffusion of ions of different metals to form alloys. At the same time, these metal species catalyze the formation of carbon material from the organic MOF ligands. The metal NPs made in this way are used as efficient electrocatalysts only when they are supported on carbon materials with good conductivity.
elements.clean_text:
Electrocatalysis
Recently MOFs have been
extensively studied as components of electrode
materials for electrocatalysis of the oxygen reduction reaction (ORR),
oxygen evolution reaction (OER), hydrogen evolution reaction (HER),
reduction of carbon dioxide (CO2), and for Li–air
batteries. The field of MOF-based nanomaterials
for electrocatalysis has been reviewed by Zou’s group in 2016
and Zhang’s group in 2018, and designed strategies for energy
conversion have been reviewed by Qiao’s group in 2017. Traditionally Pt has proven to be the ideal electrocatalytic metal,
but its high price and scarcity on Earth has promoted research of
other nanomaterials. The challenges are to overcome kinetic problems
related to multielectron transfer and mass transport. Earth-abundant
catalysts are limited by high overpotentials, but new strategies involve
the design of bi- or trimetallic core–shell or alloy nanostructures
eventually incorporating B, N, or P atoms in these structures or in
carbon frameworks. MOF-derived nanocomposites have limited electron
transport capability because of poor graphitic degree upon pyrolysis,
but metal-based NPs encapsulated in porous carbon are promising high-stability
materials. The pyrolysis of MOFs containing
atomically dispersed metal nanoclusters between organic linkers is
thus a major method to produce nanostructured M–N–C
catalysts of suitable size with uniformly distributed active sites
and excellent porosity. During the pyrolysis, the high annealing temperature
provides enough Gibb’s free energy for diffusion of ions of
different metals to form alloys. At the same time, these metal species
catalyze the formation of carbon material from the organic MOF ligands.
The metal NPs made in this way are used as efficient electrocatalysts
only when they are supported on carbon materials with good conductivity.

elements.content: Besides, optimization of the MOF porosity by “iso-reticular expansion” improves mass transport. Metal open sites of MOF such as Fe, Co, and Ni have the useful function of Lewis-acid catalysts often operating in synergy with the guest metal NPs. Several other strategies are therefore developed, such as calcination of MOF-MNP at controlled temperatures yielding MOF-derived carbon-based nanocatalysts and nanocatalyst supports optimizing synergies between inter alia C, N, P, metals, and metal oxides. In this method, the MNP@MOF structure is a sacrified precursor of nanoporous heteroatom-doped carbon-based nanomaterials with high BET surface area and large pore volumes most often performing very efficiently as heterogeneous catalysts, in particular for these electrocatalyzed reactions.
elements.clean_text:
Besides, optimization of the MOF porosity
by “iso-reticular
expansion” improves mass transport. Metal open sites of MOF
such as Fe, Co, and Ni have the useful function of Lewis-acid catalysts
often operating in synergy with the guest metal NPs. Several other
strategies are therefore developed, such as calcination of MOF-MNP
at controlled temperatures yielding MOF-derived carbon-based nanocatalysts
and nanocatalyst supports optimizing synergies between inter alia
C, N, P, metals, and metal oxides. In this method, the MNP@MOF structure
is a sacrified precursor of nanoporous heteroatom-doped carbon-based
nanomaterials with high BET surface area and large pore volumes most
often performing very efficiently as heterogeneous catalysts, in particular
for these electrocatalyzed reactions.

elements.content:
In addition, there is increasing evidence that MOFs modified with guest materials show better electrocatalytic performance than without organic guest due to modified electronic structure.

In sum, the qualities that are researched for new electrocatalysts obtained by pyrolysis of mono- or polymetallic NP-MOF generally include high surface area, porous carbon with retained morphology, a high graphitization degree, hierarchical porosity, and N and/or P dopant moieties. Another promising strategy is that of using single-site catalysts, a quite new, very active, and promising field. In order to describe the performances of electrocatalysts, several parameters are normally used including the onset potential (E onset), overpotential at a current density (ηj), Tafel slope (TS), and turnover frequency (TOF).

elements.content: The production of hydrogen from nonfossil-fuel sources is the key to environmentally safe energy of the close future. Therefore, hydrogen evolution reactions (HER) with MOF-based and MOF-derived catalysts include chemical hydrogen sources such as inorganic hydrides that are the subject of , electrocatalytic water splitting described in this section, and photocatalytic water splitting treated in . A year ago Zhu, Zou, and Xu reported a review of MOF-based catalysts for HER with special emphasis on postsynthetic MOF modifications for highly efficient HER. In this section, after briefly recalling the fundamental principles, focus will be oriented toward the very new HER electrocatalysts ().

Hydrogen Evolution Reaction (HER)
The production of
hydrogen from nonfossil-fuel sources is the key
to environmentally safe energy of the close future. Therefore, hydrogen
evolution reactions (HER) with MOF-based and MOF-derived catalysts
include chemical hydrogen sources such as inorganic hydrides that
are the subject of , electrocatalytic water splitting described in this section,
and photocatalytic water splitting treated in . A year ago Zhu, Zou, and Xu reported a
review of MOF-based catalysts for HER with special emphasis on postsynthetic
MOF modifications for highly efficient HER. In this section, after briefly recalling the fundamental principles,
focus will be oriented toward the very new HER electrocatalysts ().

elements.content:
The electrochemical HER from water is the reduction of protons or water by two electrons: 2 H + + 2 e − → H 2

This proton reduction reaction involves two steps: the proton reduction by one electron to the adsorbed hydrogen atom, the Volmer step, followed by the second step that can proceed according to two distinct mechanisms. The reduction of the adsorbed hydrogen atom by an electron and a proton is the Heyrovski mechanism, whereas the reductive elimination of two adsorbed hydrogen atoms is the Tafel mechanism. H + + e − → H * ⁣ Volmer step H * + H + + e − → H 2 ⁣ Heyrovski mechanism 2 H * → H 2 ⁣ Tafel mechanism

elements.content: The activation energy strongly depends on the adsorption energy of the adsorbed hydrogen atom that should be neither too weak nor too strong. The optimized catalyst corresponds to a nil adsorption free energy (volcano-type) and minimal overpotential in both acidic and basic conditions. DFT calculations are useful to optimize this H adsorption energy on catalyst surfaces. Catalysts possessing oxo atoms should be favorable because oxo atoms facilitate the mobility of protons. Therefore MOFs have been combined with polyoxometallates (POMs) in POMOF catalysts or precursors leading to Mo oxide nanomaterials. In POMOFs, the optimized countercation is a hydrated Li cation that transports the largest amount of water molecules. Other materials presenting good electrocatalytic properties were cobalt and bimetallic Fe–Co Prussian Blue and MOFs phosphides eventually containing other atoms (B, C, N, and S) for synergistic catalysis. Altogether a large number of Earth-abundant metal-based catalysts (in particular with Mo and W) such as chalcogenides, phosphides, carbides, and nitrides, metal-free carbon-based materials, and their hybrids with a variety of structures morphologies have been reported for HER electrocatalysis, but considerable efforts are needed to obtain nanomaterials able to compete with Pt-based electrocatalysts. Some bimetallic and trimetallic catalysts combining a first-raw transition metal and a noble metal have also been introduced, such as IrCo-, NiRu-, NiMo-, CoW-, and PtCoFe-catalysts with excellent performances.

(in particular with Mo and W) such as chalcogenides, phosphides, carbides,
and nitrides, metal-free carbon-based materials, and their hybrids

elements.content: In spite of the outstanding activity of Pt and other noble-metal electrocatalysts, emphasis is now on the design of catalysts based on Earth-abundant metals. In the design of HER electrocatalysts, it is essential to take into account doping to bring about activation synergy, combination with graphene, or CNTs in order to improve the conductivity, and the optimization of the specific surface area by decreasing the catalyst size to increase its proportion of active sites. Therefore decreasing the catalyst size down to the single atom should be extremely efficient and now appear most promising in the overall catalyst field. Several Mo- and W-based HER electrocatalysts have been reported taking into account the need of these properties with an Earth-abundant metal. Indeed the electronic structures of Mo2C, WC, W2C, MoP, WN, MoS2, and WSe2 inter alia have indicated that these catalysts are excellent substitutes of Pt. Mo-based nanomaterials have been much investigated as HER electrocatalysts with low overpotentials, including MoS2, MoSe2, Mo2C, MoB, MoP, and Mo-containing bimetallic NPs. MoO2, a semiconductor, has received a lot of attention as a promising stable anode material due high electrochemical activity. The seemingly metallic MoO2 behavior is essentially due to the delocalization of metal electrons in its conduction band, and the multiple oxygen vacancies in transition metal oxides narrow the band gaps and create additional active sites boosting the electrocatalytic activity. Although MoS2 has received most attention as a standard HER electrocatalyst in the beginning of the 20th century, it requires a relatively high overpotential and does not present a sufficient density of active edge sites, so that practical applications using this catalyst cannot be envisaged. Mo-based MOF-derived nanomaterials represent a new generation of cheap, Earth-abundant recently emphasized HER electrocatalysts. Shao and Liu’s group fabricated MoN-NC from Cu-MOF NENU-5. The HER activity of MoN is much enhanced by the presence of porous MoN@N-doped carbon octahedrons derived from MOFs. MoN-NC achieved an overpotential of 62 mV at current density of 10 mA cm–2, and the Tafel slope was 54 mV dec–1 in 0.5 M H2SO4. MoN presents corrosion resistance, and the catalytic property of MoN-NC was also attributed to the unique MoN structure and the synergy between MoN and the N-doped carbon substrate. Li’s group synthesized MoP@PC (), also starting from NENU-5 further functionalized with phosphorus-containing groups aiming at further formation of P-doped carbon after pyrolysis. Therefore the authors synthesized a POMOF to fabricate MoP encapsulated in P-doped porous carbon, i.e., MoP@PC, by carbonization and phosphidation. This catalyst showed an onset overpotential of 97 mV to reach 10 mA cm–2 current density, with a Tafel slope of 59.3 mV dec–1 in 0.5 M H2SO4. Thomas’ group reported a hierarchically mesoporous Mo-based carbon electrocatalyst synthesized from MOF precursors. This Mo-based mesoporous electrocatalyst exhibited HER activity and stability with an overpotential of 222 mV at 100 mA cm–2 (compare Pt/C: 263 mV).

elements.content: Zhang and Li’s groups designed ultrasmall WC NPs using as precursor zeolitic metal-azolate framework (MAF)-6 to confine [W­(CO)6] before pyrolysis. MAF-6 is nitrogen-rich, which favors the production of N-doped carbon for the stabilization of nanoclusters. Pyrolysis yieded WC nanoclusters/NP of 2 nm size. This electrocatalyst showed an overpotential of 51 mV at 10 mA cm–2 and Tafel slope of 49 mV per decade, as well as exchange current density of 2.4 mA cm–2 in 0.5 M H2 SO4. A single-W-atom MOF-derived N-doped carbon catalyst, W-SAC with W1N1C3 local structure, has been designed by Wang’s group (). In order to synthesize this catalyst, WCl5 was encapsulated in UiO-66-NH2 in which the NH2 group prevented W species aggregation, followed by pyrolysis at 950 °C. W-SAC exhibited an overpotential (85 mV) at a current density of 10 mA cm–2 and a Tafel slope of 53 mV dec–1 in 0.1 M KOH. The HER activity is comparable to that of commercial Pt/C and benefits from the structure of the W1N1C3 species as revealed by DFT calculations.

elements.content: Electrocatalysts based on the late first-raw transition metals have recently been the subject of special attention in view of the low cost and abundance of these metals. Thus such catalysts have been made with Fe, Co, Ni, and Cu, although NPs of these metal NPs must be handled carefully in the absence of air to avoid oxidation, at least on their surface. Xiang’s group synthesized in a single step Fe x P@NPC () an iron phosphide hybrid encapsulated in hollow N–P codoped carbon derived from MIL-101-NH2-Fe-P (P from glyphosine via postsynthetic modification). This electrocatalyst showed a nearly constant voltage with only less than 0.1% increase at 10 mA cm–2 after 90 h in a full water splitting cell. The Faradaic efficiency was nearly quantitative with a similar level after 10 days.

elements.content: Most monometallic HER electrocatalysts are based on Co NPs. Co@N-CNTs@rGO reported by Fang et al. was derived from core–shell ZIF-67@ZIF-8 (). In order to fabricate ultrafine Co NPs N-doped carbon, NTs were grafted onto both sides of graphene oxide (GO) by annealing GO-wrapped bimetallic (Co–Zn) ZIF-67@ZIF-8. Therefore Zn2+ was electrostatically bonded to the oxygen atoms of GO, and then 2-MeIm was coordinated to Zn2+ allowing ZIF growth on both GO sides. The so-formed sandwich-shape ZIF-8@GO template then served as an epitaxial seed for the growth of ZIF-67 in the presence of Co2+ and 2-MeIm in a solvothermal reaction for 6 h at 90 °C. Co@N-CNTs@rGO was finally fabricated by pyrolysis at 900 °C liberating the GO and Co2+ that were reduced to rGO and Co NPs, respectively, whereas reduced Zn evaporated, leaving mesopores and micropores. Co@N-CNTs@rGO showed in HER, for a current density of 10 mA cm–2 (η10), catalytic activity in both 1 M KOH (overpotential: 108 mV) and 0.5 M H2SO4 solution (overpotential: 87 mV). Durability in both acidic and alkaline conditions was observed. Employing the same strategy, some binary and ternary alloy@N-CNTs@rGO were fabricated and showed good performances.

for the growth of ZIF-67 in the presence of Co2+ and 2-MeIm

whereas reduced Zn evaporated, leaving mesopores and micropores. Co@N-CNTs@rGO showed in HER, for a current density of 10 mA
cm–2 (η10), catalytic activity
in both 1 M KOH (overpotential: 108 mV) and 0.5 M H2SO4 solution (overpotential: 87 mV). Durability in both acidic
and alkaline conditions was observed. Employing the same strategy,

good performances.

elements.content: Li’s group fabricated ZIF-67-derived CoPS/NC and CoP-CNTs upon introducing phosphorus atoms into the nanomaterials. For the former catalyst, ternary pyrite Co phosphosulfide NPs on a N-doped carbon matrix were fabricated by carbonization and phosphosulfurization of Co-ZIF-67. This electrocatalyst showed a catalytic current density of 10 mA cm–2 at overpotentials of 80 and 148 mV versus RHE and Tafel slope of 68 and 78 mV dec–1 in 0.5 M H2SO4 and 1 M KOH, respectively, which was among the best results obtained for transition-metal phosphosulfide HER catalysts. Synergistic catalytic effects between CoP polyhedron NPs and CNTs were disclosed for CoP-CNTs that exhibited HER activity, with an overpotential of 139 mV yielding a current density of 10 mA cm–2, a Tafel slope of 52 mV dec–1, and a stability over 20 h in 0.5 M H2SO4. Liu’s group used a cobalt-based MOF as the starting material to fabricate a hybrid of CoP nanocrystals (∼10 nm) confined in N-doped bundled carbon nanowires (CoP/NCNWs). The Co-MOF precursor of bundle-like nanowire morphology was prepared via a solvothermal reaction. Co cations were linked by trimesic anions (Hbtc2) forming a planar structure. Pyrolysis was conducted at 700 °C, far above the MOF decomposition temperature of 300 °C. The CoP/NCNWs hybrid displayed a Tafel slope of ∼50 mV dec–1; the Tafel slope for CoP/NC-D, CoP/C, and CoP NPs were 65, 70, and 69 mV dec–1, respectively, which demonstrated the Volmer-Heyrovsky mechanism. The Hu and Bu group reported a MOF containing Co and S as a precursor of Co sulfide with a variety of Co/S stoichiometries. Co9S8/CoS1.097/rGO showed HER with an overpotential of 50 mV at a current density of 1 mA cm–2 and 188 mV at a current density of 10 mA cm–2.

elements.content: Single-phase Ni phosphide materials fabricated from a MOF precursor with a hierarchically porous and regular morphology are highly desired as active HER electrocatalysts. Zhao’s group synthesized a regular three-dimensional hierarchically porous single-phase Ni 2 P polyhedron from a MOF-74-Ni precursor using one-step calcination at only 275 °C with sodium hypophosphite. In this way, Ni2P inherited the morphology and porosity of its precursor MOF-74-Ni. Ni 2 P presented an overpotential of 158 mV to reach a current density of 10 mA cm–2 and a Tafel slope of 73 mV dec–1 in 0.5 M H2SO4, showing the Volmer-Heyrovsky mechanism for HER. The Ni 2 P electrocatalyst was durable for over 20 h. Ni NPs synthesized by optimizing the annealing temperature of Ni-MOF performed HER with an overpotential of 41 mV at 10 mA cm–2. The introduction of Ni3+ lowered the Gibbs free energy of H-atom absorption on the Ni/NiO surface, due to the presence of additional active sites, which was confirmed by DFT calculation.

elements.content: The Chen group designed a core–shell structure of NiSe2 NPs@N-doped graphene derived from a Ni-based MOF in both acidic and alkaline media. In acidic (or alkaline) media, the hybrid had an onset potential of −163 (or −171) mV versus RHE, an overpotential of 201 (or 248) mV versus RHE at 10 mA cm–2, and a Tafel slope of 36.1 (or 74.2) mV dec–1.

elements.content: Copper, as a low-cost material that has recently emerged as an abundant source of numerous catalytic processes, was an obvious candidate for the fabrication of MOF-derived green catalysts for energy conversion. Zang’s group synthesized Cu 3 P@NPPC-650. The authors chose a Cu-based MOF (Cu-NPMOF), connecting the Cu2+ nodes with two linkers, 1-hydroxyethylidene-1,1-diphosphonic acid, and N-atom-containing pyrazine as a template, to fabricate, after pyrolysis at 650 °C, Cu3P NPs covered with a N,P-co-doped carbon shell, Cu 3 P@NPPC-650. This electrocatalyst exhibited an overpotential of 89 mV for η10 in 0.5 M H2SO4 with a Tafel slope of 76 mV dec–1, suggesting the Volmer-Heyrovsky mechanism.

elements.content: Platinum-based materials remaining the best performing HER electrocatalysts, smarter strategies for the design of sophisticated Pt-based nanomaterials fabricated from MOF-based precursors are highly desired, and some recent reports have indeed appeared. For example, Chen’s group synthesized Pt@NHPCP from ZIF-8. In 0.1 M HClO4, to obtain a current density of 10 mA cm–2, the overpotential value of Pt@NHPCP (−57.0 mV) was lower than that of commercial Pt/C (−69.6 mV), and the Tafel slope (27 mV dec–1) was also lower than for Pt/C (32 mV dec–1), suggesting a Volmer–Tafel mechanism for HER. The catalyst Pt@NHPCP was demonstrated to have better HER durability than Pt/C by durability tests after 5000 potential cycles. Sun’s group reported N-doped hollow carbon nanospheres fabricated from a MOF for in situ Pt dispersion. Therefore Pt NPs were anchored on the surface of electrode modified with the carbon nanospheres. In H2SO4, the Tafel slope was 33 mV dec–1, the overpotential was 40 mV to reach the current density of 10 mA cm–2, and the catalyst was stable for 4000 CV cycles with a total 30 h of high current density (10, 50, and 100 mA cm–2 chronoamperometric electrolysis).

elements.content: Numerous bimetallic HER electrocatalysts have been reported with Fe, Co, Ni, Mo, W, or a noble metal. Fu and Sun’s group designed a MOF-templated approach with MIL-88B to synthesize Co incorporating FeP nanotubes. First CoFe MIL-88B nanorods were assembled by a solvothermal process using two metal salts and 1,4-BDC, next these nanorods were converted to semihollow CoFeO x by calcination in air, and then after phosphidation, the hollow Co–Fe–P nanotubes were obtained. They presented abundant catalytic sites, fast mass and charge transport pathways, and optimized electronic configuration. The Co–Fe–P nanotubes performed in a wide pH range, achieving overpotentials of 86, 108, and 66 mV at a current density of 10 mA cm–2 in 1 M KOH, 1 M phosphate buffer solution, and 0.5 M H2SO4, respectively. DFT calculations attributed the efficiency to the increased density of states near the Fermi level created by Co substitution. Hou’s group reported a hierarchical porous Co9S8–N-doped carbon@MoS2 polyhedral nanomaterial named Co 9 S 8 /NC@MoS 2 in which the morphology of the ZIF-67 precursor was preserved (). The Co/NC polyhedrons, precursors of the Co9S8 NPs, were synthesized by carbonization at 800 °C of Co-based ZIF-67, and these authors improved the conductivity of the hybrid to allow charge transfer at the electrode/electrolyte interface. Co 9 S 8 /NC@MoS 2 served as a pH-universal HER electrocatalyst exhibiting activity for HER with overpotentials at 10 mA cm–2 in 1.0 M KOH (67 mV), 0.5 M H2SO4 (117 mV), and 1.0 M phosphate buffer solution (261 mV). The Tafel slopes were 60.3, 68.8, and 126.1 mV dec–1, respectively.

elements.content: Among Earth-abundant metal-based HER electrocatalysts, the Ni–Mo alloys were those that exhibited the lowest overpotentials. Zheng and Li et al. synthesized NiMo–C from a well-known Ni-MOF, Ni3(BTC)2. This nanomaterial consisted of Ni NPs incorporated in a molybdate by addition of MoCl5 during the preparation of the Ni-MOF, which did not modify the Ni–MOF structure, and the Mo oxide was encapsulated in N-doped carbon layers. NiMo–C was obtained upon heating MoOx@Ni-MOF (Mo: Ni molar ratio of 6:94) at 450 °C under an atmosphere of NH3: Ar = 1:5 (v/v). A current density of 20 mA cm–2 (η20) was obtained with an overpotential of 58 mV, and this potential remained stable at 20 mA cm–2 for 12 h. The Tafel slope was 57 mV dec–1. The d-band center of the CoIr alloy is located in the vicinity of the Fermi level and close to that of the Pt benchmark. This suggested that the electronic state of the CoIr alloy would be similar to that of Pt. Therefore on this basis, Chen’s group fabricated Ir–Co alloys encapsulated in N-doped carbon, IrCo@NC, for HER catalysis. The fabrication of the MOF-derived IrCo@NC catalyst involved incorporation of Ir into the Prussian-blue analog Co3[Co­(CN)6]2, which provided Ir as a single-atom precursor to form the desired nanomaterial composed of an alloy core with highly N-doped carbon layers. The obtained precursor was carbonized at temperatures between 500 and 800 °C under inert atmosphere, provoking the merging of Ir and Co into the Ir–Co alloy, while the CN– groups were carbonized to form an N-rich graphene as layers at the alloy surface. The Tafel slope was 23 mV dec–1, indicating a Volmer-Heyrovsky reaction mechanism. The catalytic performance was superior to most reported catalysts, owing to electron transfer from the IrCo core to the graphene shell as demonstrated by DFT calculations. The trend of η in 0.5 M H2SO4 at the current density of 10 mA cm–2 ranked according to IrCo@NC-500 (24 mV) < 20% Pt/C (35 mV) < 20% Ir/C (51 mV) < 5% Pt/C (59 mV) < Co@NC-600 (276 mV). It is remarkable that the alloy effect was clear compared to the individual metals and that the HER performance of optimal IrCo@NC-500 even exceeded that of 20 wt % Pt/C.

elements.content: Wang et al. prepared bimetallic NiRu@N–C from Ni-based MOF [Ni2-(bdc)2ted] for HER. First the Ni-based MOF [Ni2(bdc)2ted] was synthesized by reacting Ni­(NO3)2·6H2O, bdc (1,4-benzenedicarboxylic acid), and ted (triethylenediamine) in DMF solution at 130 °C for 24 h. Ni-MOF reacted with a RuCl3 solution, and the sheet-like morphology of the original Ni-based MOF was essentially maintained. Then the Ru-doped Ni-based MOF precursors were pyrolyzed at 800 °C under nitrogen, which provoked the reduction of NiII and RuIII to bimetallic RuNi alloy nanocrystals and the formation of nitrogen-doped graphitized carbon layers from the organic components of the precursor. For a current density of 10 mA cm–2, 50 mV was needed from this catalyst in 0.5 M H2SO4 and 32 mV was needed in 1.0 M KOH corresponding to Tafel slopes of 36 mV dec–1 in 0.5 H2SO4 and 64 mV dec–1 in KOH, respectively.

elements.content: Among the noble metals, Ru ($42 per oz) is the cheapest compared to Pt ($992 per oz), Ir ($500 per oz), and Pd ($551) per oz. Chen’s group also believed that the strong electronic interactions via the interface of the Ru/MoO2 nanomaterial would enhance electrical conductivity and lower the energy barriers of intermediates, and therefore, on this basis these authors fabricated Ru-MoO 2 prepared from Mo-MOF (Mo3(btc)2) annealing. The nanostructure involved Ru NPs dispersed on the MoO2 surface. For the synthesis of Ru-MoO 2 , an aqueous RuCl3 solution was first added to an oxygen-free ethanol solution of Mo-btc NPs, and after separation, this precursor was pyrolyzed at 700 °C. At a current density of 10 mA cm–2, the electrocatalyst showed a good activity under both acidic 0.5 M H2SO4 (55 mV) and 1 M KOH (29 mV), better than that of 20% Pt/C. The Tafel slopes were 44 and 31 mV dec–1, respectively. DFT calculations suggested that the catalytic performances benefited from the electronic interactions between Ru NPs and MoO2.

elements.content:
The OER is the oxidation of water at the anode producing O2: 2 H 2 O → O 2 + 4 H + + 4 e −

The reaction proceeds with sluggish kinetics and large overpotential, however, and a variety of mechanisms have been proposed, as well as the four following overall steps: H 2 O site → HO * + H + + e − HO * → O * + H + + e − O * + H 2 O → HOO * + H + + e − HOO * → O 2 + H + + e −

elements.content: Understanding the actual OER mechanism is thus essential because the sluggish OER is the current bottleneck of efficient water electrolysis and also is key to the rechargeable metal-air batteries. The optimization of the OER kinetics is crucial for the applications of the water-splitting process, including the efficient generation of hydrogen. A high surface area is expected to optimize the electrocatalyst as well as hydrophilicity to take the evolved bubbles into account. It must overtake the high free energies of HO*, O*, HOO* and anionic species binding on the surface causing large overpotentials. The best catalysts are so far noble metals (Pt) and noble metal oxides (RuO2 and IrO2). The best and so far most popular catalyst is RuO2, but it is corroded (as IrO2) under operating conditions. Research with MOFs is at the forefront of new catalyst optimization. For instance MOF functional groups such as −NH2, organic ligands, and coordinated metals significantly decrease or influence these surface binding energies. In order to compensate for the poor MOF conductivity and enhance electrode/electrolyte interface, highly porous composite nanomaterials must be elaborated for instance by growing MOF films on highly conductive compounds such as GO and MWCNTs. Cobalt is an Earth-abundant metal of choice for OER electrocatalysis with MOFs because pyrolysis forms Co3O4 that provide O–H interactions favoring proton mobility. Doping MOF-Co catalysts with P, C, or Ni upon calcination also proved efficient in lowering overpotentials, and therefore, the calcination temperature is very influencial. Recently, various transition metal catalysts, especially non-noble metals, such as Fe, Co, Ni, Mn, Cu, and their oxides, especially hybridized with N-doped carbons, have been fabricated and successfully applied for OER, and the area has specifically been reviewed by Zhao’s group in 2017. The transition metals favor the crystallinity and electrical conductivity of carbon matrix by catalytic graphitization at high temperature, which protect the metals from corrosion and aggregation during the electrochemical reactions. The synergy of metal species, the doped N species, and carbon lattice introduce localized reactive sites upon modification of the charge distribution on the carbon surface by promoting electron transfer, thereby modifying O2 adsorption and facilitating the ORR and OER. Recent results on OER are discussed in the following sections ().

elements.content: Numerous Co-based MOF electrocatalysts for OER have recently emerged. NC@Co–NGC DSNCs with NC as inner shell and Co-NGC as outer shell () was fabricated by Zhao and Qiu’s group. The hybrid nanocages involve closely packed double shells comprising a ZIF-8-derived inner shell of N-doped microporous carbon (NC) and a ZIF-67-derived outer shell of codecorated N-doped mesoporous graphitic carbon (Co-NGC), noted NC@Co–NGC DSNCs. Polyhedral nanocrystals of ZIF-8 were first fabricated by the coordination of Zn2+ by 2-MeIm in methanol and function as crystal seeds for subsequent epitaxial growth of ZIF-67 with similar structure ([M­(MeIm)2] (M = Zn for ZIF-8 or Co for ZIF-67). The resulting ZIF-8@ZIF-67 nanomaterial presenting structural similarities with ZIF-8 and ZIF-67 crystals is then thermally annealed under N2 at 800 °C followed by etching away the unstable Co NPs with H2SO4, which forms short carbon NTs on the surface. The catalytic activities for OER (η10: 1.64 V, Tafel slope: 91 mV dec–1) were superior to those of Pt and RuO2, due to the synergistic effect between the CoNPs and two carbon shells.

elements.content: Fan’s group synthesized CoSe 2 -450 from Co-MOF (using cobalt nitrate hexahydrate and 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylic acid as precursors). The hollow MOF precursor Co-MOF was converted into a catalyst by single-step selenization annealing at 450 °C under Ar. The catalyst exhibits a η10 of 330 mV with a Tafel slope of 79 mV dec–1, which is superior to that of IrO2. The catalytic activity was attributed to the hollow CoSe2 shape and the well-distributed active sites. CoSe 2 -450 shows a durability of 1000 CV cycles.

elements.content: N, P, and S are widely used to dope MOF materials in order to enhance the catalytic performances, and thus Li and Su et al. fabricated Co@NC-3/1 from CoZn-BMZIF (). Co@NC-3/1 presented OER activity (η10: 1.57 V, Tafel slope: 85 mV dec–1) in 1 M KOH, which exceeded the OER performance of RuO2 and IrO2, and it exhibited stability for 2000-circle scanning. These authors also addressed the difficult challenge of designing a bifunctional electrocatalyst able to perform both ORR and OER. Indeed Ru- and Ir-based composites that present the best OER activity are also poor ORR catalysts. Pt Ir alloys and their oxides perform well as ORR catalysts but are not stable, and their scarcity also precludes commercial applications. Transition-metal chalcogenides and oxides are potentially able to serve as catalysts for both ORR and OER, but they suffer from easy NP aggregation, large NP size, low specific surface areas, and lack of active sites. On the other hand, transition-metal carbonitriles are good candidates, and therefore, ZIFs are excellent precursors with plenty of N atoms that can form N-doped carbons upon pyrolysis. Therefore, these authors synthesized N-doped graphitic carbon frameworks cross-linked with Co NPs and crystalline CNTs derived from Co x Zn y -BMZIF for both ORR and OER. Porous carbons derived from Co x Zn y -BMZIF indeed combine the advantages of carbons derived from both ZIF-8 and ZIF-67, and they benefit from high large surface area, graphitic carbon, highly dispersed N, and active Co–N x groups.

elements.content: Co9S8 NP-embedded N/S-co-doped carbon nanofibers derived from ZIF-wrapped CdS nanowires Co 9 S 8 /NSCNFs was reported by the Song and Zhang group as OER electrocatalysts. Therefore CdS nanowires were synthesized by solvothermal reaction, and then CdS@ZIF was prepared by mixing Zn­(NO3)2, 2-MeIm, and PVP in methanol with CdS followed by pyrolysis under N2 leading to Co 9 S 8 /NSCNFs. The overpotential with this electrocatalyst to reach a current density of 10 mA cm–2 was of 302 mV, the Tafel slope was 54 mV dec–1, and stability of Co 9 S 8 /NSCNFs for 1000 CV cycles was observed. Another S,N-co-doped carbon-fiber nanomaterial, Co/Co x S y @SNCF-800, was fabricated by Zhang’s group. These authors synthesized [Co­(Tdc)­(bpy)] n as a MOF using water and methanol as solvents with NaOH. The presence of doubly pillared layer structures brought a high thermal stability to the Co-MOFs. Pyrolysis at 800 °C provided uniformly encapsulated 50–100 nm Co/Co x S y NPs into the carbon structure. The η10 potential of this nanomaterial was of 1.542 V and the Tafel slope of 68 mV dec–1 for OER, close to those of RuO2 (1.536 V, 59 mV dec–1). Besides these two reports, several other OER catalysts were fabricated based on Co oxides. For example, Jiang et al. fabricated UTSA-16 with a Co4O4 core. Benefiting from the synergistic effects of the porous structure, high-valent Co and cubane-shaped Co4O4, UTSA-16 exhibited activity toward OER in 1.0 M KOH with η10 of 408 mV and Tafel slope of 77 mV dec–1, which is much smaller than Co3O4 but still larger than RuO2.

elements.content: Ni-based OER electrocatalysts are less numerous than those based on Co, but examples have recently appeared. Chao et al. fabricated Ni NPs@N-CNTs for OER electrocatalysis. The Ni-MOF precursor, prepared from Ni­(NO3)2·H2O, Na2CO3, 4,40-bipyridine, and D-(+)-camphoric acid in water at 120 °C, was pyrolyzed at 600 °C for 3h yielding Ni NPs@N-CNTs.

and D-(+)-camphoric acid in water at 120 °C, was pyrolyzed at

elements.content: Acharya et al. reported a hybrid electrocatalyst, AgNPs@rGO/MIL-88B­(Fe), that was based on a MOF, MIL-88B (Fe), and chemically grown in situ on flexible GO sheets and then doped with Ag NPs. AgNPs@rGO/MIL-88B­(Fe) provided an overpotential of 395 mV at a current density of 1 mA cm–2 with a Tafel slope of 60 mV dec–1 in a neutral buffer solution. The catalyst also exhibited stability for over 30 days. The catalytic performances may be due to the stability of AgNPs, high porosity, and conductivity of the hybrid MOF structure.

elements.content: Co oxide-based electrocatalysts have shown promising performances for the OER, but they are not commercially viable because of their low conductivity and aggregation in alkaline media. The use of MOFs as template precursors should allow overcoming these problems, however. In particular, MOF-derived bimetallic electrocatalysts appear especially suitable due to their tunability toward microstructures, compatibility with many metal ions, and ability to achieve uniform dispersion of derived carbon.
elements.clean_text:
Bimetallic Catalysts for OER
Co
oxide-based electrocatalysts have shown promising performances for
the OER, but they are not commercially viable because of their low
conductivity and aggregation in alkaline media. The use of MOFs as
template precursors should allow overcoming these problems, however.
In particular, MOF-derived bimetallic electrocatalysts appear especially
suitable due to their tunability toward microstructures, compatibility
with many metal ions, and ability to achieve uniform dispersion of
derived carbon.

elements.content: Co and Fe being two most Earth-abundant and benign metals, their combination in catalysts is attractive in spite of their low intrinsic conductivity and trend to agglomerate leading to high overpotentials. The ability of charge transfer is a missing quality of these metal NPs in terms of overpotential. Bimetallic synergy in the effect of additives such as oxyphosphides appears suitable for catalyst improvements, in particular, with MOF-derived materials that bring about sufficient porosity. With porous structure the diffusion of oxygen gas bubbles is expedited as well as the stability and rigidity of the structure for optimized electron transfer. On the basis of these concepts Wang et al. synthesized the bimetallic CoFe nanomaterial Co 3 FeP x O. Therefore, a mixed Co3Fe MOF with nanodiamond morphology was fabricated from a solution of Co2+, Fe3+, and p-benzenedicarboxylic acid (BDC) followed by phosphorylation with NaH2PO2 and annealing in air at 550 °C to give the CoFe oxyphosphide Co 3 FeP x O. The Co/Fe ratio was optimized to Co3Fe, and this nanocatalyst exhibited an activity of η10 = 291 mV, Tafel slope = 85 mV dec–1, and durability over 18 h for OER because of the highly active sites in the porous structure and the efficient electron transfer from metal to P.

elements.content: Likewise, Ni is another first-raw late transition metal of choice to combine with Co or Fe for synergy with the advantages and qualities indicated above, and several reports have appeared with such bimetallic OER catalysts. Thus combining Ni and Fe, Jiang’s group synthesized the bimetallic catalyst Fe–Ni–P/rGO-400, prepared from a Ni-MOF template. Benefiting from the synergistic effect between Fe and Ni, the good conductivity of rGO and the highly porous structure, an overpotential of 240 mV was found to reach 10 mA cm–2 and a Tafel slope of 63 mV dec–1 was obtained, better than IrO2 and most non-noble metal electrocatalysts. After 5 h of continuous CV scanning, the catalyst was slightly inactivated.

elements.content: In order to optimize synergy, trimetallic nanomaterials have also been tested as OER catalysts combining three first-raw late transition metals. Zhang’s group reported Ni 3 FeN/Co,N-CNF, prepared from a ZIF-type MOF with 2-MeIm linkers after carbonization of the precursor at 900 °C for 2 h under N2. This nanomaterial afforded a η10 of 0.27 V that was superior to that of IrO2 (0.34 V), and the Tafel slope (51 mV dec–1) was lower than that of IrO2 (70 mV dec–1). The remarkable OER activity was attributable to the size effect of Ni3FeN NPs and the Co,N–CNF support that inhibited the aggregation of Ni3FeN.

elements.content: Dong’s group transformed bimetallic MOF polyhedra (CoNi-ZIF PHs) with a hollow structure for the fabrication of NiCoP/NC PHCs using etching with tannic acid, calcination at 700 °C for 3 h, and finally phosphidation with NaH2PO4 at 300 °C for 2 h (). The electrocatalytic properties of this nanocomposite were characterized by an overpotential of 297 mV to reach a current density of 10 mA cm–2 and a Tafel slope of 51 mV dec–1, better than commercial RuO2 (η10: 358 mV, Tafel slope: 81 mV dec–1). The catalyst retained stability over 10 h.

elements.content: Cui’s group encapsulated a Ni–Cu alloy into MOF-74 without additional precursors, and the catalyst showed multiple synergistic effects for the OER. Lee’s group fabricated a 3D bimetallic CoMo-based electrocatalyst CoOx-MoC/NC for OER. This catalyst showed an overpotential of 330 mV at 10 mA cm–2 (smaller than IrO2/C, 400 mV) with a Tafel slope of 89 mV dec–1, benefiting from the synergistic effect between Co and MoC.
