elements.content: Electrocatalytic water splitting, the reverse process of fuel cell reactions, consists in the catalysis of hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) at the cathode and oxygen evolution reaction (OER) at the anode. The energy input under standard conditions is 237 kJ mol–1 (1.23 V), but in practice, the required energy is much higher due to the sluggish kinetics related to multiple electron transfers with bond rearrangements. See the HER and OER sections for mechanistic details. Thus both reactions require efficient catalysts, and therefore, traditionally Pt was by far the best element for HER and RuO2 and IrO2 the best electrocatalysts for OER. Earth-abundant metal components are presently actively searched in particular based on or derived from MOFs. Among the electrocatalysts discussed and cited in the HER and OER sections, some are good catalysts for only one of these two reactions, whereas some others are good catalysts for both reactions. There are many common features for electrocatalysts of these two reactions, however. The electrocatalysts are evaluated for their activity determined by the potential in the polarization curve for which the current density reaches 10 mA cm–2 and the Tafel slope, and for their stability. To date, non-noble metals and their carbides, nitrides, phosphides, sulfides, and selenides have been explored as effective water-splitting electrocatalysts. Pristine MOFs are being more and more rarely used as heterogeneous functional electrocatalysts for overall water splitting, but they can be productively engineered to integrate both catalytic sites of HER and OER in the same MOF structure. Actually there is an impressive increase of the number of reports on HER, OER, and overall water splitting using bifunctional MOF derivatives because they can avoid the drawbacks of low conductivity, aggregation, and limited stability that are currently encountered with pristine MOFs. Typical examples include POM, ZIF-type MOFs, and other hollow structural motifs. In particular, the calcination strategy under well-determined temperature and gas atmosphere conditions allows using MOFs for the fabrication of highly porous composites containing N- and other element-doped carbon-supported transition-metal NPs. Doping elements of conducting carbon materials are classified according to their charge populations as electron donors (F, S, P, and B) and electron acceptors (N, O). Specifically for HER, N/P codoping provided the lowest overpotential results, whereas they were obtained for OER in alkaline media with N-doped mesoprous carbon. The superiority of MOF-dependent strategies in producing porous N- and element-doped carbons encapsulating, thus stabilizing active metal sites, ensuring their dispersity and the material conductivity has been demonstrated. It is manifested by cage confinement, and using adequate engineering, single-site catalysts avoiding metal site aggregation have been designed for efficient electrocatalysis activity and stability for overall water splitting. Publications in the recent years on MOFs in water splitting are discussed in the following sections ().

elements.content: Many transition metal phosphide-based electrocatalyst for overall water splitting have been designed. Recently, non-noble metal based, especially Co (the most used non-noble metal) and Ni catalysts, have drawn much attention for their capabilities in electrocatalytic water splitting. For a number of applications, there is a need of multiple reactions proceeding in tandem or a concerted way. Rather than using several catalysts at the same electrode, it would be desirable to design a single material able to catalyze several reactions. For instance, gas electrodes in fuel cells and metal–air batteries require both OER and ORR catalysts. Mechanistic information would also benefit from such devices. Such an area remains in its infancy, and innovative concepts and materials are awaited toward this goal.
elements.clean_text:
Monometallic Catalysts for Water Splitting
Many transition metal phosphide-based electrocatalyst for overall
water splitting have been designed. Recently, non-noble metal based,
especially Co (the most used non-noble metal) and Ni catalysts, have drawn much attention for their capabilities in electrocatalytic
water splitting. For a number of applications, there is a need of
multiple reactions proceeding in tandem or a concerted way. Rather
than using several catalysts at the same electrode, it would be desirable
to design a single material able to catalyze several reactions. For
instance, gas electrodes in fuel cells and metal–air batteries
require both OER and ORR catalysts. Mechanistic information would
also benefit from such devices. Such an area remains in its infancy,
and innovative concepts and materials are awaited toward this goal.

elements.content: Along this line, the Chen and Li group constructed a hybrid nanostructure CoP/NCNHP with CoP NPs embedded in N-doped CNT hollow polyhedron (NCNHP) using a strategy successively involving pyrolysis at 900 °C, oxidation and phosphidation from a ZIF-8@ZIF-67 (). The seed ZIF-8-derived N-doped carbon, from which Zn evaporated with the temperature reaching above 900 °C (under Ar flow), functioned as a nanostructured hollow frame promoting the diffusion kinetics. The CNTs formed on the surface of hollow polyhedrons upon pyrolysis played a major catalytic role. This catalyst CoP/NCNHP was used as both anode and cathode for overall water splitting, and a potential of 1.64 V was needed to achieve the current density of 10 mA cm–2 with durability of 36 h without significant potential decrease.

elements.content: Liu and Sun et al. designed a trifunctional catalyst Co/CoP-HNC prepared from Co-based ZIF-67, this MOF type being chosen for its uniform pore size and large number of C, Co, and N atoms in the framework. Pyrolysis of Co-ZIF-67 with dicyandiamide resulted in the formation of carbon polyhedrons penetrated with CNTs. ORR activity is provided by the Co NPs embedded in the N-CNTs. HER and OER activities come from the Co NPs on the side wall of hierarchical N-doped carbon polyhedrons as a result of the phophorization of uncovered Co NPs. For a current density of 10 mA cm–2, the overpotential was 0.18 V for HER. For OER and overall water splitting in 1.0 M KOH, 1.53 and 1.68 V were needed, respectively. In another report of multiple electrocatalysis, Zhang and Liu’s group fabricated a Co NP-embedded N-doped carbon/CNT framework by pyrolysis of a Co-containing MOF with adenine as a ligand without any other precursor. This Co@N-CNTF catalyst showed performances toward the ORR, OER, and HER, with a high half-wave potential of 0.81 V versus RHE for the ORR, and overpotential at 10 mA cm–2 for the OER of 0.35 V and HER of 0.22 V, and for overall water splitting an alkaline electrolyzer with 10 mA cm–2 under a stable voltage of 1.71 V. These performances were attributed to the abundant, homogeneously distributed Co NP active sites within the N-doped graphitic layer. The Jin and Ma group synthesized CoPS@NPS-C with CoPS NPs and tridoped (N, P, S) porous carbon fabricated from a Co-ZIF-67 MOF and commercial carbon black (XC-72) precursors. The catalyst benefited from the interaction between CoPS NPs and NPS-C. Overpotentials of 93 mV and 191 mV were needed to reach the current density of 10 mA cm–2 in 0.5 M H2SO4 and 1 M KOH, respectively, for HER; 320 mV was needed under these latter conditions for OER. Toward overall water splitting, the observed value under the same alkaline conditions for η10 was 1.62 V.

elements.content: After Co, Ni is the second-most used Earth-abundant metal on which electrocatalysts are based for water splitting. Theoretical calculations have indicated that Ni2P possesses a superior activity compared to the noble metal catalysts for HER, and catalytic results also showed high activity in OER, making the synthesis of Ni2P a privileged choice for overall water splitting electrocatalysis. Xing and Zhao et al. fabricated Ni 2 P/rGO from MOF-74-Ni-GO upon heating with NaH2PO2·H2O at 275 °C for 3 h. The exposed defects of the rGO sheets on Ni2P/rGO showed that Ni2P NPs have grown ultrasmall nickel phosphide nanocrystals on both sides of rGO, so that a sandwich structure was obtained for Ni 2 P/rGO (). TEM images indicated that Ni 2 P/rGO remained in the same shape as MOF-74-Ni/GO without aggregation of homogeneous carbon formed during the phosphorization, which was a source of electron highway for enhanced electron-transfer efficiency. A large active surface area and a perfect dispersity of active sites were provided with a NP size of 2.6 nm. In 1.0 M KOH, Ni 2 P/rGO exhibited η10 of 142 mV, 260 mV, and 1.61 V, for HER, OER, and overall water splitting, respectively.

elements.content: Several noble-metal-free bi- or trimetallic electrocatalysts for water splitting were recently reported by combining Co with Ti, Mo, W, Fe, Ni, or Zn, increasing the possibilities of activation synergies compared to monometallic electrocatalysts. Several catalysts have been designed with Ni, and Zhao’s group reported Co4Ni1P, synthesized from MOF-74. This catalyst exhibited η10 values of 129 mV, 245 mV, and 1.59 V for HER, OER, and overall water splitting, respectively, thanks to the highly dispersed active sites and the synergistic effect between NiCoP and Co2P. The catalyst was also stable with a durability test over 50 h.
elements.clean_text:
Bi- and Trimetallic Catalysts for Water
Splitting
Several noble-metal-free bi- or trimetallic electrocatalysts
for water splitting were recently reported by combining Co with Ti,
Mo, W, Fe, Ni, or Zn, increasing the possibilities of activation synergies
compared to monometallic electrocatalysts. Several catalysts have been designed with Ni, and Zhao’s group reported Co4Ni1P, synthesized
from MOF-74. This catalyst exhibited
η10 values of 129 mV, 245 mV, and 1.59 V for HER,
OER, and overall water splitting, respectively, thanks to the highly
dispersed active sites and the synergistic effect between NiCoP and
Co2P. The catalyst was also stable with a durability test
over 50 h.

elements.content: Liu’s group fabricated Co 9 S 8 -NSC@Mo 2 C composed of Co9S8 and Mo2C NPs starting from the ZIF-67 precursor. The electrocatalyst showed HER performances over a broad pH range. To achieve a current density of 10 mA cm–2, the overpotentials were 74, 89, and 121 mV in 0.5 M H2SO4, 1.0 M KOH, and 1.0 M phosphate-buffered solution, with Tafel slopes of 69.3, 86.7, and 106.4 mV dec–1, respectively. η10 of 293 mV with a Tafel slope of 59.7 mV dec–1 was observed for OER, with a η10 value of 1.6 V in 1.0 M KOH. The catalytic activities of Co 9 S 8 -NSC@Mo 2 C were assigned to electron transfer between Co and Mo2C. Also prepared from the precursor ZIF-67, the catalyst Fe–CoP HTPAs was synthesized by Yu’s group, with a needed overpotential of 98 and 230 mV to achieve a 10 mA cm–2 current density for HER and OER. Toward overall water splitting, the η10 was only 1.59 V because of the abundant active sites and efficient electron-transfer properties of the catalyst.

elements.content: Bai and Sun’s group reported several catalysts combining Co and Zn. For instance, these authors synthesized a catalyst containing Co3ZnC and Co NPs embedded in a N-doped CNT-grafted carbon polyhedron framework, Zn0.975Co0.025S/CoS2 NPs. This nanomaterial was obtained by pyrolysis of CoZn-ZIF in a reducing atmosphere of H2/Ar (). The electrical conductivity and structure stability were improved by the interconnected CNTs in the polyhedra. Because of the mesoporous structure and the synergetic effect of Zn and Co, the catalyst ZnCoS-NSCNT/NP exhibited the following catalytic performance for HER (η10: 152 mV), OER (η10: 270 mV), and overall water splitting (η10: 1.59 V) in 1 M KOH and showed stability during 40 h for water splitting.

elements.content: A number of catalysts have been reported upon combining Ni and Fe. Manthiram and Ahn designed C-incorporated porous Fe–Ni phosphide nanorods grown on commercial Ni foam, Ni–Fe–P@C NRs. This catalyst displayed activity for both HER (η10, 79 mV; Tafel slope, 92.6 mV dec–1) and OER (η10, 217 mV; Tafel slope, 40 mV dec–1) in 1.0 KOH. It needed only 1.52 V to afford a current density of 10 mA cm–2 with over 24 h stability for water splitting. The Xu and Zhu groups designed a MIL-53­(NiFe)-based electrode composed of thin Ni–Fe MOF foam nanosheets containing small Fe–Ni clusters that they used as OER electrocatalyst with performance of required overpotentials 227 and 253 mV for current densities of 10 and 100 mA cm–2, respectively, which outperformed the benchmark of RuO. Upon coupling with a Pt electrode in overall water splitting, only 1.537 V was needed to obtain a current density of 10 mA cm–2.

elements.content: Co has also been combined with noble metals. For instance Tang and Wang’s group fabricated core–shell Co@Ir NPs encapsulated in porous carbon, Co@Ir/NC-10%. This catalyst was derived from ZIF-67 by pyrolysis at 900 °C for 3 h and then the powder dispersed under ambient conditions in water was impregnated with aqueous IrCl3·3H2O. Co@Ir/NC-10% exhibited an overpotential of 121 mV for HER and 280 mV for OER at a current density of 10 mA cm–2 in 1 M KOH. It may be practical for water splitting with a potential of 1.7 V.

elements.content:
In fuel cells, O2 is reduced at the cathodic half-cell according to O 2 + 4 H + + 4 e − → 2 H 2 O

O2 is adsorbed then reduced by an associative, dissociative, or peroxo mechanism that proceeds either unfavorably according to a 2e– pathway via the intermediate H2O2 or through the hoped-for 4e– pathway. ORR is of great importance in electrochemical energy conversion area including proton exchange membrane fuel cells (PEMFCs) and metal-air batteries. Pt/C has been widely used in ORR for several decades, but Pt is rare and expensive, easy to corrode carbon, and aggregate. Therefore efforts have been dedicated to design and synthesize inexpensive substitutes such as Pt-metal alloys and non-noble metal electrocatalysts to replace Pt/C. The later strategy was pioneered by Mao et al. with Cu-based MOFs. The poor MOF conductivity needs to be overtaken by combining the MOF with conducting graphene oxide (GO) or by using ionic MOF species or a mediator. Calcination of MOFs together with N ligands for the formation of M–N–C carbonaceous composite nanocatalysts (M = Fe or Co) proved especially efficient. A similar approach was used with metal sulfides to form M–S–C composite catalysts or oxides to generate M–O–C catalysts. Boron and phosphorus are other helpful doping atoms. High surface areas and macropores are necessary in these composites for efficient mass transfer, but micropores are also needed for active sites. Publications in recent years on NPs in MOFs for ORR are discussed in the following sections ().

elements.content: Recent research on MOF-derived ORR electrocatalysts has focused on Ti, Fe, Co, Ni, and Cu-containing mono- and bimetallic nanomaterials, in particular when these nanomaterials contained N-doped carbon. Actually, a number of electrocatalysts introduced in the HER and OER section also display good catalytic performance for ORR, some of them being even trifunctional.
elements.clean_text:
Monometallic Catalysis for ORR
Recent research on MOF-derived
ORR electrocatalysts has focused on
Ti, Fe, Co, Ni, and Cu-containing mono- and bimetallic nanomaterials,
in particular when these nanomaterials contained N-doped carbon. Actually,
a number of electrocatalysts introduced in the HER and OER section also display good catalytic
performance for ORR, some of them being even trifunctional.

elements.content: Qin and Huang’s group reported Ti-MOF/N-doped graphene nanomaterials as ORR electrocatalysts in both alkaline and acidic media. The onset potential and the Tafel slope value of the Ti-MOFs/NG nanocomposite are 1.14 V and 17.84 mV dec–1 in 0.1 M HClO4, respectively. The catalysts performances have been attributed to the existences of the Ti3N2–x , C2O7Ti2.3, H2Ti5O11, Ti, and TiO active ORR segments.
elements.clean_text:
Qin and Huang’s group reported Ti-MOF/N-doped graphene
nanomaterials as ORR electrocatalysts in both alkaline and acidic
media. The onset potential and the Tafel slope value of the Ti-MOFs/NG
nanocomposite are 1.14 V and 17.84 mV dec–1 in 0.1
M HClO4, respectively. The
catalysts performances have been attributed to the existences of the
Ti3N2–x
, C2O7Ti2.3, H2Ti5O11, Ti, and TiO active ORR segments.

elements.content: Electrocatalysts based on Fe, the most abundant on Earth, are attractive, and Fe is an active component of electrocatalysts. It has been suggested that Fe–N/C nanomaterials present a better ORR activity than other M-N/C materials with the other first-raw late transition metals as a result of the optimized synergy between the Fe–N fragment and the conductive carbon layers. Therefore Liu and Xia et al. fabricated Fe 3 O 4 /N-HCSC by encapsulating Fe3O4 with a hollow core–shell N-doped carbon sphere with uniformly dispersed Fe–N species in both carbon core and shell. The carbon architecture favors both mass transfer and electron transfer during the catalytic process. Because of these factors related to the porous hollow structure and the synergistic effect between Fe3O4 and NC, the Fe 3 O 4 /N-HCSC shows an E onset of 1.024 V, E 1/2 of 0.846 V, and J L of 5.69 mA cm–2, prior to that of Pt/C.

elements.content: Most recently reported ORR electrocatalysts fabricated from MOFs are based on cobalt. Varela and Dai’s group prepared PANI/ZIF-67 by in situ synthesis of the complex of polyaniline and Co-ZIF-67 followed by simple pyrolysis at 500 °C for 2 h then 800 °C for 3 h. This catalyst consisted of Co/Co3O4/NC and exhibited good catalytic multifunctional activities toward HER, OER, and ORR. Benefiting from the synergy between Co and Co3O4 NPs, PANI/ZIF-67 displayed for ORR E onset of 0.85 V, E 1/2 of 0.75 V, and a diffusion-limited current density of 4.6 mA cm–2.
elements.clean_text:
Most recently reported ORR electrocatalysts
fabricated from MOFs
are based on cobalt. Varela and Dai’s group prepared PANI/ZIF-67 by
in situ synthesis of the complex of polyaniline and Co-ZIF-67 followed
by simple pyrolysis at 500 °C for 2 h then 800 °C for 3
h. This catalyst consisted of Co/Co3O4/NC and exhibited good catalytic multifunctional
activities toward HER, OER, and ORR. Benefiting from the synergy between
Co and Co3O4 NPs, PANI/ZIF-67 displayed
for ORR E
onset of 0.85 V, E
1/2 of 0.75 V, and a diffusion-limited current density
of 4.6 mA cm–2.

elements.content: The Zhang group tuned the dimensions and structures of N-doped carbon nanomaterials upon regulating the Co/Zn ratio in ZIF-8 or ZIF-67 arrays grown in situ on γ-C3N4 nanosheets, forming the 1D, 2D, and 3D nitrogen-doped Co nanomaterials Co/N-BCNTs, N-CNS, and Co/N-CNTFs from Zn/Co-ZIF@g-C3N4, ZIF-8@g-C3N4 (Co free), and ZIF-67@g-C3N4 (Zn free), respectively. After pyrolysis at 900 °C for 1 h, Zn/Co-ZIF@g-C3N4 yielded Co/N-BCNTs that showed a half-wave potential of 0.83 V with a limiting current density of 6 mA cm–2, which is larger than that of Pt/C (E 1/2: 0.82 V, J L: 5.37 mA cm–2) in 0.1 M KOH. Its stability was also demonstrated to be better than Pt/C after a 12 h test. Kim and Lee’s group reported a one-pot synthesis of Co@NC derived from Co-MOFs, Zn x Co1–x (C3H4N2) via a mechanochemical coordination self-assembly synthesis. Pyrolysis of Zn x Co1–x (C3H4N2) yielded the uniform Co@NC nanostructure by simple evaporation of Zn. This Co@NC-MOF catalyst () exhibited an E onset of 0.97 V, an E 1/2 of 0.88 V, and a Tafel slope of 55 mV dec–1. The catalytic activity may be ascribed to the efficient electron transfer from NC shell to Co NPs.

elements.content: The Zou and Xu groups have designed N- and S-doped non-noble metal honeycomb-like open porous carbon structures containing Co9S8 NPs derived from MIL-101-NH2. Because of multiple synergies this nanomaterial disclosed excellent electrocatalytic activity for the ORR with long-term stability and methanol tolerance comparable with commercial 20 wt % Pt/C catalyst under alkaline conditions. Therefore, the authors have achieved double encapsulation to uniformly and quantitatively introduce thiourea (TU) and CoCl2 forming [(TU)4Co]­Cl2 as the secondary precursors into the MOF pores without their aggregation on the MOF external surface ().
elements.clean_text:
The Zou and Xu groups
have designed N- and S-doped non-noble metal
honeycomb-like open porous carbon structures containing Co9S8 NPs derived from MIL-101-NH2. Because of multiple synergies this nanomaterial disclosed
excellent electrocatalytic activity for the ORR with long-term stability and methanol tolerance comparable with commercial
20 wt % Pt/C catalyst under alkaline conditions. Therefore, the authors
have achieved double encapsulation to uniformly and quantitatively
introduce thiourea (TU) and CoCl2 forming [(TU)4Co]­Cl2 as the secondary precursors into the MOF pores
without their aggregation on the MOF external surface ().

elements.content: Cu 3 P@NPPC-650 synthesized by Zang’s group is applied to both HER and ORR. This catalyst shows a half-wave potential (E 1/2) of 0.78 V with a limiting current density (J L) of 5.57 mA cm–2 in 0.1 M KOH, ascribed to the synergistic effect between the heteroatom-doped carbon and the Cu3P. On the basis of Cu, Wang and Tang et al. fabricated CuNC/KB-400 with Cu/Cu2O NPs and CuN x C y species from a Cu-MOF. CuNC/KB-400 exhibited better catalytic activity for ORR (E 1/2, 0.82 V; J L, 6.05 mA cm–2; and Tafel slope, 69.7 mA cm–2) than commercial Pt/C.

elements.content: Numerous non-noble bimetallic catalysts have recently been reported using a combination of Co with Mo, Fe, Ni, or Zn. Ni 3 FeN/Co,N-CNF developed by Zhang’s group exhibited good catalytic activity toward both OER and ORR. For ORR, it afforded a half-wave potential of 0.81 V and a Tafel slope of 52 mV dec–1, which is comparable to Pt/C. Li and Su’s group synthesized Co@NC-3/1 for both OER and ORR. The bimetallic Co/Zn catalysts synthesized from Co x Zn y BMZIF-derived porous carbon with various Co/Zn ratios combine the advantages of ZIF-8 and ZIF-67, possess highly graphitic carbon, large surface area, highly dispersed N and active C–N x groups. Upon carbonization of Co x Zn y BMZIF at 900 °C under Ar, Zn evaporated. The best catalyst, Co@NC-3/1, presented a high onset potential (E onset) of 1.15 V and E 1/2 of 0.93 V, i.e., superior performance and durability than commercial Pt/C (E onset, 0.93 V; E 1/2, 0.87 V), because of the active Co–N x species, evenly dispersed Co NPs and heteroatoms, and hierarchical pores.

elements.content: Li’s group fabricated ZnO/ZnCo 2 O 4 /C@rGO from ZIF-67 (). The E 1/2 of ZnO/ZnCo 2 O 4 /C@rGO was −0.15 V (V vs Ag/AgCl), less negative than Pt/C (−0.18 V), the Tafel slope of 46.70 mV dec–1 also outperforming Pt/C (74.79 mV dec–1). The good catalytic performance was attributed to the porous hollow structure and the synergistic effect between ZnO/ZnCo2O4/C and GO.

elements.content: Noble metals are no longer widely used in monometallic catalysts, but some reports still appeared using noble metals cooperating with Co, Fe, and Ce to improve the catalytic activities. Chen’s group synthesized np-PtFe/NPCS supported on N-doped carbon sheets via thermolysis of a Pt-modified Fe-MOF. Meanwhile the porous PtFe NPs are converted to a hollow structure. np-PtFe/NPCS exhibited a more positive E 1/2 (0.92 V) than Pt/C catalyst (0.883 V) and a smaller Tafel slope (40 mV dec–1) than Pt/C (48 mV dec–1) in 0.1 M HClO4, benefiting from the synergistic effect between PtFe NPs and the porous NC. Su and Wu’s group reported the preparation of Pt/40Co-NC synthesized from ordered Pt3Co NPs through thermal treatment of Pt NPs supported on Co-doped MOF-derived carbon. The dispersed Co sites originally embedded in MOF-derived carbon diffused into Pt NPs to form the final structure. Pt/40Co-NC showed a high E onset of 1.05 V and E 1/2 of 0.92 V, both higher than Pt/C (E onset, 1.02 V; E 1/2, 0.86 V), and the stability was also demonstrated by only a 12 mV decrease of E 1/2 after 30 000 cycles.

elements.content: CO2, the main fuel combustion product, is very largely available, but it is a very low-energy molecule. Thus its reduction () requires high reduction potentials. Therefore the finding of clean, selective, and low-overpotential electrocatalytic reduction is a considerable challenge due to its complexity with multielectron step processes involved and the variety of reduction products including mainly CO and HCOOH but also some hydrogen, carbonate, oxalic acid, methane, and ethane.
elements.clean_text:
CO2 Reduction
Reaction (CO2RR)
CO2, the main fuel
combustion product,
is very largely available, but it is a very low-energy molecule. Thus
its reduction () requires high reduction potentials. Therefore the finding of clean,
selective, and low-overpotential electrocatalytic reduction is a considerable
challenge due to its complexity with multielectron step processes
involved and the variety of reduction products including mainly CO
and HCOOH but also some hydrogen, carbonate, oxalic acid, methane,
and ethane.

elements.content: Yet in nature, photosynthesis efficiently converts it together with water into oxygen and energy-storing carbohydrates in most plants, algae, and cyanobacteria using green chlorophyll pigments of reaction centers. Although soluble synthetic porphyrin electrocatalysts suffer from limited density of reaction centers and side reactions, Co porphyrins proved to be very useful catalyst components in combination with MOF thin films and showed selectivity in the Fischer–Tropsch products CO and H2. These electrocatalysts also showed greater catalytic currents than homogeneous metalloporphyrin catalysts. Besides metalloporphyrin-MOF-based electrocatalysts, various metals have been probed in combination with MOF heterogeneous electrocatalysts, and interestingly, in early studies only Cu was found to efficiently lead to the formation of hydrocarbons. In nonaqueous media, oxalic acid or formic acid are produced. MOF-Cu electrocatalysts are indeed promising as also suggested by DFT calculation. Most recently, however, more and more non-noble metal catalysts based on Co, Ni, Mo, and Cu are being developed and applied for CO2RR, producing CO, HCOOH, CH4, and ethylene.

and ethylene.

elements.content: The Wu and Li group synthesized a series of atomically dispersed Co catalysts with various N coordination numbers from a bimetallic precursor Co/Zn-ZIF (). Among them, Co with two-coordinate N atoms, Co–N 2 , was the best catalyst in terms of both selectivity with the formation of 94% CO Faradaic efficiency and a current of 18.1 mA cm–2 at an overpotential of 520 mV and activity with TOF = 18200 h–1 in 0.5 M KHCO3 (pH = 7.2). Upon comparing Co–N 2 and Co–N 4 , DFT calculations demonstrated that less coordinated N to Co favors the CO2 activation and enhances the CO2RR activity.

elements.content: The same Wu and Li group developed single-Ni-site catalysts for CO2RR based on ionic exchange between ZnII nodes and NiII in the ZIF-8 cavity. ZIF-8 was dispersed in hexane, and Ni­(NO3)2 was injected in aqueous solution. The double-solvent approach allowed confining NiII in the ZIF-8 pores. This was followed by pyrolysis at 1000 °C under an Ar flow providing N-doped carbon skeleton while Zn (Eb: 907 °C) evaporated, providing N-rich defects. At an overpotential of 0.89 V, Ni SAs/N–C exhibited a high CO selectivity (Faradaic efficiency: 71.9%), a current density of 10.48 mA cm–2, and a TOF value of 5273 h–1.

elements.content: Han et al. synthesized MoP NPs supported on In-doped carbon using In-MIL-68 as a precursor. MoP@In-PC was fabricated by reaction between MoO2 with PH3 and H2. This catalyst MoP@In-PC provided a high Faradaic efficiency for formic acid (96.5%) and a current density of 43.8 mA cm–2 with [Bmim]­PF6 as the supporting electrolyte in MeCN/H2O. The catalytic performance was ascribed to the efficient adsorption of CO2 and the synergistic effect between MoP NPs and In–C supports.

elements.content: Sargent et al. designed a Cu catalyst for CO2RR toward high selectivity for C2 hydrocarbon. The Cu-MOF HKUST-1 was synthesized in which the SBU was a paddle-wheel Cu dimer stabilized by the four O atoms of the carboxylate groups. The authors optimized the surface topology and size of Cu clusters by promoting undercoordinated sites during the formation of Cu clusters upon control of the Cu dimer structure. Thus the symmetric Cu dimer of HKUST-1 was distorted to an asymmetric frame under selective thermal treatment at 250 °C detaching the carboxylate fragments, based on thermogravimetric studies. The modified, HKUST-1 catalyst exhibited in 1 M KOH a high Faradaic efficiency of 45% for C2H4, and a current density of 262 mA cm–2 was achieved at −1.07 V (vs RHE).

elements.content: In summary, there are multiple synergistic ways and types of interactions involving MOFs in NP catalysis. The Lewis acidic or basic MOF sites may interact with the NPs as well as other components of the nanocatalyst such as functional groups introduced during the MOF synthesis or by PSM, inorganic oxide NPs, or POMs. The MOF pores induce size selectivity in organic synthesis, enhance gas concentrations, and modulate the electronic properties of the NP catalysts that most often also act in synergy among the two metals in bimetallic NPs (for instance a noble metal and an Earth-abundant metal or a transition metal and a main-group element such as B, N, O, P, or S). These multicomponent synergistic interactions are best designed and optimized using DFT theoretical calculations given the high crystallinity of MOFs. Great progress and understanding are awaited from the area of pyrolysis of MNP@MOF compounds. This strategy is employed for the valorization of biomass. Therefore single-atom-based nanocatalysts are attracting increased attention.
elements.clean_text:
Concluding Remarks
In summary, there
are multiple synergistic ways and types of interactions involving
MOFs in NP catalysis. The Lewis acidic or basic MOF sites may interact
with the NPs as well as other components of the nanocatalyst such
as functional groups introduced during the MOF synthesis or by PSM,
inorganic oxide NPs, or POMs. The MOF pores induce size selectivity
in organic synthesis, enhance gas concentrations, and modulate the
electronic properties of the NP catalysts that most often also act
in synergy among the two metals in bimetallic NPs (for instance a
noble metal and an Earth-abundant metal or a transition metal and
a main-group element such as B, N, O, P, or S). These multicomponent
synergistic interactions are best designed and optimized using DFT
theoretical calculations given the high crystallinity of MOFs. Great
progress and understanding are awaited from the area of pyrolysis
of MNP@MOF compounds. This strategy is
employed for the valorization of biomass. Therefore single-atom-based nanocatalysts are attracting increased
attention.

elements.content: Photocatalysis is an environmentally friendly and convenient approach to convert solar energy into chemical energy. Almost 50 years ago, early studies led to the discovery of H2 production from water splitting from photocatalytic TiO2 materials. Since then semiconductor-promoted photocatalysis has remained an active research area. Presently the search of eco-friendly, cheap nanomaterials using sunlight for water splitting remains a formidable challenge for which MOF-based and derived nanomaterials occupy a central place. These photocatalysts are also active for a range of other transformations, including CO2 reduction, degradation of dyes and pollutants, and other organic reactions.
elements.clean_text:
Photocatalysis

has remained an active research area. Presently the search of eco-friendly,
cheap nanomaterials using sunlight for water splitting remains a formidable
challenge for which MOF-based and derived nanomaterials occupy a central
place. These photocatalysts are also
active for a range of other transformations, including CO2 reduction, degradation of dyes and pollutants, and other organic
reactions.

elements.content: Paralleling electrocatalysis, photocatalysis is increasingly involving MOF tools for hydrogen evolution from H2O. Several MOF-based photocatalysts have also been probed for H2 release from hydrogen storage inorganic materials, such as mostly ammonia borane and formic acid. Data obtained recently are summarized in .

for hydrogen evolution from H2O. Several MOF-based photocatalysts
have also been probed for H2 release from hydrogen storage
inorganic materials, such as mostly ammonia borane and formic acid. Data obtained recently are summarized in .

elements.content: When a semiconductor photocathode is irradiated by light with an energy superior to the semiconductor bandgap, an electron is injected from the semiconductor valence band to the conductive band, and this electron transfers to the catalyst surface via redox mediation to reduce a proton to adsorbed H atom and then H2. The highly competitive process is the recombination, with a strong driving force, of the generated electron with the electron hole that occurs if the mediation is not efficient enough and annihilates the reaction. Free holes and electrons are generated within picoseconds after light irradiation, but hydrogen generation only occurs on the order of microseconds.
elements.clean_text:
Hydrogen Production from
Water
When a semiconductor photocathode is irradiated by
light with an
energy superior to the semiconductor bandgap, an electron is injected
from the semiconductor valence band to the conductive band, and this
electron transfers to the catalyst surface via redox mediation to
reduce a proton to adsorbed H atom and then H2. The highly
competitive process is the recombination, with a strong driving force,
of the generated electron with the electron hole that occurs if the
mediation is not efficient enough and annihilates the reaction. Free
holes and electrons are generated within picoseconds after light irradiation,
but hydrogen generation only occurs on the order of microseconds.

elements.content: MOFs are essential in this context, because the MOF linker can be a semiconductor that transfers the light-generated electron to the nearby metal node by ligand-to-metal charge transfer (MLCT). The reduced metal node can then transfer the electron to the surface of the transition metal NP cocatalyst for proton reduction. The great structural versatility of the MOF allows exchanging the metal node, adapting the nature of the linker to the required semiconductor properties (verified by the MOF electrical conductivity), bearing ligands that can complex metal ions, and encapsulating the NP of choice. Water photosplitting using visible light is an immense challenge because most semiconductors absorb in the UV region. The use of photosensitizers such as organic dyes in combination with an inorganic semiconductor represents a solution to extend the light absorption from the UV region into the visible region. Thus, dye fixation on the semiconductor surface improves the electron transfer process because the dye absorbs visible light and then transfers the excited electron into the semiconductor conduction band. For instance, the organic dye Eosin Y has been much used for hydrogen generation, providing quantum yields between 9 and 19%. A well-known example of semiconductor is CdS due to its favorable band gap of ca. 2.4 eV that provokes excitation of charge carriers via effective absorption of solar light. A cocatalyst such as a transition-metal sulfide (instead of rare and expensive Pt) is employed to inhibit the fast electron–hole recombination and achieve good performances, including high hydrogen generation and quantum yield. Recent research has involved MOF nanomaterial engineering with a heterojunction, the junction between two distinct semiconductors that considerably enhances the photocatalytic activity. Bimetallic heterojunction photocatalysts are obtained upon pyrolyzing a metal-MOF-semiconductor precursor. Finally in phocatalytic H2 generation, a sacrificial agent is required stoichiometrically as an electron donor to scavenge the photogenerated holes. This is a great difficulty because the oxidation of water to O2 is sluggish, and otherwise, if in an electron donor such a sacrificial amine is stoichiometrically used, the benefit of H2 production is annihilated.

elements.content: Hydrogen evolution photocatalysts based on non-noble metals including Ti, Fe, Co, Ni, Cu, Zn, Mo, Cd, and In are being increasingly investigated. In order to decrease the overpotential, the cocatalyst needs active exposed facet and large dispersion, providing fast charge transfer and low surface hydrogen adsorption energy. The adsorption of H atom on the catalyst surface is the essential step of HER, determining its kinetics, and it is reflected by the adsorption energy.
elements.clean_text:
Hydrogen evolution
photocatalysts based on non-noble metals including
Ti, Fe, Co, Ni, Cu, Zn, Mo, Cd, and In are being increasingly investigated.
In order to decrease the overpotential, the cocatalyst needs active
exposed facet and large dispersion, providing fast charge transfer
and low surface hydrogen adsorption energy. The adsorption of H atom
on the catalyst surface is the essential step of HER, determining
its kinetics, and it is reflected by the adsorption energy.

elements.content: A number of reports have recently appeared combining the semiconductor TiO2 with a MOF to design a photocatalyst in which the visible light becomes efficient and the hole–electron pair recombination is inhibited. The Cheng group reported titanium dioxide hollow nanospheres (HNP) TiO 2 HNPs externally decorated with ZIF-8 using sonochemistry. The resulting composite showed dispersion of ZIF-8 on the TiO2 HNP surface. An apparent quantum efficiency of 50.89% was obtained, and the photocatalyst exhibited 3.5 times higher HER than bare TiO2 HNPs due to synergistic activation in the hybrid double shell HNP.
elements.clean_text:
A number of reports have recently appeared combining the semiconductor
TiO2 with a MOF to design a photocatalyst in which the
visible light becomes efficient and the hole–electron pair
recombination is inhibited. The Cheng group reported titanium
dioxide hollow nanospheres (HNP) TiO

2

HNPs externally decorated with ZIF-8 using sonochemistry.
The resulting composite showed dispersion of ZIF-8 on the TiO2 HNP surface. An apparent quantum efficiency of 50.89% was
obtained, and the photocatalyst exhibited 3.5 times higher HER than
bare TiO2 HNPs due to synergistic activation in the hybrid
double shell HNP.

elements.content: Lu et al. found that the hydrogen adsorption energy on various bimetallic sulfide cocatalysts Co x Ni4–x S4 could be adjusted by variation of the Co/Ni ratio. Using a DFT calculation, these authors proposed that Co2Ni2S4 possess the lowest hydrogen adsorption energy in the Co x Ni4–x S4 series; and then they synthesized Co 2 Ni 2 S 4 @MIL-101 to photocatalyze H2 generation. A rate of 441.4 μmol h–1 g–1 was obtained because of the low hydrogen adsorption energy of Co2Ni2S4 and the stability of intermediates during the reaction.

elements.content: Kim’s group designed an onion slice-type Co4S3 nanomaterial Co 4 S 3 /CdS from Co-MOF (). The Co4S3 NPs effectively accelerated charge separation and transfer because of the low density, hollow interior, and shell permeability of the onion-morphology. A H2 production rate of 12360 μmol h–1 g–1 in cobalt sulfide-based composites was obtained. The photocatalyst Co 4 S 3 /CdS was stable for 65 h of H2 generation reaction and could be reused for five runs.

elements.content: Stylianou et al. mixed MIL-125-NH2 as the photocatalyst with Ni2P NPs as the cocatalyst in a solvent mixture composed of CH3CN, NEt3 (sacrificial electron donor), and water and used visible light irradiation (300 W Xe lamp). The synthesized Ni 2 P/MIL-125-NH 2 catalyst benefitted from the high intrinsic activity of Ni2P and the efficient electron transfer from MOF to Ni2P. A H2 generation rate of 894 μmol h–1 g–1 H2 was achieved with quantum yields of 27.0 and 6.6% at 400 and 450 nm, respectively, and the photocatalyst was recycled for 7 catalytic runs of 12 h each. Neppolian et al. designed a Cu2O-encapsulating NH2-MIL-125­(Ti) MOF by postsynthetic encapsulation of the Cu2O NP cocatalyst (). In Cu 2 O/NH 2 -MIL-125­(Ti), Cu2O NPs located in the MOF pores facilitated electron transfer and the Ti3+ sites favored charge separation, drastically reducing electron–hole pair recombination. A H2 production activity of 11055.5 μmol h–1 g–1 was achieved under solar light, 28 times superior to that of the pristine MOF, and the catalytic activity remained for 5 runs of recycling.

elements.content: Cheng et al. fabricated ZnO/ZnS nanomaterials (average size: 20 nm) through calcination of MOF-5 (Zn) as a host and thioacetamide as a sulfur source guest. The nanoscale heterojunction formed ZnO/ZnS was tuned to enhance photocatalytic HER activity with visible light (λ > 420 nm) with high stability and recyclability without cocatalyst. The best catalyst ZnOS-30 (calcination time in air, 30 min) exhibited a photocatalytic HER activity at a rate of 415 μmol h–1 g–1 because of the shorter path of charge carriers and the efficient charge separation by the ZnO/ZnS structure. Jin et al. showed the enhanced synergistic effects of MoS2 quantum dots and graphene as cocatalysts for the photocatalytic activity of UiO-66-NH2 combined with the dye sensitizer Eosin Y. Graphene is an efficient cocatalyst due to its exceptional electron mobility and large surface. Thus, these authors fabricated MoS 2 QDs/UiO-66-NH 2 /G, and they employed this photocatalyst for a H2 production rate of 62.12 μmol h–1 g–1 with apparent quantum efficiency of 40.5% under visible light irradiation (λ > 420 nm). The proposed mechanism involved light absorption by Eosin Y on the MOF surface forming singlet excited state Eosin Y*1, decaying to triplet Eosin Y*3 quenched by triethanolamine (TEOA) to give Y– that transfers the electron to the MOF, graphene, and finally MoS2 that reduces H2O to H2. Sun and Zhang’s group incorporated CdS quantum dots and carbon nanodots (CDs) into the cages of the MIL-101 nanoreactor using the one-step double-solvent method followed by heating. With the optimum CD content of 5.2 wt %, the photocatalyst CD/CdS@MIL-101­(50) exhibited an H2 evolution activity at a rate of 14.66 μmol h–1 under visible light irradiation. This rate was 8.5 and 18.6 times higher than that of CdS@MIL-101 and bare CdS, respectively, and this enhancement was assigned to the effect of CDs serving as electron collector increasing the photogenerated charge lifetime. Han et al. assembled hollow hexagonal porous microrods In2O3@C from core–shell In2O3@carbon nanoparticles (PHIC). Therefore, these authors achieved thermal decomposition upon calcination of the In-MIL-68 precursor in one-step. PHIC afforded a H2 production of 2700 mmol h–1 g–1, higher than that of commercial In2O3 (543 mmol h–1 g–1). The H2 yield rate was comparable to that of Pt/PHI, hollow hexagonal microrods assembled from In2O3 NPs without carbon layer, which showed that the carbon layer coating of In2O3 NPs has an effect comparable to that of Pt. There was no apparent deactivation of the photocatalyst after 5 reaction cycles.

elements.content: There is continuous interest in Pt and other noble-metal catalysts given the initial impressive performances of Pt photocatalysts for H2 evolution from water. Liu and Su’s group synthesized a dye-sensitized photocatalyst Calix-3/Pt@UiO-66-NH 2 -1. This catalyst achieved a high hydrogen production activity (1528 μmol h–1 g–1). Liu et al. elaborated a strategy to inhibit hole–electron pair recombination by introducing PtNPs into UiO-66-NH2 followed by using graphene oxide wrapping around the external surface of the MOF in order to facilitate electron transfer on the MOF surface, and they therefore fabricated the catalyst GOWPt@U 6 N-8 mL. Because of efficient electron transfer, high molar absorptivity, and low aggregation tendency this catalyst provided a H2 generation rate of 18.15 mmol h–1 g–1, 21 times higher than the PtNP inside-only decorated sample and 32 times than the outside-only decorated one (GOWU6N). A decrease of the H2 generation activity was observed after the first cycle, however. Pt/PCN-777 synthesized by Jiang’s group produced a H2 production rate of 586 μmol g–1 h–1 in the presence of TEOA (triethyl orthoacetate). Upon replacing TEOA by benzylamine, the H2 production rate decreased to 332 μmol g–1 h–1, while the benzylamine was oxidized to N-benzylbenzaldimine. The same group also confined the single Pt atoms into the catalyst Al-TCPP MOF (), and Al-TCPP-0.1Pt exhibited a H2 production rate of 129 μmol g–1 h–1, higher that that of Al-TCPP-PtNPs (50 μmol g–1 h–1). DFT calculations suggested that the hydrogen binding energy improved the H2 production activity with the single Pt atoms introduction. Jiang et al. further introduced a plasmonic metal Au in order to inject hot electrons to the LUMO (lowest unoccupied molecular orbital) of semiconductor-like MOF (MIL-125). The catalyst Pt@MIL-125/Au then showed a H2 production rate of 1743 μmol g–1 h–1.

elements.content: Wan and Guo et al. introduced a methylthio terephtalate group into MIL-125 by solvent-assisted ligand-exchange and then doped this methylthio-functionalized MOF with Pt to obtain Pt/20%-MIL-125-(SCH 3 ) 2 . The methylthio group helps the absorption band extension to the visible-light region by donating the sp3 electrons. A H2 production with quantum yield of 8.90% at 420 nm was obtained, and the rate of 3814.0 μmol g–1 h–1 was much higher than that of Pt/MIL-125-NH2 (366.7 μmol g–1 h–1). Liu and Wang reported that postsynthetic modification of a triazine-based MOF [PCN-9­(Co)] by PtII complexation of the N atom of triazine enhanced photocatalytic HER under UV–vis light irradiation by about 6.8 times compared to that of PCN-9­(Co) because Pt improved the separation efficiency of photogenerated charge carriers. Wang and Su reported the photocatalytic HER activity of an amine-functionalized polyhedral Zr MOF (510.42 μmol g–1 h–1) and its further enhancement upon introduction of Pt, which was assigned to efficient electron–hole separation, targeted electron transfer, and recombination suppression.

elements.content: Besides Pt, other noble metals have also been used to catalyze H2 evolution. In particular, the Au plasmon has been utilized by several research groups. Tilgner and Kempe reported the combination of plasmonic Au irradiation with the semiconducting properties of TiO2. Therefore, these authors utilized MIL-101 (Cr) as core material to stabilize and direct the size of the core–shell photocatalyst composite. The Zhang group demonstrated that Au plasmon excitation by visible light boosted the HER reaction in N-doped carbon-Au NP resulting from pyrolysis at 900 °C under N2 of Au-ZIF-8 together with furfuryl alcohol that retained the porous framework while expanding the active surface area by evaporating Zn. Upon visible light irradiation, the overpotential of HER at a current density of 10 mA cm–2 decreased from 196 mV to 99 mV and an ∼4-fold enhancement was obtained, which was attributed to efficient charge transfer of N-doped carbon that fastened the injection of hot electrons from the plasmonic Au NPs. MIL-101-core-Au/anatase-shell was synthesized toward photocatalysis of HER from water. The anastase shell was formed stepwise using [Ti­(O-i-Pr)4] as a precursor, and a hydrogen evolution rate of 903 μmol g–1 h–1 was obtained. Visible light plasmonic Au NP irradiation on TiO2 shell produced higher activity than Au–P25 (Degussa).

elements.content: The intrinsic photoactivity of ZIF-67 was enhanced by energy transfer from a photosensitizer RuN3 on the surface of ZIF-67 by Huang’s group. RuN 3 /ZIF-67 sensitized by the photosensitizer RuN3 on the surface of ZIF-67 allowed for reaching a hydrogen evolution rate of 4.85 μmol g–1 h–1 without a cocatalyst. The photocatalyst NH 2 -MIL-125­(Ti)/0.75CN/Ni 15.8 Pd 2.1 was synthesized by Wang’s group. It showed a hydrogen production rate of 8.7 mmol g–1 h–1, attributed to efficient charge transfer by the NiPd NPs cocatalyst and the intimate interfacial contact between the MOF and CN.

elements.content: Only a few publications recently appeared on photocatalytic hydrogen generation using MOF-based or MOF-derived nanomaterials from some inorganic hydrides, i.e., ammonia borane and formic acid. Gu and Su et al. synthesized and compared a series of Co/Ni-MOF-NH2 and Co/Ni-MOF catalysts for AB hydrolysis. The results indicated that the catalysts with NH2-functionalized photoactive MOFs performed better than nonfunctionalized MOFs. The visible light irradiation enriched the electron density of Co and Ni NPs, and the highest TOF value (117.7 min–1) was achieved with Co/MIL-101­(Cr)-NH 2 . This catalyst preserved its activities after 25 runs of reaction. Kim et al. doped Pd NPs to a core–shell MOFs@COFs (covalent organic frameworks) to form Pd/TiATA@LZU1 and then applied this photocatalyst for a tandem AB dehydrogenation and styrene hydrogenation reaction in a dual-chamber microreactor. Under visible light irradiation, a TOF value of 147 molH2 molPd –1 min–1 was achieved for dehydrogenation of AB, due to the synergistic effect among the MOF electron donor, the COF shell mediator, and the Pd NP active sites. Xu et al. reported Pt@Rh/p-TiO 2 with subnanometer core–shell Pt@Rh NPs using MIL-125-derived TiO2 as both photoreductant and catalyst support. The TOF value of AB hydrolysis with Pt@Rh/p-TiO 2 was high, 2441 min–1 (within 1.17 min; n metal/n AB = 0.0011) at 30 °C due to the synergistic effect between the two metals, the subnanometer and uniform particle size.

elements.content: For photocatalytic hydrogen generation from formic acid decomposition, Mori and Yamashita’s group fabricated Au@Pd/UiO-66­(Zr 85 Ti 15 ) upon assembling Au@Pd NPs on NH2-functionalized MOFs {UiO-66­(Zr100–x Ti x )}. The photoactive MOFs and the localized surface plasmon resonance effect of Au promoted the electron-rich Pd sites () and then boosted the TOF value to 200 h–1 for FA dehydrogenation. Kinetic isotope effect (KIE) measurements suggested that the C–H cleavage of FA was the rate-determining step.

elements.content: Besides the production of hydrogen, the photoreduction of anthropogenic CO2 (CO2RR) also is of high interest in order to contribute to compensate excessive CO2 emission due to fossil fuel consumption. This process was first discovered by Inoue et al. in 1979 using Xe lamp irradiation and a suspended semiconductor photocatalyst. Photoreduction benefits from the sunlight energy to reduce this cheap and abundant low-energy C1 molecule to valuable products. Indeed such photoreduction is difficult because single-electron reduction of CO2 requires about 1.9 eV, which is above the conduction band of the semiconductors. Whereas homogeneously photocatalyzed CO2 photoreduction is marred by catalyst separation, the heterogeneously catalyzed reaction by semiconductor suspension most often produces CO, although it might be coupled with water splitting and water–gas-shift reaction to produce methanol. For instance, 2 C O 2 + 4 H 2 O → C H 3 OH + O 2

elements.content: This reaction remains a real challenge, however, and research in this area is still in its infancy. Heterogeneous photocatalysts for CO2 reduction include semiconductors, transition metal NPs, and alloys and carbon materials, and besides CO, a variety of other reaction products have been obtained including methane, ethane, ethylene, propylene, methanol, ethanol, and formic, acetic, and malonic acids. Reactions are most often conducted in water (although CO2 is a little soluble), which mimics photosynthesis in nature. In this case, water is oxidized to O2 by the electron hole upon photoexcitation, thus both CO2 reduction potentials and water oxidation potential must be taken into account for the electronic potentials of the photocatalysts. The surface of the catalyst (porosity, defects, etc.) is most important for its interaction with and activation of CO2.
elements.clean_text:
This reaction remains a real challenge,
however, and research in this area is still in its infancy. Heterogeneous
photocatalysts for CO2 reduction include semiconductors,
transition metal NPs, and alloys and carbon materials, and besides
CO, a variety of other reaction products have been obtained including
methane, ethane, ethylene, propylene, methanol, ethanol, and formic,
acetic, and malonic acids. Reactions are most often conducted in water
(although CO2 is a little soluble), which mimics photosynthesis
in nature. In this case, water is oxidized to O2 by the
electron hole upon photoexcitation, thus both CO2 reduction
potentials and water oxidation potential must be taken into account
for the electronic potentials of the photocatalysts. The surface of
the catalyst (porosity, defects, etc.) is most important for its interaction
with and activation of CO2.

elements.content: The major difficulties to overcome in CO2 photocatalytic reduction are (i) photolysis must occur with light of sufficient energy to reach the conducting band of the semiconductor bandgap that usually is in the UV region (only 4% of sunlight) and (ii) the fast electron–hole recombination competes after photoirradiation. Thus, although easily available TiO2 has long been the most studied photocatalyst nanomaterial engineering during the last four decades, researchers have attempted to design new photocatalysts that are efficient with visible light and increase the quantum efficiency by decreasing the electron–hole recombination. In this context, the catalyst improvements brought about by the contribution of MOF-based and MOF-derived nanomaterials has attracted much attention given their rich and tunable photocatalytic properties.

recombination competes after photoirradiation. Thus, although easily

nanomaterial engineering during the last four decades, researchers
have attempted to design new photocatalysts that are efficient with

improvements brought about by the contribution of MOF-based and MOF-derived

elements.content: If MOF metal nodes act as semiconductor QDs, the organic linkers are antenna sensitizing the QDs, and fast charge transfer to metal cluster is efficient. In addition a photoactive metalloligand may also be added by a postsynthetic method. The large structural diversity of these MOF elements makes them tunable photocatalysts. summarizes the recent data obtained with MOF NP photocatalysts.
elements.clean_text:
If
MOF metal nodes act as semiconductor QDs, the organic linkers
are antenna sensitizing the QDs, and fast charge transfer to metal
cluster is efficient. In addition a photoactive metalloligand may
also be added by a postsynthetic method. The large structural diversity
of these MOF elements makes them tunable photocatalysts.
 summarizes
the recent data obtained with MOF NP photocatalysts.

elements.content: The MOFs used for photocatalytic CO2 reduction have recently been ZIF-8, ZIF-9, ZIF-67, UiO-66, HKUST-1, MOL, MIL-125, NENU-10, MOF-74, and PMOF. Besides classic homogeneous Re-based catalysts that have been introduced into MOF pores, CO2 photoreduction has been initiated by MOF metal nodes and hybrid systems as nanomaterial composites. The photocatalysts have been MOF-based, with the exception of a HKUST-derived catalyst. In many cases, a MOF structure has been associated with a semiconductor NP such as TiO2, Co3O4, Zn2GeO4, Cd0.2Zn0.8S, ZnO, CdS, or CsPbBr3 loaded in the MOF pores for synergistic reduction of the semiconductor band gap from the UV to the visible light energy region. Carbon materials such as amine-functionalized graphene or graphitic carbon nitride nanosheets are sometimes integrated in the photocatalysts in order to improve electronic conductivity inhibiting electron–hole recombination.
elements.clean_text:
The MOFs used for photocatalytic CO2 reduction have
recently been ZIF-8, ZIF-9, ZIF-67, UiO-66, HKUST-1, MOL, MIL-125, NENU-10, MOF-74, and PMOF. Besides classic homogeneous Re-based catalysts that have been introduced
into MOF pores, CO2 photoreduction has been initiated by
MOF metal nodes and hybrid systems as nanomaterial composites. The
photocatalysts have been MOF-based, with the exception of a HKUST-derived
catalyst. In many cases, a MOF structure
has been associated with a semiconductor NP such as TiO2, Co3O4, Zn2GeO4, Cd0.2Zn0.8S, ZnO, CdS, or CsPbBr3
 loaded in the MOF pores for synergistic reduction of the semiconductor
band gap from the UV to the visible light energy region. Carbon materials
such as amine-functionalized graphene or graphitic carbon nitride nanosheets are sometimes integrated in the photocatalysts in order to improve
electronic conductivity inhibiting electron–hole recombination.

elements.content: Using the high CO2 adsorption capacity of MOFs, Maina et al. developed Cu-TiO 2 -ZIF-8 by depositing ZIF-8 on graphene oxide then adding semiconductor Cu-TiO2 nanoparticles. 2170 ppm g–1 for CO and 2238 ppm g–1 for methanol were produced with 7 μg of Cu-TiO2 NPs loading under UV light irradiation. The catalytic performances are due to the synergistic effect between the semiconductor NPs and MOFs and the use of dimethylacetamide as the solvent that possesses a higher CO2 solubility than H2O. DFT studies conducted by the Zhang group on the ligand effects of NH2, OH, and NO2 on the photocatalytic properties of Ti-based MIL-125 MOF showed that new energy bands appeared in the MOF band gap after introducing this group in the BDC linker and that the NH2 group decreased the band gap of MIL-125 that became significantly shifted toward the visible region. Uribe-Romo’s group also studied the effect of substituents of the MIL-125 terephthalate linkers on the bandgap and photocatalytic properties of these MOFs under blue illumination over 120 h. These authors showed that the secondary N-alkyl groups (isopropyl, cyclopentyl, and cyclohexyl) involve larger apparent quantum yields than the primary N-alkyl analogs directly related to their longer-lived excited-state lifetime, and that, in particular, the cyclopentyl group induces a small bandgap (E g = 2.30 eV), a long-lived excited-state (τ = 68.8 ns), and a larger apparent quantum yield (Φapp = 1.80%) compared to the parent MIL-125-NH2 (E g = 2.56 eV, Φ app = 0.31%, τ = 12.8 ns). These fine and conclusive substituent studies bring about precious information on the molecular engineering of photocatalysts. Wang’s group synthesized HKUST-1/TiO 2 nanocomposites in microdroplets through an aerosol route. A CO yield of 256.35 μmol/(g-TiO2 h) was obtained by HKUST-1/TiO 2 (ratio: 3.33), much higher than that of TiO2 [11.48 μmol/(g-TiO2 h)] because of the reactant adsorption promoted by MOF. Heterojunctions (vide supra) between the TiO2 and Cu2O semiconductors have been introduced by He and Wang via microdroplet approach followed in the in situ growth of the [Cu3(BTC)2] MOF. This is a rare case for which CO2 photoreduction preferentially produces CH4. The enhanced performances were assigned to the semiconductor heterojunction and unsaturated copper coordination sites. The Li group synthesized simple Ni, Co, and Cu isostructural MOFs and found that the Ni-MOF was the best photocatalyst for CO2 reduction to CO with 97.7% selectivity (). Model studies allowed proposing a mechanism involving CO2 coordination to a Ni node followed by protonation then proton-induced loss of hydroxide to form water followed by CO decoordination. Using HKUST-1 as a precursor and further loading on graphitic carbon nitride, Sun and Wang’s group synthesized C–Cu 2–x S@g-C 3 N 4 and used this nanomaterial to catalyze CO2 photoreduction. This is a rare example of MOF-derived photocatalyst for CO2 reduction. As an electron reservoir, the carbon coat in the catalyst facilitated the electron–hole pair separation. When the C–Cu2–x S content was 0.71 wt %, the selectivity of 97% and yield of 1062.6 μmol g–1 for CO were obtained upon CO2 photoreduction by H2O after 12 h. As a catalyst component, NH2-UiO-66 was combined with Cd0.2Zn0.8S solid solution by Wang’s group for enhanced photocatalytic CO2 reduction to produce CH3OH.

elements.content: The Sun group introduced the sensitizer [Ru­(bpy)3]­Cl2·6H2O] into the new pillared-layer porous high-nuclear Ag@Co-ZIF-9. With the use of this nanomaterial, photocatalysis of CO2 reduction to CO with visible-light irradiation provided, after 0.5 h, 28.4 μmol CO and 22.9 μmol H2. Upon attaching [ReI(CO)3(BPYDC)­Cl] to Zr-UiO-67, the Yaghi group fabricated a CO2 photoreduction catalyst that was coated onto Ag nanocubes (). The Re centers were confined to the intensified near-surface electric field at the Ag nanocube surface resulting in a 7-fold enhancement of CO2 conversion to CO under visible light, and the catalyst stability was maintained for 48 h. The Xu group reported the use of Au nanorods (NRs) serving as cores for the epitaxial growth of Ag shells, followed by oxidative etching, which led to the trinuclear Au@PtAg nanorattles with an aqueous K2PtCl4 solution. These trinuclear NPs were encapsulated in ZIF-8, and this nanocomposite photocatalyzed the selective gas-phase CO2 reduction by H2O to CO. Ryu et al. reported UiO-67 modification with a Re photocatalyst and a primary amine to produce a photocatalyst for CO2 reduction to CO under visible light in the presence of TEA. The activity was 3-fold superior to that of the same catalyst without the primary amine. Au@NENU-10, consisting of Au NPs, Ti-substituted Keggin-type polyoxometalate [PTi2W10O40]7– (PTiW), and HKUST-1 in which the PTiW was used as an electron and proton reservoir was synthesized by Liu’s group. This nanocomposite served as a visible-light photocatalyst for CO2 reduction to CO that was 85.3 times more efficient than the analogue containing [PW12O40]3–, which was ascribed to the higher net charges on the terminal oxygen atoms.

elements.content: Zhong’s group fabricated CsPbBr 3 QDs/UiO-66­(NH 2 ) from perovskite CsPbBr3 QDs and UiO-66­(NH2). High CO2 conversion was reached at 98.57 μmol g–1 upon modifying the CsPbBr3 QDs content as 15 wt % under Xe lamp. This catalytic performance resulted from efficient charge separation and transfer between the MOF and the semiconductor CsPbBr3.

as 15 wt % under Xe lamp. This catalytic
performance resulted from efficient charge separation and transfer
between the MOF and the semiconductor CsPbBr3.

elements.content: In conclusion, the use of various MOF as photocatalyst components is very promising toward future prospects. Precious information has been obtained on the roles and synergies of the linkers, their substituents, nodes, additives, various semiconductor NPs, carbon materials, heterojunction, and in particular, their influence on the UV to visible region shift of the semiconductor band gaps. The results are still modest in terms of TOFs despite recent progress. The stability of the MOF has been increased with the appearance of very stable MOFs such as the ZIP types but remains a point of care. Recent mechanistic studies bring some light on reaction mechanisms, but progress still remains to be conducted for clarification, for instance using transient absorption techniques. If photocatalytic CO2 reduction is desired, it must be accompanied by oxidation of water to O2 by the electron hole. Many if not most studies are not conducted in water and need a sacrificial reagent such as amine, H2, etc., which remains ecologically and economically problematic. MOFs are extraordinarily rich and powerful nanomaterials, and therefore, there is no doubt that the future will open immense progress.
elements.clean_text:
In
conclusion, the use of various MOF as photocatalyst components
is very promising toward future prospects. Precious information has
been obtained on the roles and synergies of the linkers, their substituents,
nodes, additives, various semiconductor NPs, carbon materials, heterojunction,
and in particular, their influence on the UV to visible region shift
of the semiconductor band gaps. The results are still modest in terms
of TOFs despite recent progress. The stability of the MOF has been
increased with the appearance of very stable MOFs such as the ZIP
types but remains a point of care. Recent mechanistic studies bring
some light on reaction mechanisms, but progress still remains to be
conducted for clarification, for instance using transient absorption
techniques. If photocatalytic CO2 reduction is desired,
it must be accompanied by oxidation of water to O2 by the
electron hole. Many if not most studies are not conducted in water
and need a sacrificial reagent such as amine, H2, etc.,
which remains ecologically and economically problematic. MOFs are
extraordinarily rich and powerful nanomaterials, and therefore, there
is no doubt that the future will open immense progress.

elements.content: Water contamination by organic pollutants, in particular dyes and antibiotics, is a crucial and vital environmental problem of human health. Many of these pollutants contain aromatic fragments that are very resistant to biological and other classic treatments. Using sunlight to degrade the pollutants by means of highly active oxygen radicals such as hydroxide radical (OH•) or superoxide radicals (O2 •–) for ultimate oxidation to CO2 and H2O is highly desirable. Direct bond cleavage by light being rarely possible, the intermediacy of semiconductors facilitates this process by photoinjection of an electron from the semiconductor valence band with creation of a hole (h+) to its valence band if the light energy is superior to the semiconductor band gap. Further mechanisms are not obvious and depend on the system and substrate, but anyway, the electron hole is strongly oxidizing (for instance oxidizing H2O to OH•) if recombination of the hole–electron pair can be avoided. If the high-energy electron in the conducting band can be quenched by oxygen producing O2 •–, the latter can be aggressive toward groups of the pollutant by nucleophilic reaction and even more so in nonaqueous media. TiO2 is the most popular semiconductor and has been used for pollutant degradation, but its band gap (3.2 eV) necessitates UV light, restricting applications. Metal sulfides including CdS, In2S3, Sb2S3, and CoS2 are often considered because their lower band gaps allow their effective function with visible light, but their use is ecologically very problematic, when they contain a toxic heavy metal. Therefore, the search of new semiconductor systems is very challenging, and the role of MOFs in this context is highly promising, as for other photocatalyzed reactions. MOFs themselves are semiconductors with tunable band gaps due to their extraordinary designable structural variety, and they have been extensively probed in the early investigation for this purpose. Several well-documented reviews are available on this topic, in particular, the later one by the Wang group. Pristine MOFs have been the subject of a large number of studies, but their photoactivity remains modest. Consequently, there have been only a few studies of such MOF electrocatalysts during the last two years. Investigations of pristine MOFs in photo-oxidation of pollutants are nowadays published along with the syntheses of new MOF such as in Kumar’s publication on Co and Zn coordination polymers. Recent articles on MOF semiconductors for depollution focus on composite photocatalysts that are hybrid nanomaterials composed at least of a semiconductor and a MOF. Again the most frequent combination is that of TiO2 with a MOF. Nanomaterials including TiO2 semiconductor as multifunction photocatalysts have been reviewed by Zou’s group who has also appropriately emphasized the specificity and interest of the construction of robust Ti­(IV)-based MOFs for these applications. TiO2 has recently been associated with MIL-88B, MIL-101, and MIL-125. Other associated semiconductors mostly include metal oxides such as α-Fe2O3 with UiO-66, Fe3O4 with MIL-100­(Fe), ZnO with ZIF-8, ZrO2 with HKUST-1, Ag2WO4 with UiO-66, and rare cases of metal phosphates such as Ag3PO4 with MIL-53 (Fe) and UMOFN, CdS with MIL-53­(Fe). Magnetic catalysts among the semiconductors, i.e., α-Fe2O3 are especially useful for recycling. Coupled to NH2-MIL-125, QDs served as both electron acceptors promoting photoinduced charge separation and spectrum converter to convert NIR light into visible light. Heterojunctions juxtaposing two distinct semiconductors are often used to boost performances. The recent data are summarized in .
elements.clean_text:
Degradation of Organic Contaminants
Water contamination
by organic pollutants, in particular dyes and
antibiotics, is a crucial and vital environmental problem of human
health. Many of these pollutants contain aromatic fragments that are
very resistant to biological and other classic treatments. Using sunlight
to degrade the pollutants by means of highly active oxygen radicals
such as hydroxide radical (OH•) or superoxide radicals (O2
•–) for ultimate oxidation to CO2 and H2O is highly desirable. Direct bond cleavage
by light being rarely possible, the intermediacy of semiconductors
facilitates this process by photoinjection of an electron from the
semiconductor valence band with creation of a hole (h+)
to its valence band if the light energy is superior to the semiconductor
band gap. Further mechanisms are not obvious and depend on the system
and substrate, but anyway, the electron hole is strongly oxidizing
(for instance oxidizing H2O to OH•) if recombination
of the hole–electron pair can be avoided. If the high-energy
electron in the conducting band can be quenched by oxygen producing
O2
•–, the latter can be aggressive
toward groups of the pollutant by nucleophilic reaction and even more
so in nonaqueous media. TiO2 is the most popular semiconductor
and has been used for pollutant degradation, but its band gap (3.2
eV) necessitates UV light, restricting applications. Metal sulfides
including CdS, In2S3, Sb2S3, and CoS2 are often considered because their lower band
gaps allow their effective function with visible light, but their
use is ecologically very problematic, when they contain a toxic heavy
metal. Therefore, the search of new semiconductor systems is very
challenging, and the role of MOFs in this context is highly promising,
as for other photocatalyzed reactions. MOFs themselves are semiconductors
with tunable band gaps due to their extraordinary designable structural
variety, and they have been extensively probed in the early investigation
for this purpose. Several well-documented reviews are available on
this topic, in particular, the later one by the Wang group. Pristine MOFs have been the subject of a large
number of studies, but their photoactivity remains modest. Consequently,
there have been only a few studies of such MOF electrocatalysts during
the last two years. Investigations of pristine MOFs in photo-oxidation
of pollutants are nowadays published along with the syntheses of new
MOF such as in Kumar’s publication on Co and Zn coordination
polymers. Recent articles on MOF semiconductors
for depollution focus on composite photocatalysts that are hybrid
nanomaterials composed at least of a semiconductor and a MOF. Again
the most frequent combination is that of TiO2 with a MOF.
Nanomaterials including TiO2 semiconductor as multifunction
photocatalysts have been reviewed by Zou’s group who has also
appropriately emphasized the specificity and interest of the construction
of robust Ti­(IV)-based MOFs for these applications. TiO2 has recently been associated with MIL-88B,
MIL-101, and MIL-125. Other associated semiconductors mostly include metal oxides such
as α-Fe2O3 with UiO-66, Fe3O4 with MIL-100­(Fe), ZnO with ZIF-8, ZrO2 with HKUST-1, Ag2WO4 with UiO-66, and
rare cases of metal phosphates such as Ag3PO4 with MIL-53 (Fe) and UMOFN, CdS with MIL-53­(Fe). Magnetic catalysts among the semiconductors, i.e., α-Fe2O3 are especially useful for recycling. Coupled to NH2-MIL-125, QDs served as both electron acceptors
promoting photoinduced charge separation and spectrum converter to
convert NIR light into visible light. Heterojunctions juxtaposing two distinct semiconductors are often
used to boost performances. The recent
data are summarized in .

elements.content: The most frequently studied dyes are Rhodamine B (RhB) and methylene blue (MB), the degradation of some other dyes (MO: methylene orange) have been less frequently examined. TiO2 is still widely used in the photocataltytic degradation field. TP-222­(Zn) containing a porph-Zr-MOF and linked TiO2 NPs () was synthesized by Zhang and Feng et al. and showed efficiency for photocatalytic degradation of RhB. Complete RhB degradation along with a rate constant of 0.01239 min–1 was achieved under visible light irradiation due to the promoted charge separation and transfer from MOF to TiO2 NPs. The TON only changed a little (725 to 719 mg g–1) from the first degradation cycle to the fourth cycle, demonstrating the high stability of TP-222­(Zn).

elements.content: Remarkably, there are very few reports using MOF-derived catalysts even recently, presumably due to the success of MOF-based catalysts. Zhang and Liu’s group fabricated and phosphatized a bimetallic Co/Fe-MOF material producing Cp/Fe metal-phosphide embedded in mesoporous carbon, CoP/Fe 2 P@mC, that was active to degrade RhB in visible light. The efficiency of this photocatalyst was assigned to the high electron–hole separation rate of Fe2P@mC, fast electron transfer from CoP@mC, and strong absorption of mesoporous carbon based on radical trapping and ESR data.

elements.content: Feng’s group reported a ternary photocatalyst UiO-66/g-C3N4/Ag for which the catalytic efficiency in decomposition of RhB and 2,4-dichlorophenoxyacetic acid (2,4-d) increased compared to that of the MOF alone due to synergies among the catalyst components. Sofi and Majid reported plasmon-induced charge transfer across Zr-UiO-66 coupled Ag2WO4 heterojunction combined with AgNPs for the photodegradation of azo and nonazo dyes (RhB), under visible light. Synergistic effects of the heterojunction and the Ag NP plasmon were found responsible for the favorable photocatalytic properties.

elements.content: Li’s group has investigated RhB degradation use a core–shell photocatalyst UCNP@NH 2 -MIL-53­(Fe) through NaYF4:Yb,Tm and a NH2-functionalized MOF. Lanthanide ion-doped UCNPs (UpConversion NPs) are a special anti-Stokes emission material that absorbs near-infrared (NIR) photons then emits a photon with higher energy (UV and visible regions). Considering that MOF photocatalysts can be activated by UV and visible photons, integration of UCNPs into MOFs is a potential way to develop NIR-responsive photocatalysts (). A degradation rate over 80% was achieved for photocatalytic RhB degradation by UCNP@NH 2 -MIL-53­(Fe).

elements.content: The ternary 2D photocatalyst BiOBr/GO/MOF-5 was synthesized by the Chen group by ultrasonic-assisted solvothermal method and exhibited degradation of RhB because of excellent electron mobility of GO enhancing charge separation of electron–hole pairs and to the large MOF-5 surface area.

elements.content: Wheatley et al. degraded MB using the photocatalyst SnO 2 @ mono ZIF-8 integrated with SnO2-NPs to a monolithic MOF (ZIF-8). 41.5% of MB was degraded in 3 h with 53 μmol of SnO 2 @ mono ZIF-8, and the degradation rate increased to 93.6% with a larger amount of catalyst (225 μmol). The MB degradation rate was sustained with 39.4 after the 10th cycle of reaction, revealing the recyclability of catalyst.

elements.content: Shen and Li studied the photocatalytic degradation of methyl orange (MO) through calcination of a Zn/Co-ZIF. The MOF-derived material ZnO@C–N–Co contained ZnO NPs in the core and Co NPs with graphitized carbon in the shell. This catalyst displayed the good degradation percentage of 99.5% for MO after 2.5 h (apparent rate constant: 0.0283 min–1) because of the synergistic effect between the ZnO and C–N–Co shell.

shell.

elements.content: The degradation of antibiotics is particularly important due to the antibiotic resistance, a rapidly developing phenomenon due to the resistance of bacteria resulting from the wide use of antibiotics in animal food and human drugs for decades. Zhang and Xie’s groups have addressed the problem of antibiotics photodegradation with a combination of MIL-53­(Fe) and Ag3PO4 using the examples of tetracycline derivatives. Thus, tetracycline hydrochloride, oxytetracycline, and chlortetracycline were the subject of these studies. Upon exposition for 1 h to visible light, destruction was achieved on the order of 90%. Yang et al. studied the photodegradation of a typical fluoroquinolone antibiotic, norfloxacin (NOR), with the BiOr-UiO-66-NH2 composite under simulated sunlight. UiO-66-NH2 content of 20 wt % (BUN-20) showed the best performance for the removal of NOR. The removal efficiency of NOR (10 mg/L) over BUN-20 (0.3 g/L) was 93.60% within 180 min irradiation. Efficiency was ascribed to photoadsorption capacity and weaker recombination probability of electron–hole pair.

elements.content: Pan’s group reported the pyrolysis of MIL-125 in NH3 atmosphere at 500 °C producing N-doped anatase/rutile mixed-phase TiO2 (A/R N-TiO2) that was efficient for the photodegradation and mineralization (77% in 100 min) of nitrobenzene under UV irradiation.

under UV irradiation.

elements.content: The photodegradation of cyhalothrine, an insecticide of the pyrethrinoid family, is urgent because its wide use has caused high toxicity to the aquatic organism and danger for the bioenvironment. Cao’s group has examined cyalothrin photodegradation using a combination of HKUST-1 and CuCl2. With ZrO2, a junction formed with HKUST-1, narrowing the band gap and reducing the recombination of photoinduced carriers. The composite photocatalysts used are efficient not only for the degradation of organic contaminants but also for the inorganic ones. For instance, MIL-88B­(Fe)­Ag-TiO 2 NT/Ti plates were active for the removal of Pb2+. Yao’s group reported that the photocatalyzed reduction of Cr­(VI) was promoted by the nanocomposites Au/UiO-66-NH2 and Au/UiO-66 in which the activity was synergistically boosted by combination between Au NPs and the MOF.

elements.content: Cui’s group synthesized core–shell Ag 3 PO 4 @UMOFNs by coating ultrathin two-dimensional Ni–Co MOF nanosheets on Ag3PO4 NPs. For degradation of phenol and biphenyl A, the degradation rate was 100% within 16 min and 98.9% within 20 min, respectively. The enhanced photocatalytic performance was ascribed to the promoted charge transfer by the MOF π–π bonds and the weak interactions between Ag3PO4 and MOFs.

elements.content: Zheng and Jiao fabricated the catalyst Bi 2 WO 6 /MIL-100­(Fe) for the degradation of salicylic acid. The degradation rate for salicylic acid was improved to 95.1% by Bi 2 WO 6 /MIL-100­(Fe) compared to 65% by Bi2WO6 after 50 min irradiation because of the facilitated electron–hole pairs separation by the p–n junctions between MOFs and Bi2WO6. In addition, no obvious loss of degradation rate was observed after five cycles of the reaction, showing the stability of the catalyst.
