elements.content: In conclusion, research on photodegradation of organic and inorganic pollutants is bursting obviously for ecological reasons and the development of nanomaterials. MOFs play an important role in the design of photocatalysts due to their extremely flexible design possibilities and semiconductor behavior. Irradiation of a photosensitive linker is facilitated by subsequent fast LMCT to the neighboring metal node. Combination of the MOF with NP guests and specific groups on the linker facilitate charge separation and catalytic photoactivity. Mixing MOFs in binary or ternary composites including heterojunction semiconductors, metal NP, plasmonic metals, and carbon materials (GO and C3N4) was found essential to create synergies boosting the photocatalytic activities. Several dyes, phenols, and antibiotics have been targeted, and the spectrum of targets will necessarily need extension in the close future. It is likely that further research will include more catalysts not only based on MOFs but also derived from MOFs.
elements.clean_text:
In conclusion, research
on photodegradation of organic and inorganic
pollutants is bursting obviously for ecological reasons and the development
of nanomaterials. MOFs play an important role in the design of photocatalysts
due to their extremely flexible design possibilities and semiconductor
behavior. Irradiation of a photosensitive linker is facilitated by
subsequent fast LMCT to the neighboring metal node. Combination of
the MOF with NP guests and specific groups on the linker facilitate
charge separation and catalytic photoactivity. Mixing MOFs in binary
or ternary composites including heterojunction semiconductors, metal
NP, plasmonic metals, and carbon materials (GO and C3N4) was found essential to create synergies boosting the photocatalytic
activities. Several dyes, phenols, and antibiotics have been targeted,
and the spectrum of targets will necessarily need extension in the
close future. It is likely that further research will include more
catalysts not only based on MOFs but also derived from MOFs.

elements.content: Besides HER, CO2 photoreduction, and decontamination from organic pollutants, there are a few distinct photocatalytic reactions. Cohen’s group reported a representative review of organic transformation photocatalyzed by MOFs until the end of 2016. These earlier works included photooxidation of alcohols, olefins, and cyclohexane by MOF SBUs behaving as semiconductors, activities of metalloligands of MOFs for photooxidation of amines, phenol, and sulfides and oxidative C–N bond formation, enhanced catalysis by encapsulating catalysts in MOFs, and photocatalysis by MOF-containing composites using benzylic alcohol oxidation as a model reaction. Composite photocatalysts are rapidly developing, and their remarkable properties together with recent examples have been emphasized in the previous sections. Some additional cases of various reactions including tandem reactions catalyzed by MOF-based or MOF-derived composite photocatalysts have appeared since 2017, often interfacing with the other sections of this review.
elements.clean_text:
Miscellaneous Photocatalyzed Reactions
Besides HER,
CO2 photoreduction, and decontamination from
organic pollutants, there are a few distinct photocatalytic reactions.
Cohen’s group reported a representative review of organic transformation
photocatalyzed by MOFs until the end of 2016. These earlier works included photooxidation of alcohols,
olefins, and cyclohexane by MOF SBUs behaving as semiconductors, activities
of metalloligands of MOFs for photooxidation of amines, phenol, and
sulfides and oxidative C–N bond formation, enhanced catalysis
by encapsulating catalysts in MOFs, and photocatalysis by MOF-containing
composites using benzylic alcohol oxidation as a model reaction. Composite
photocatalysts are rapidly developing, and their remarkable properties
together with recent examples have been emphasized in the previous
sections. Some additional cases of various reactions including tandem
reactions catalyzed by MOF-based or MOF-derived composite photocatalysts
have appeared since 2017, often interfacing with the other sections
of this review.

elements.content: Oxidative coupling of amines to imines using O2 in air as oxidant was reported by Han and Chen et al., who synthesized therefore a butterfly-like TiO2@N-doped porous carbon (TNPC) by calcination of NH2-MIL-125 (Ti) (). This photocatalyst led to a yield of 99% (rate constant, 0.14 h–1) after 17 h for the oxidative coupling of benzylamine due to the efficient charge separation. DFT calculations together with transient absorption spectroscopy were utilized to show the charge carrier dynamics in N-doped catalyst, assigning the photocatalytic performance to long-lived holes.

elements.content: Chen and Lu et al. reported oxidation of H2S photocatalyzed by a double-shell urchin-inspired nanomaterial, TiO 2 @MIL-101, by coating MIL-101 (Cr) MOF onto hollow TiO2. In the presence of oxygen, TiO 2 @MIL-101 exhibited a H2S conversion rate of 90.1% after 60 min, almost two-times faster than with hollow TiO2 because of the excellent H2S adsorption capability of MIL-101. In this process, H2S was oxidized by the high-energy photogenerated OH• radicals formed upon H2O oxidation by the electron holes.

elements.content: Chen and Han et al. reported C–C bond forming reactions photocatalyzed by Cu2O@N–C (MCNC). This nanomaterial was synthesized by calcination of a Cu MOFs (NTU-105) () and catalyzed coupling reactions between various indole derivatives with N-aryl-tetrahydroisoquinoline in 89–99% yields. The composite offers favorable photocatalysis advantages: the porous C matrix substrate stabilizes small Cu2O NPs, inhibiting aggregation, Cu2O N-doping, enhances conductivity, and uniform distribution of N-doped Cu2O NPs produces many active sites. The stability of the catalyst MCNC was established by 5 runs of recycling experiments without loss of catalytic activity.

elements.content: Su’s group reported ZnCo2O4 mesocrystal on rGO synthesized by annealing ZnCo ZIF on rGO. The ZnCo2O4 photocatalyst was active in NO photo-oxidation (83.8% under visible light and 92.6% under simulated solar light) and was more stable than N-doped TiO2.

more stable than N-doped TiO2.

elements.content: Kim et al. reported hydrogenation of styrene photocatalyzed by a Pd-doped MOFs@COF nanomaterial, Pd/TiATA@LZU1, that displayed good catalytic performance for the tandem reaction of AB dehydrogenation and styrene hydrogenation. Complete conversion of styrene with a high selectivity for ethylbenzene (>99%) was obtained after 15 min under visible-light irradiation (TOF: 589 h–1) because of the synergistic effect between the Pt active center, the MOF electron donor, and electron transfer by COF.

elements.content: The N-alkylation of amines with alcohols was reported by Li’s group who synthesized bimetallic nanomaterial PdAu@MIL-100­(Fe) by encapsulating 1.7 nm PdAu alloy NPs into MIL-100­(Fe). A conversion of 99% and yield of 93% were obtained for the N-alkylation of aniline by benzyl alcohol photocatalyzed by Pd 1 Au 1 @MIL-100­(Fe) after 24 h under visible-light irradiation. The reaction rates of the two consecutive steps in the N-alkylation reaction, photocatalytic alcohol dehydrogenation and imine hydrogenation, were synchronized in order to optimize the whole process.

elements.content: Photoreduction of Cr­(VI) was reported by Jiang and Ai et al., who synthesized the catalyst Ag/AgCl@MIL-53-Fe by combining plasmonic Ag/AgCl and photoactive MIL-53-Fe. Ag/AgCl@MIL-53-Fe was both efficient for photodegradation of RhB and photoreduction of Cr­(VI). For Cr­(VI) reduction, high reduction efficiency (99.4%) and rate constant (1.002 h–1) were achieved under visible light irradiation after 4 h. After five-run recycling, 93% of Cr­(VI) reduction by Ag/AgCl@MIL-53-Fe was still maintained.

elements.content: Sun et al. reported photocatalytic oxygen evolution using the catalyst In 2 O 3 -450 containing the n-type semiconductor In2O3. In 2 O 3 -450 was synthesized by calcination of an In-based sod-ZMOF at 450 °C, and the In2O3 band gap narrowed to 2.9 from 3.7 eV of the pure In2O3 because of N-doping and formation of oxygen vacancies. In 0.1 M KOH, an overpotential for a current density of 10 mA cm–2 (0.60 V) and small Tafel slope (60 mV dec–1) were reached for oxygen evolution under Xe lamp irradiation with long-term durability.

elements.content: In photocatalytic water splitting, the OER being sluggish, Jiang’s group astutely coupled HER with the value-added benzylamine oxidation in the absence of a sacrificial agent. Charge separation was enhanced by the use of an elongated conjugated ligand in PCN-777. Upon catalyst Pt/PCN-777 photoexcitation, the excited electron produced H2 (vide infra) while the electron holes were used for amine oxidation (rate, 1512 μmol g–1 h–1; selectivity, 99% reached in the presence of 200 mg AgNO3).

elements.content: Dai and Fu et al. reported CO oxidation using a composite photocatalyst, Au/ZIF-8-TiO 2 , prepared by distributing ZIF-8 onto the surface of TiO2 to prevent the aggregation and migration of Au NPs and promote electron transfer between TiO2 and Au NPs. Benefiting from ZIF-8, the catalytic activity of Au/ZIF-8-TiO 2 was remarkably enhanced compared to Au/TiO2. The many delocalized π electrons of ZIF-8 could transfer electron density to TiO2 and mediate electron transfer between Au and TiO2 induced by the Au NP plasmon under visible light irradiation. The catalytic performance did not improve too much from dark to visible light conditions, however.
elements.clean_text:
Dai
and Fu et al. reported CO oxidation using a composite photocatalyst, Au/ZIF-8-TiO

2
, prepared by distributing
ZIF-8 onto the surface of TiO2 to prevent the aggregation
and migration of Au NPs and promote electron transfer between TiO2 and Au NPs. Benefiting from
ZIF-8, the catalytic activity of Au/ZIF-8-TiO

2
 was remarkably enhanced compared to Au/TiO2. The many delocalized π electrons of ZIF-8 could transfer
electron density to TiO2 and mediate electron transfer
between Au and TiO2 induced by the Au NP plasmon under
visible light irradiation. The catalytic performance did not improve
too much from dark to visible light conditions, however.

elements.content: In summary, composite photocatalysts present possibilities of multiple activation potentially for a large variety of substrates and reactions because of the synergy between MOFs with metal and semiconductor NP components. The goal of these synergies is to favor charge separation by decreasing band gaps and increasing catalyst stabilities. There is now room for considerable selectivity and efficiency improvements. Further mechanistic studies and DFT calculations are still also necessary toward optimized catalyst design.
elements.clean_text:
Concluding Remarks
In summary, composite
photocatalysts present possibilities of multiple activation potentially
for a large variety of substrates and reactions because of the synergy
between MOFs with metal and semiconductor NP components. The goal
of these synergies is to favor charge separation by decreasing band
gaps and increasing catalyst stabilities. There is now room for considerable
selectivity and efficiency improvements. Further mechanistic studies
and DFT calculations are still also necessary toward optimized catalyst
design.

elements.content: Catalysis is of prime importance in the transformation of chemicals in industry as well as in the laboratory, and MOFs are taking a fast-growing part in catalytic processes. With more than 20 000 MOFs fabricated so far, the selection of catalytically useful MOFs is becoming more demanding in order to satisfy the requirement of stability, selectivity, and efficiency of MOF-based and MOF-derived nanocatalysts. This review has presented first an introduction and general background on MOF nanocatalysis including mentions of seminal and representative examples of catalysts reported in the first 20 years of the field and then a comprehensive view of the last years of research in the field of MOF-based and MOF-derived nanocatalysis.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions and Prospects
Catalysis is of prime importance in the transformation of chemicals
in industry as well as in the laboratory, and MOFs are taking a fast-growing
part in catalytic processes. With more than 20 000 MOFs fabricated
so far, the selection of catalytically useful MOFs is becoming more
demanding in order to satisfy the requirement of stability, selectivity,
and efficiency of MOF-based and MOF-derived nanocatalysts. This review
has presented first an introduction and general background on MOF
nanocatalysis including mentions of seminal and representative examples
of catalysts reported in the first 20 years of the field and then
a comprehensive view of the last years of research in the field of
MOF-based and MOF-derived nanocatalysis.

elements.content: MOF thermal stability and in particular stability toward water is a primary consideration in catalysis with durability for recycling, harsh catalytic conditions, and resistance to an environment that has been verified, in particular, for MOF-74, ZIF-8, CPO-27, UiO-66, Cu-BDC (HKUST-1), MIL-53, and MIL-101. Recent emphases on high-oxidation-state metal nodes (TiIV and ZrIV) still improve stability trends.
elements.clean_text:
MOF thermal stability
and in particular stability toward water
is a primary consideration in catalysis with durability for recycling,
harsh catalytic conditions, and resistance to an environment that
has been verified, in particular, for MOF-74, ZIF-8, CPO-27, UiO-66, Cu-BDC (HKUST-1), MIL-53, and MIL-101. Recent emphases on high-oxidation-state metal nodes (TiIV and ZrIV) still
improve stability trends.

elements.content: MOFs present the advantage over traditional heterogeneous catalysts to possess a perfectly defined architecture with specific pores allowing selective introduction of substrates. MOFs can be engineered and tailored on demand for a given purpose with considerable flexibility in the design of the nature of the metal nodes and linkers. The influential factors concerning the metal nodes include the oxidation state, redox activity, possibilities of metal-cation exchange and solvent removal for unsaturation, whereas those of the linkers are the acidity, redox properties, and possibilities of functionalization. The choice of the MOF cavity is also dictated by the size of the metal, metal cluster, metal derivative, or semiconductor nanoparticle or any substrate that needs to be introduced inside the MOF or around which the MOF is constructed. A drawback for the characterization of MOF-encapsulated nanoparticles is the difficulty of imaging by TEM or HRTEM due to MOF framework shielding. Digestion of the MOF and extraction of the nanoparticle with a polymer is not fully satisfactory. Likewise alloys are difficult to analyze inside MOFs by EDS line scanning or elemental mapping. Therefore, new techniques must be developed.
elements.clean_text:
MOFs present the advantage over traditional
heterogeneous catalysts
to possess a perfectly defined architecture with specific pores allowing
selective introduction of substrates. MOFs can be engineered and tailored
on demand for a given purpose with considerable flexibility in the
design of the nature of the metal nodes and linkers. The influential
factors concerning the metal nodes include the oxidation state, redox
activity, possibilities of metal-cation exchange and solvent removal
for unsaturation, whereas those of the linkers are the acidity, redox
properties, and possibilities of functionalization. The choice of
the MOF cavity is also dictated by the size of the metal, metal cluster,
metal derivative, or semiconductor nanoparticle or any substrate that
needs to be introduced inside the MOF or around which the MOF is constructed.
A drawback for the characterization of MOF-encapsulated nanoparticles
is the difficulty of imaging by TEM or HRTEM due to MOF framework
shielding. Digestion of the MOF and extraction of the nanoparticle
with a polymer is not fully satisfactory. Likewise alloys are difficult
to analyze inside MOFs by EDS line scanning or elemental mapping.
Therefore, new techniques must be developed.

elements.content: For catalysis, metal nanoparticles must be very small, ideally of subnanometer size, although the efficiency sometimes decreases when the nanoparticle size decreases below a certain atom number. For instance in dendrimers, that can be considered as the equivalents of MOFs in homogeneous catalysis, the Yamamoto group demonstrated that the golden number for Pt nanocluster catalysis was 19 for both ORR and aerobic toluene oxidation, i.e., the catalytic efficiency was lower below 19 Pt atoms. This also raises the question concerning the optimized catalysis by single atom catalysts for which the first MOF examples have recently started to appear and how single-atom catalysts compare with subnanoclusters in terms of catalytic efficiency. Single-atom catalysts are the equivalents of the numerous monometallic complexes in homogeneous catalysis whose efficiency is extremely variable depending on the nature of the metals and ligands. As recently pointed out by Corma, the difference in heterogeneous catalysts is that the ligands of the single atoms are rigidly held in solid matrices, whereas they are more flexible when the complexes are soluble. Also note that single atom catalysis has been frequently encountered for several decades in Basset’s catalytic organometallic surfaces. The merit of single-site catalysis, however, is that it emphasizes the need to intimately characterize the catalytic event and its precise steps at the atomic and molecular levels. Therefore, the ongoing contribution of MOF catalyst to single-site catalysis is a major one because it involves a rather clearly defined framework environment around the catalytic sites. The relationship between the MOF framework and the catalytically important nanoparticle shape also remains to be determined. In this sense, organometallic chemistry helps one to understand MOF catalysis, and in turn, MOF catalysis helps one to understand heterogeneous catalysis. Nevertheless, progress is awaited concerning the characterization techniques to define the single-site catalyst and its detailed behavior during the catalytic act.

elements.content: The precise definition of the MOF template should also promote increased efforts for tandem reactions and for enantioselective catalysis using homochiral MOFs for the design of asymmetric induction pathways for which a proof of concept was provided a decade ago. Sophistication of the MOF architecture by recently designed combined MOFs or MOF@MOF may allow the performance of multistep reactions with improved catalyst separation. There also is a potential for the use of MOFs as enzyme supports for which attempts have already been reported. In particular, the Yaghi and Sommorjai groups have very recently fabricated MOF-808 with appropriate topology and functionality to postsynthetically install imidazole-containing fragments that were coordinated to CuI in the presence of oxygen for selective oxidation of methane to methanol under isothermal conditions at 150 °C. A methane-monooxygenase-like bis (μ-oxo) dicopper species was proposed as the active catalytic site. It is likely that this MOF-enzyme/biomimetic area will burst shortly.

elements.content: Beyond the advantage of precision, MOF nanocatalysis has provided the possibility of involving several components to obtain synergistic catalytic effects between the MOF itself and encapsulated metal nanoparticle or other metal species (cluster, POM, nanoparticle, and semiconductor), encapsulated alloys involving additional synergies. Postsynthetic modifications bring about more synergies by mixing metal nodes and linker functional groups and ligands. Many strategies involving chemical, electrochemical, and photochemical aspects of MOF nanocatalysis focus on avoiding the use of noble metals and their replacement by Earth-abundant elements acting in synergy. This is the case for hydrogen generation for which Co and Ni nanoparticles, in particular P-doped ones, should replace the best performing Pt nanoparticles, although performances are still far inferior. In C–C coupling reactions, Ni catalysts are also on their way to compete with the classic Pd catalysts but with great progress still in front of us.
elements.clean_text:
Beyond the advantage of precision, MOF nanocatalysis
has provided
the possibility of involving several components to obtain synergistic
catalytic effects between the MOF itself and encapsulated metal nanoparticle
or other metal species (cluster, POM, nanoparticle, and semiconductor),
encapsulated alloys involving additional synergies. Postsynthetic
modifications bring about more synergies by mixing metal nodes and
linker functional groups and ligands. Many strategies involving chemical,
electrochemical, and photochemical aspects of MOF nanocatalysis focus
on avoiding the use of noble metals and their replacement by Earth-abundant
elements acting in synergy. This is the case for hydrogen generation
for which Co and Ni nanoparticles, in particular P-doped ones, should
replace the best performing Pt nanoparticles, although performances
are still far inferior. In C–C coupling reactions, Ni catalysts
are also on their way to compete with the classic Pd catalysts but
with great progress still in front of us.

elements.content: A fast-increasing proportion of Earth-abundant metal MOFs are used to produce MOF-derived catalysts for which the MOF together with encapsulated materials are pyrolyzed at variable temperatures. The goal is to fabricate highly porous graphitized carbons with large surface areas, controllable hierarchical structures, and optimized porosities for mass transport and exposition of a large number of active sites, preferably N- or P-doped provided by the presence of precursors containing these elements. The templating MOF framework is preserved for maintaining a good porosity and stability of the catalyst. These nanomaterials including metal and metal oxide nanoparticles are fabricated with the aim of substituting noble metals in catalysis. They should be used more often in the future for the catalysis of organic reactions, but they already have been abundantly used with success for energy conversion and electrocatalysis of HER, OER, ORR, overall water splitting, and the highly energetic electrocatalytic CO2 reduction. Improved conductivity for adequate electron transfer is ensured by addition of graphene materials and/or CNTs. Obvious advantages are the simplicity of the synthesis and handling and the low cost.
elements.clean_text:

hierarchical structures, and optimized porosities for mass transport
and exposition of a large number of active sites, preferably N- or
P-doped provided by the presence of precursors containing these elements.
The templating MOF framework is preserved for maintaining a good porosity
and stability of the catalyst. These nanomaterials including metal
and metal oxide nanoparticles are fabricated with the aim of substituting

for the catalysis of organic reactions, but they already have been
abundantly used with success for energy conversion and electrocatalysis
of HER, OER, ORR, overall water splitting, and the highly energetic
electrocatalytic CO2 reduction. Improved conductivity for
adequate electron transfer is ensured by addition
of graphene materials and/or CNTs. Obvious advantages are the simplicity
of the synthesis and handling and the low cost.

elements.content: Limitations are the impossibility to control the fine structure in the absence of mechanistic information, disordered structures with lack of interconnection of the pores, and the absence of understanding of the possibilities to optimize electrocatalytic properties. These features are especially crucial for improvement of the central OER and its reverse ORR process marred by their sluggish kinetics. Here again molecular inorganic chemistry should bring precious information on the precise chemistry of the metal-oxo species involved on the oxide surfaces in electrocatalysis. An extended number of MOFs should be probed in order to improve our understanding, and operando in situ monitoring would bring considerable knowledge on these processes. As in general in heterogeneous catalysis, in situ surface techniques including XAS, XPS, XRD, and TEM allowing to follow catalyst evolution along the reaction should be of great help. The engineering strategies for pore surfaces and their functionalization play a crucial role in heterogeneous catalysis and have been discussed in particular for MOF.

elements.content: Photocatalysis with MOF catalysts have been used to improve the well-known photocatalyzed water splitting induced by TiO2 with UV light. In particular, combining a semiconductor and a MOF in a composite photocatalyst with visible light brings about remarkable improvement. MOF structures allowed for a decrease in the semiconductor band gap to the visible region and for a decrease in the charge recombination by separating charges. However, the sluggish water oxidation by electron hole largely limits the efficiency of the HER process in absence of a more efficient sacrificial electron donor. Besides HER, two increasingly active areas of MOF-based photocatalysis using sunlight are photoreduction of anthropogenic CO2 to valuable C1 chemicals and photodegradation of organic contaminants, in particular, in view of water depollution. Photoreduction of CO2 with sunlight is a formidable challenge mimicking photosynthesis in water, and a variety of C1 products have been obtained, although CO is the most common one. CO2 is not very soluble in water, however, and quantum yields and turnover numbers remain low. Yet, the abundant recent research has allowed great improvement in the efficiency of MOF-semiconductor photocatalysts by functionalizing the MOF linker, optimizing the surface porosity and defects for active sites, using heterojunctions, and enriching the photocomposite catalyst by adding carbon materials in order to improve the electronic conductivity. The use of the plasmonic Ag or Au nanoparticles also allows injecting hot electron into the semiconductor photocatalyst to decrease the semiconductor bandgap. Another limit is the stability of MOFs to UV light in water, although recent MOFs are becoming more resistant. Many studies are not conducted in water but rather in CO2-solubilizing solvents with a sacrificial agent as electron donor reducing the electron hole. If this sacrificial agent could be an organic compound whose oxidation would add value, such solution would be beneficial but has rarely been used. Finally increased mechanistic and theoretical research with DFT calculations on this process should be very helpful.

elements.content: Photodegradation of organic contaminants is a bursting area using MOF-semiconductor nanocomposite photocatalysts because it is one of the most powerful decontamination methods, and the problem is increasingly becoming crucial for the environment. Presently, however, most studies concentrate on the degradation of a few dyes using UV light, whereas a much larger spectrum of organic and biomedical contaminants should be examined in the next future.

should be examined in the next future.

elements.content: Photolytic processes have rarely also involved polymerization. Yaghi’s group used MOF-901 and MOF-902 for the photocatalytic polymerization of methyl acrylate, benzyl methacrylate, and styrene under visible light in the presence of the co-initiator ethyl α-bromophenylacetate. Finally MOF have been shown to also generate radicals for Fenton-like catalysis. Nonmetallic cavities such as doped cellular carbon nanocapsules also are efficient electrode materials for energy storage. Covalent organic frameworks (COFs) are the cousins of MOFs and have not been considered in this review. COFs are deeply investigated for their physical properties and materials applications but less so in catalysis in spite of their capacity to encapsulate catalysts. COFs are sometimes associated in complex MOF structures for designed MOF applications.

COFs are deeply investigated for their physical properties and materials

elements.content: In this review, pristine MOFs and their Lewis-acid properties have been mentioned in the introductory background section and had been previously reviewed. Thus, they have not been further emphasized, especially because synergies with inter alia metal NPs and functionalization have been treated here and have brought about considerable catalytic improvements. Besides, although MOFs have been discussed as perfect materials, it has appeared that many catalytic properties were in fact due to defects in their structures, and this aspect has recently been emphasized. Moreover, as noted in the introduction, the stability of MOFs and their resistance in water is of prime importance for applications and, in particular, for their use in industry. Along this line, careful studies of the water stabilities of the various MOFs have delineated this important feature, and a number of early MOF catalysts have been discarded based on this criterion, whereas some MOFs have been found to be remarkably water resistant. Water-stable MOFs are key materials not only in catalysis but also, for instance, for removal of heavy metal and radionuclides. MOF-derived nanomaterials have been developed in recent years with great significance for energy-related problems including, in particular, as electrocatalysts and photocatalysts, and here again, the synergies between the nanomaterial components as well as the high porosity of doped graphitized carbon obtained upon pyrolysis of MOFs with other components have been shown to result in remarkable enhancement of electronic and catalytic properties. Another essential criterion for the use of MOF-based and MOF-derived catalysts in industry is their cost that usually remains rather high given their sophistication. This latter aspect is especially crucial and should be taken care of because by comparison the costs of zeolite catalysts are only of a few euros or dollars per kilograms and thus will remain difficult to challenge.

elements.content: In conclusion, MOFs will certainly continue to trigger much increasing research in the future with catalysis using Earth-abundant elements to efficiently address the most challenging chemical, energy, and environmental problems of our time. The greatest goals are fossil-free hydrogen production, selective methane oxidation, water splitting, CO2 reduction to methanol, nitrogen fixation, and water depollution.

elements.content:
The authors declare no competing financial interest.

Qi Wang was born in Luan, Anhui Province, China, and did undergraduate studies at the Anhui University in Hefei where she obtained her Master’s degree under the supervision of Dr. Yan Feng and then carried out Ph.D. studies in France as a Chinese Research Council awardee under the supervision of Professor Didier Astruc at the University of Bordeaux on hydrogen evolution reactions. She is presently completing her Ph.D. thesis with Professor Jean-Yves Saillard in Rennes with DFT calculations. Her interests are in the synthesis, properties, and applications of nanomaterials.

elements.content: Didier Astruc was born in Versailles and received his Ph.D. from the University of Rennes under the supervision of Professor René Dabard. He was then a NATO postdoctoral fellow at MIT with Prof. Richard R. Schrock and later spent a sabbatical year in Berkeley with Prof. K. Peter C. Vollhardt. He is a professor of chemistry at the University of Bordeaux and a Member of the Institut Universitaire de France and several Academies. He is the author of more than 500 research publications and several books including “Electron Transfer and Radical Processes in Transition Metal Chemistry” (VCH, 1995, foreword by Henry Taube) and “Organometallic Chemistry and Catalysis” (Springer, 2007). His present interests are in nanomaterials and, particularly, their applications in nanocatalysis.
